PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That the proposed changes to taxation on superannuation will have a dramatic impact on the lives of the majority of working Australians.

2. That Australian citizens have traditionally been proud to be independent and self-reliant of government and the proposed changes will effectively remove incentive for citizens to provide for their own retirement.
3. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any changes to the current tax arrangements for superannuation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the imposition of sales tax, import duties and other financial constraints on Telecom Australia will have the effects of:
Increasing local and STD call charges.
Increasing telephone rental charges.
Increasing delays in providing services to new, rural, most small business and domestic subscribers.
Decreasing service standards generally.
Leading to the destruction of the Australian telecommunications manufacturing industry.
Increasing the internal and external pressures for the deregulation and/or privatisation of Telecom Australia.
Leading to the abandonment of the ``service to all Australians'' principle on which Telecom Australia has always operated if deregulation and/or privatisation continues further.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government revokes its recent decisions applying extra financial burdens on Telecom Australia and takes appropriate steps to ensure that Telecom Australia has the legal, and financial ability to discharge its statutory obligations to provide universal service under its present monopoly status as the national telecommunications provider.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the House assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, Caesium-137, Caesium-134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray the Federal Government ban the importation of any radio-active substances or machinery for the purpose of food irradiation, disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia, and ban the irradiation of food in this country.
We also call upon the Federal Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia.
Respectfully showeth that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Childs (from 100 citizens) and Cook (from 58 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, Senator Collins, I withdraw Business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 2, 3 and 6 standing in his name for four sitting days hence, pursuant to notice of intention to withdraw given on 23 May 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

(c) calls upon the Government to annul its decision to close Page Primary School, and requires that the Government conduct a complete review of school planning in the South Belconnen region, which would give all schools involved, including parents of Page Primary School, an opportunity to respond to its proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, noting-
(a) the unsatisfactory answer given by the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Ray) in response to a question asked by Senator Patterson on 23 May 1988;

(b) the response to Senator Michael Baume's question in Senate Estimates Committee hearings by the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Ray) that the Government was not aware of the extent to which properties it owns were vacant or underutilised, that it would be a `herculean' task to find out and that `we may have to make a judgment as to the amount of resources we would need to devote to answering that question'; and

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH CAR DRIVERS: ACCESS TO NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate on 20 May during the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) the question of arrangements for Commonwealth car drivers to have access to the new Parliament House was raised. The Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, has approached me on this issue and I am able to inform all honourable senators that access arrangements for Commonwealth car drivers to the new Parliament House will be on the same basis as for this building.
—Another rumour gone.

—I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to reports in the Melbourne Sun and the Canberra Times quoting the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Bob Hogg, as telling the Victorian Parliamentary Press Gallery that there would be no savage cuts contained in tomorrow's mini-Budget, that the statement would deal with tariff levels, investment and `other inducements which will assist our own manufacturing base in this country'. In view of the understandable weight which would be attached to comments from someone in such a senior Party position, I ask the Minister: What access has Mr Hogg had to any of the detail of tomorrow night's statement? If no direct access has been allowed, has he been briefed on the general content of the mini-Budget, and by whom, and on whose authority was Mr Hogg given either access or briefing?

—I have not seen the Press reports to which Senator Chaney has referred but over the last three months I have seen a wide range of other Press reports about the likely contents of the May statement to be released tomorrow. It could well be that Mr Hogg, being a more careful peruser of the newspapers than Opposition senators, would have reached some conclusions of his own about the content of the May statement as a result of reading newspapers.
—Is that where you find out what goes on in this Government?
—If I said yes to that interjection, honourable senators would be better informed as a result of following the papers diligently--
—Is it government by leaks?
—No.
—Order!

—Mr Hogg would have had no access to Government decisions or documents relating to the May statement. I believe he would have had discussions with Ministers such as me in which I talked to him about the general tenor of the May statement. I have done that, but on nothing specific about any details which will be released tomorrow night.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. From that answer it is not at all clear whether what Mr Hogg said was speculative or whether it was based on a series of briefings, one of which was from the Minister. Since the reports do not suggest that Mr Hogg is speculating on the contents, will the Minister ascertain specifically what access Mr Hogg has been given to either documents or briefings from his colleagues and advise the Senate of the position?

—I have already answered that part of the question. I said that Mr Hogg had been given no access to documents or briefings in the strict sense of the term. As I said, I and undoubtedly other Ministers would have discussed with him, as we have discussed amongst ourselves and with others, the general contents of the May statement-in terms of what it will be about. That is all Mr Hogg's reported remarks really suggest.
—How do you know? You have not seen them.

—The honourable senator told me what they were in his initial question. Mr Hogg's remarks do not suggest any access. All they suggest is a general knowledge about the contents of the May statement. If I might say so, there are a number of people in industry who have, as a result of the consultative process which has been going on, a general understanding about the tariff issues in the May statement, but they do not know the details. There are two quite distinct questions. All Mr Hogg is really saying is that he has a general picture of what the May statement is about. Most people who have been studying the issue do.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to some comments made by Mr John Elliott, the Liberal Party President, at a conference in Sydney on the Pacific economy? Mr Elliott is reported to have said that Mr Keating cut off the economy at the knees in 1985 by raising interest rates.What in fact has been the growth in the level of economic activity in Australia since the Hawke Government took office? How does this compare with the period immediately preceding it? Are these figures compatible with the idea of the economy having been cut off at the knees in 1985?

—My attention has been drawn to statements by the Liberal Party President last week, or yesterday-I am not too sure. I do not know whether the statements should be attributed to a fundamental innumeracy, too much Fosters or a desire to consciously mislead the public. The best available indicator of the overall level of economic activity and growth is gross domestic product (GDP), even though Senator Coulter has some reservations about that. If he does, I trust he will put his ideas to the Australian Statistician, as I invited him to do before. Using that measure, between the March quarter of 1983 and the December quarter of 1987, the latest available figure in the period that covers the term of office of this Government, GDP in Australia went up by 22.7 per cent; that is, a compound rate of 4.4 per cent each year. March 1983 to December 1987 was a 4 3/4-year period. If we take the 4 3/4 years immediately preceding March 1983, GDP rose by 9.4 per cent, a compound rate of 1.9 per cent per year. So in the 4 3/4 years under Labor, GDP increased at a compound rate of 4.4 per cent. In the previous 4 3/4 years it increased at a compound rate of 1.9 per cent. In other words, the growth rate in GDP under the Labor Government is more than twice the growth rate recorded by the discredited Liberal Administration when John Howard was Treasurer. If we take a measure that some people would regard as more reliable, non-farm GDP, the figures are not quite so spectacular. Non-farm GDP under Labor grew at a 4.2 per cent compound annual rate and under the Liberal Party, over the same time period, it grew by 2.2 per cent. So it was more than twice as much by one measurement and almost twice as much by the other. If Mr Elliott thinks that is cutting the economy off at the knees, I wonder what he thinks Mr Howard did-presumably cut it off at the ankles.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce yet resolved his difficulties with Caucus in his efforts to win approval for a $30m cash injection for the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC)? If not, if he like Senator Evans has conceded the defeat of his attempt to get private capital into the AIDC, what alternatives is he considering to help overcome the Corporation's shortage of working funds?
—I am glad that Senator Lewis, as a result of two good AIDC dinners in the last year or so, is espousing the Corporation's cause in this chamber-I thought Liberal policy was to sell it.
—That would inject private funds into it.

—Would it? The answer to the first part of his question is no; the answer to the second part of the question is no; and the answer to the third part of the question relating to alternatives is that when the Government decides on that issue, it will advise him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY: PROTECTION OF WITNESSES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. In light of the death of Ms Cassandra Ogden some hours before she was due to reveal details of drug dealings to the National Crime Authority, will the Minister confirm that there is a regime in existence for the protection of witnesses giving evidence to that Authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to the question of protection of witnesses in general in a moment. The very tragic death of Ms Cassandra Ogden is before the Coroner in Melbourne at the moment. Therefore, it would not be proper for me to comment on any aspect of the National Crime Authority's operations, including any possible protection which was either offered or might be thought to have been required in relation to that witness. But in relation to the National Crime Authority in general, the fact is that the National Crime Authority does have a regime in place which provides for the protection of key witnesses and it does so in conjunction with relevant police forces, such as the Australian Federal Police and the police forces in New South Wales and Victoria.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority is, if not tomorrow, certainly by the end of this week, hoping to table in the Parliament its report on the whole question of witness protection across all the jurisdictions of Australia and how this important aspect of crime fighting might best be addressed on a national scale. The fact is that the assurance that one can give to potential witnesses of their physical safety and the preservation of their anonymity in certain situations is obviously very crucial to the gathering of evidence and the proceedings which may lead to the successful conviction of criminals targeted by the National Crime Authority in its investigations, whether general or by way of special reference. But the Government awaits that report with keen interest. I hope to be able to respond to it very promptly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is it the case that although funding for medical research through the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) was steadily increased in real terms between 1980 and 1986, funding has now plateaued and barely matches inflation? Is it the case that medical research done cheaply by postgraduate students has been, or is likely to be, reduced because of the Government's imposition of very high fees for overseas postgraduate students in the form of study visas, and because of the possible introduction by the Government of a graduate tax? Given all these indicators, has there been a change in the Government's attitude towards the funding of medical research and, if so, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean was kind enough to give me advance notice of this question and I obtained an answer from Dr Blewett to the three parts of the question. It is pleasing to note that in the first part of the question Senator McLean acknowledges that under the Hawke Government funding for research through the National Health and Medical Research Council has increased. That in itself is an acknowledgment that I think ought to be mentioned in reply to the question. However, the answer is that funding through the NHMRC steadily increased in real terms from 1980 to 1987. In 1988, in the context of overall financial constraints faced by the Government, the funding level was maintained at the same level as 1987 in real terms. This cannot be taken to indicate that the Government has determined a policy of maintaining a plateau on future funding research. In addition to appropriations to the NHMRC, the Government has allocated an additional $3m for acquired immune deficiency syndrome research and $1.3m for public health research and development projects. I am informed that Dr Blewett will be arguing strenuously for a real increase in the appropriation to the medical research endowment fund in the forthcoming Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of Senator McLean's question concerned whether our funding has been done cheaply by postgraduates and contained what I regard as a cheap political shot about the proposed introduction of a government graduate tax. The answer is: Funds for overseas postgraduate students have very little effect on the NHMRC as less than 6 per cent of the postgraduate training scholarships awarded by the NHMRC fall into this category. At this stage there is no indication that a graduate tax would necessarily deter people from pursuing postgraduate medical research training.
The last part of the question was: Given all these indicators, will the Government's attitude towards funding research change and, if so, why? The answer to that question is no, it will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not address one element of my question; that is, the impact of the $5,000 visa charge on those coming into the country to undertake postgraduate studies, some of them in the area of medical research.
—The answer I gave said that the fees for overseas postgraduate students have very little effect--
—A visa charge of $5,000.

—One assumes that not only the fees in general terms but also the visa charge are considerations for postgraduate students, and the answer that there is very little effect seems to me to stand. If I need to supplement that answer, I will do so; but I will put it on notice in order to do that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of comments by the Liberal Party's President, Mr John Elliott, to the Pacific Basin Economic Council-and he makes good reading-reflecting adversely on Australia as a place in which to invest? He stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Countries who do not perform in a competitive environment will cease to attract the capital of the major international companies.
What action is the Government taking to improve Australia's competitiveness in the company tax area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the last part of the question, Senator Beahan and everybody else will have to wait until tomorrow to find out the major component of what the Government has done. Of course, the Government has already made Australia a more attractive place in which to invest in a number of ways-principally, as I said in reply to an earlier question, by sustaining or making possible a high rate of economic growth by steadily bringing inflation down, apart from the devaluation-induced blip of a couple of years ago, from the 11.5 per cent we inherited from John Howard, to currently a little under 8 per cent. We brought the unemployment rate down and we have had an effective wages policy for five years. Of course, all of those things have made Australia an attractive place in which to invest.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not unusual, indeed, it is common- place, for Mr Elliott to be bucketing Australia to foreigners as it was for him up until a month ago to be advocating a consumption tax. It is something which he seems to be unable to resist. I suppose I should say in the context of a consumption tax that Mr Elliott has a record over several years of, essentially, trying to sabotage the Australian economy when he sets foot outside Australia, and now he has started doing it inside Australia as well. That is an attribute he has in common with the Liberal Party member of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly, Mr Ross Lightfoot, who, as we all know, wrote to George Shultz, the United States Secretary of State, last year begging the United States to resist any attempt to decontaminate or decorrupt, to use a term similar to that which Mr Kerin uses, international markets for agricultural products because, said Mr Lightfoot, he hoped the United States would depress prices for Australian agricultural exports as much as it possibly could in order to induce a recession or depression in Australia which he thought would then get rid of the Labor Government.

So Mr Elliott and Mr Lightfoot have that much in common. They are both, essentially, economic saboteurs. In that light it is not at all surprising that Mr Lightfoot wrote to Mr Elliott on 12 April 1988 congratulating him on his advocacy of a consumption tax and so on, and adding later:
I could not concede that the wider public appreciates the hollow chested, limp wristed mixture of wet Liberal socialism that some of our leaders offer, and with some alacrity, espouse.

I will not quote the entire letter. I will just table that letter from Mr Lightfoot to Mr Elliott and put it in the context that, of course, they admire each other because they are both economic saboteurs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Prices. Has the Minister noted the warning from his colleague Senator Walsh about the inevitability of higher taxes if the Government is forced to provide further capital for Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines? Is the Minister concerned about the impact on consumers of rises in personal or indirect taxation, such as the already record level of sales tax which has already risen 110 per cent under the Hawke Government, as a result of the Government's defeat on the privatisation issue? If so, will he work within his own Left faction in an effort to overcome this blockage to plans which would benefit Australian taxpayers and consumers generally?

—The easy and quick answer to Senator Baume would be to say that in this Senate I have responsibility for the Bureau of Consumer Affairs and I do not have responsibility for my Left faction. However, that would be the easy way out. Senator Baume should understand that the whole question of privatisation, as has been expressed in debate in this place a number of times quite recently not only by myself but also by Senator Walsh and Senator Gareth Evans, is not one purely of ideology, which seems to be in the forefront of Senator Baume's mind. People understand that consumers can be protected both by regulation and by a degree of deregulation and co-regulation. All those particular components of the regulation debate and the privatisation debate are obviously at the forefront of the thinking of the Government and my thinking as Minister for Consumer Affairs when we are addressing issues such as the ones that the honourable senator raised.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his reply. However, it leaves me a little concerned. I could not gather from his reply whether we are to assume that this means that he is part of the Left faction sub-faction that is implacably opposed to any privatisation or whether he is part of the Left faction sub-faction that is now prepared to acknowledge the strength of the Evans-Walsh case for some degree of private ownership.
—I do not think there is anything more to answer to Senator Baume's question.

—Has the Minister for Transport and Communications seen the comments of Senator Sheil as reported in this morning's edition of the Gold Coast Bulletin about the recent mid-air collision near Coolangatta Airport? Do the assertions contained in the article have any basis in fact?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen Senator Sheil's reported comments this morning. Indeed, I could hardly have missed them with the lurid banner headline saying, `You'll have blood on your hands', accusing me in the text of trying to sweep under the carpet last Friday's tragic accident in which four people were killed in a light plane crash near the Coolangatta Airport and accusing me further of callous disregard for the families of those killed in that tragic accident. If, as I can only assume, the reported comments of Senator Sheil are accurate, I have to say that they constitute one of the most irresponsible, ghoulish and despicable performances I have ever seen from any politician in this place or in this country. I say that with some regret because, despite all the obvious political and ideological differences that separate us, until now I have always regarded Senator Sheil as thoroughly decent and honourable in personal dealings I have had with him.

ANSWER.PARA: I have spelt out the reality of this matter; I have spelt out the facts to Senator Sheil twice in this chamber in recent days. I explained yesterday, I think it was, that the recent tragedy at Coolangatta had nothing whatever to do with the question of radar facilities at that airport. I explained, and I say again, and it is a matter of fact, that all circuit and landing training at every Australian airport is visually monitored and that will continue for reasons of safety and efficiency to be the practice at Coolangatta, even after full radar coverage down to floor level is commissioned in the early 1990s, as it will be.

Senator Sheil is suddenly an expert on air traffic control and safety procedures and was quoted this morning as saying that the simple fact of the matter is that the two planes would not have collided if Coolangatta had full radar coverage. He has chosen for what he doubtless hopes will be his own cheap political gain to completely ignore the facts and to cruelly cause further unnecessary torment and anguish to the families bereaved by last week's tragedy. He has chosen through inaccurate and near hysterical assertions-such as `blood on your hands' and all the rest of it-to risk creating needless concern to the Gold Coast community and to positively promote the quite erroneous belief that there is something inherently unsafe about the Coolangatta Airport.

We had Senator Sheil waxing piously in the chamber yesterday about the importance of tourism to Coolangatta and the possible damage to that industry by any perception that Coolangatta Airport is unsafe, yet here he is again, if accurately reported in the newspaper this morning, doing everything conceivably possible to foster just such false fears. I will say just one more thing: he took the reckless approach to this issue one step further in this morning's lengthy report by accusing me of attempting to snow over the tragedy, as he put it, because yesterday I said in this place that I was unwilling to speculate on the cause of the collision at Coolangatta Airport.

As I said yesterday and as I repeat now, this accident is currently the subject of investigation by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. It would be simply quite inappropriate for me to comment on the specific circumstances of that accident until the Bureau has completed its investigation and report. Senator Sheil suggests that I should ignore proper practices and speculate as to who, if anyone, was responsible. Whether it was pilot error, an act of God or something to do with the visual observation procedures applied by the air traffic controllers, to ask, to require or to demand that I should be speculating who if anyone might have been at fault on this occasion when this has not been determined is typical of the blatant disregard for propriety that we have come to expect from the National Party in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nice to respond to that tirade from the Minister. In fact, I have a question for him following the near miss yesterday involving a jet aircraft at Coolangatta Airport. I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications: On his visit to the Gold Coast last week-presumably to get his riding instructions from the Australian Council of Trade Unions executive on privatisation-was he not invited to visit the Coolangatta air traffic control and to see for himself first-hand the whole situation of an airport that does not have adequate radar cover? Is it a fact that the Minister refused that invitation and found it more convenient to go to Oscar's on the Beach to enjoy the company and entertainment there? I point out that the invitation was given to the Minister well before the fatal accident that occurred last Friday. That in itself demonstrates an appalling disregard for the safety of more than 930,000 passengers a year who use Coolangatta Airport, not to mention the people adjacent to the flight paths into and out of the airport. Is it a fact that since the tragic deaths of those four people last Friday the Minister is attempting now to make arrangements to visit air traffic control at Coolangatta Airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of which particular garbage bin Senator Sheil rummages through to get his information but it is utterly false and contemptibly false as to at least part of what he said to me. I do not know whether I had any invitation to visit the air traffic control facility at Coolangatta Airport. Such an invitation may have been sent to my office. I do not know; I should be interested to find out. Obviously I am perfectly willing, capable, able and happy to visit that centre.
—What did you do for lunch?

—I shall come to that in a moment. I am happy, willing and able to do so at an appropriate time. As it was, the other day I left at the crack of dawn on a VIP flight to get there. I left at the first available opportunity to get back here for Question Time. I had five minutes up my sleeve. I was due to take off at 11.30 a.m. and I arrived at Coolangatta Airport area around 11.25 a.m. I happened to ask the driver to divert in the five minutes available down to Greenmount Beach to have a look around to see whether that particular restaurant, which I remembered from a past visit, was still there. We had a look, walked out, came back into the car and drove back. The whole visit took 4 1/2 to 5 minutes.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know where Senator Sheil gets his information from but it is typical of the grandstanding nonsense that he has obviously demonstrated a willingness to engage in in this place. I note the absence of any apology for what he is obviously responsible for. I note by his silence, his obvious acquiescence, that he is responsible for every single contemptible and despicable quotation that appears in the Gold Coast Bulletin. He will be judged accordingly, not only by me but also by all Australian people who I hope have been listening to this exchange.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health to claims by the Opposition in this place in a recent debate that hospital waiting lists are very long and are due to Medicare. This claim was also made loudly in the other place very recently by Mr Tuckey. Can the Minister, yet again, correct these appallingly wrong claims and, in particular, draw to the attention of the Senate the statements by the Liberal Minister for Health in New South Wales, Mr Collins, recently refuting these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, as everyone would know, the States are responsible for the administration and running of the public hospital system-not the Federal Government. Therefore, any accusations by Mr Tuckey about Medicare in that sense are ill directed. However, not only is that a statement which I am sure the Senate would understand but also, once again, it is an attempt by Mr Tuckey to confuse his health policy by attacking our healthy achievements and it is inaccurate because, as the honourable senator's question has indicated, the State Health Ministers are not in accord with what Mr Tuckey says.

ANSWER.PARA: When I first heard the allegation about Medicare being the cause of waiting lists in public hospitals I thought that, prima facie, there may be something in this because Medicare has succeeded in achieving a major social reform for Australia by bringing health treatment into the ability of all Australians to pay and not having health treatment and health care limited to those who can afford health insurance or, of their own right, afford to go for treatment in hospitals. So at least in my view it stands to reason that if more Australians under this system of Hawke Government major reform are entitled to health care and health treatment there may be waiting lists because of that. But I am advised that that is not the reason for the waiting lists that are now identified and the State Health Ministers say that that is not the reason. Indeed, no less a person than the Premier of New South Wales, Nick Greiner, has repudiated the allegations made by Mr Tuckey and denied that Medicare is responsible and the Health Minister in New South Wales, Peter Collins, has explicitly refuted the allegation by Mr Tuckey. In an interview on 2GB on 11 March, Mr Collins said:

Medicare has got nothing to do with the debate on (State) health. The primary issue in the health debate in this State is public hospital waiting lists . . . Waiting lists are attributable to poor management of the hospital system, to the fact that orthopaedic surgeons have not been available to operate on public patients in the numbers they are needed.

Again last week Mr Collins attacked the orthopaedic and ophthalmic surgeons as being the major cause generating longer waiting lists in public hospitals in New South Wales. The honourable member for O'Connor should not need to be reminded of any of those things because particularly in elective surgery waiting lists have always been a feature of health care in Australia. About 250,000 patients receive treatment in Australia's public and private hospitals every month. So, quite naturally, hospitals book patients in advance and that is simply efficient management on their part.

However, the concept of a waiting list is misleading. It includes patients who are frequently listed at more than one hospital; patients who, for convenience, choose to go into hospitals at a particular time; patients who have had an operation and are asked to return for a checkup at a later date; and pregnant women who cannot bring forward their hospitalisation. As well, the allocation of priorities within waiting lists is a matter of clinical judgment exercised by individual medical practitioners.

The question that Senator Crowley has asked has invited me to draw that to the attention of Mr Tuckey. I do not think that, on one of his infrequent visits to the House of Representatives when he is obeying the Standing Orders, it would be necessary for me to do that because, as I have said, these factors have been pointed out by the Health Ministers themselves. Mr Tuckey is about as convincing as his attempts to forge a comprehensive or coherent policy on health care for the Opposition, which is not convincing at all.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. It follows his answer to the question asked of him in which he essayed a statement about Medicare being a great reform for those Australians who could not afford private health cover. I ask the Minister: Is he aware of the statement that the Victorian Government is forcing public hospitals to give priority admittance to insured patients ahead of those who cannot afford any other hospital care? I ask the Minister whether he is aware of the report of a memorandum dated 23 February 1988 and circulated in a Melbourne public hospital which reads, in part:

QUESTION.PARA: The financial position of the hospital has deteriorated throughout the month of January and the over-run is now in the order of $385,000. This amount has to be recovered before the end of the financial year . . . It is therefore necessary to adjust the number of public patients admitted for the balance of the financial year to the level budgeted for.
In consequence, all future elective bookings of public patients-
I interpolate that that means the people who do not have private health insurance-
will be on the basis that any number in excess of one public patient per elective list will require approval from the Medical Director . . . The restriction will remain in place until future notice.

Is it a fact that this directive means that one uninsured public patient for admission has to be supported by the admission of two insured patients and that the waiting time in public hospitals for insured elective bookings is no more than two weeks-in other words, those who can afford private insurance have to wait for only two weeks but for public patients it is many months? I ask the Minister: Is this an example of the fair deal being administered to the people of Australia by the shambles that this Government has brought upon the public health system? Does the Minister defend priority admission being given to private insured patients over public patients because they have no private insurance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that in Senator Chaney's sudden interest in health care and, in particular, in his question to me following Senator Crowley's question, he has not in any way sought to defend Mr Tuckey and the allegations Mr Tuckey has made. I am pleased that he has not done so because it proves that the answer that I gave to Senator Crowley is accepted by Senator Chaney. I ask him to pass on that acceptance to Mr Tuckey.
—He is too busy pinning you to the wall on Medicare.
—If I were Senator Baume, I would not be talking about Medicare or health. The reason Senator Baume is sitting where he is is that he fumbled the ball in the last election.

ANSWER.PARA: The first part of Senator Chaney's question was whether I was aware of a certain statement. He then proceeded to quote. I do not recall him sourcing that quotation, although he may have done. I was trying to take down notes at the time. If he did, I ask him to give me the source of the quotation. It is not familiar to me. Therefore, in answer to that part of the question, I cannot say that I am aware of it. However, I stand by what I said about Medicare being one of the most significant social reforms in Australia. It was a reform introduced by the Hawke Labor Government. It has brought within the reach of ordinary Australians access to medical and health treatment they would not otherwise have received. That is a substantial tribute to this Government. The people of Australia know that. The fact that there are problems in the hospital system and the health systems does not detract from the achievement of Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Answer the question.

—I wish Senator Vanstone would stop harping. I cannot hear half the bleating she goes on with, and it is nonsense anyway. Let me go to the part of the question about waiting lists. In the answer I gave to Senator Crowley, I referred to a series of reasons as to why there are waiting lists for public hospitals. The reasons are obvious. They stand by themselves and do not need to be reiterated by me

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not know whether the Minister is capable of answering a simple question, but let me try. Does the Minister deny that public hospitals in Victoria are giving priority admittance to insured patients ahead of those who cannot afford other hospital care? Does he deny that that is occurring?

—I do not know why Senator Chaney is waiting to sit down. I was wondering when he was going to finish the question. I thought that maybe he would want to ask a question that was supplementary to his supplementary question. I do not know the answer to the question, directly, but I do know that the administration of the State hospital system in Victoria is not a matter for this Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance whether he is aware of this reported claim by the shadow Minister for Finance, Senator Stone:

QUESTION.PARA: Road funding has decreased under Labor by more than 40 per cent in real terms over the last four years.
Is Senator Stone's claim accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is yes and no to each of the questions. I have seen a report in the Sunshine Daily, which I believe is a Sunshine Coast publication. I am not sure whether it is a throwaway. It is headed `Ahern backs road bid, but toll to stay for 20 years'. It quotes Senator Stone as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Road funding has decreased under Labor-
as Senator Black said that Senator Stone had said-
by more than 40 per cent in real terms over the last four years.

I have here a table and a bar graph-which I will table later-which show in constant 1987-88 dollars the level of Commonwealth government funding for road grants to the States from 1980-81 to 1987-88. If we go back four years from 1987-88, we find that the figure, which was a peak figure in 1983-84 because that was the peak bicentennial road program construction year, was $1,593m in 1987-88 dollars. It is true that in 1987-88 it is down to $1,244m, which is a reduction of just over 20 per cent, not the 40 per cent that Senator Stone claimed. If we go back to the last full year of the Fraser Government, we find that road grants to the States by the Commonwealth totalled $1,084m-again, in the same value in dollars-compared to $1,244m this year. There has been a 14 per cent increase in road grants to the States compared to the last year of the Fraser Government. So it is pretty clear that Senator Stone will not be much help to the Opposition when it tries to get its alternative Budget together again. Indeed, he is not much help to himself. Those who bother to look back at his alternative Budget of June last year will see that item 7, under the heading `Economic Services: Transport and Communication', reads:
Among cuts in this area to be put forward in 1987-88 would be the following:
Cut road grants to the States (and Northern Territory), estimated at $1,200 million in 1987-88, to save $120 million.

So less than a year ago Senator Stone said that the proper amount of money to provide to the States for roads was $1,080m as against the $1,244m which this Government provided. In other words, Senator Stone was advocating a level of road funding 14 per cent lower, in round figures, than the level of funding which he now tells his constituents on the Sunshine Coast is much lower than it ought to be. I table the bar graph and the table.

From all this, one can draw three possible conclusions, none of them flattering to Senator Stone. The first is that he is innumerate; the second is that he has taken to telling fibs just like all his redneck colleagues; and the third is that he is confused about what we have done, what he intended to do, and what he would do if he got a chance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Quite clearly the Minister's penultimate sentence was unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw the reference.
—Certainly, Mr President. I have also finished the answer.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce been receiving indications of concern and disquiet over the effect of the harmonising of tariffs, particularly as these measures relate to a large number of leading fashion houses throughout Australia which have been forced to bear the brunt of tariff increases, from 2 to 40 per cent, on lightweight woollen cloths used in the manufacture of fashion garments? Is the Minister aware that the fashion industry provides direct employment opportunities for significant numbers of Australians and for many others in the distribution and retail areas? Further, given the fact that the Government is currently spending in excess of $34m on wool promotion and that it has taken the last five years to educate the retailers into accepting lightweight woollen cloths using the cool new wool theme, does the Minister agree that the 1 January tariff increase of 38 per cent in the short term at least is having a demoralising effect on our local manufacturers, to the point where they are now being forced to turn to the use of synthetics and thereby acting in direct contradiction to the main aims of wool promotion?

—I have not received a large number of representations on this issue, as I understand it. I have received representations from some significant organisations, such as the Australian Wool Corporation, and I have responded to those representations. I just say that in the policy by-law reform the coverage of the by-laws for wool, cotton and synthetic fabrics was reduced from 51 to around 13. The total effect of this change, as has been noted by the Wool Corporation, was marginal. As I understand it, it had the effect of indicating to the Wool Corporation and others that the Government was concerned about adding value to Australian wool in Australia. I will certainly consult to see whether any further representations have been made to me; I do not believe they have been. As soon as I can I will provide the honourable senator with a more detailed answer on that issue. I am quite aware of the importance of the Australian fashion industry and that it plays a significant part in respect of the use of small quantities of wool. It is important that it does this effectively.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. By way of preamble I point out that the genesis of this question lies in the very considerable concern which is being expressed over the Antarctic Treaty nations negotiations in relation to minerals prospecting and exploitation and, particularly, that liability in the case of environmental damage must extend to prospecting in the Antarctic. I ask the Minister: Are the Antarctic Treaty nations, including Australia, currently considering an Antarctic minerals convention at a meeting in Wellington, New Zealand? Are the considerations centred upon a draft document prepared for this meeting? Is it a fact that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has prevented release of this document to the Australian public, whilst the United States Government has made the document freely available? Finally, does the Government believe that the Australian public should be prevented from knowing what is being negotiated? If the answer is no, will it make the document available? If the answer is yes, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question, yes, it is the case that the Antarctic Treaty consultative parties are meeting from 2 May to 2 June in Wellington in order to complete negotiations on a convention to govern possible mineral resources activity in Antarctica. There is currently an agreed moratorium amongst consultative parties on minerals activity in Antarctica. The adoption of such a convention does not mean that exploitation is imminent. I should perhaps say further in that respect that little is known of the commercial minerals potential of Antarctica and little, if any, activity apart from prospecting is likely to occur until well into the next century at the earliest. The convention is being concluded now to ensure that a system of regulation is available in case exploitation should ever become economically feasible and environmentally safe. Preparing in advance for problems has been a feature of the well-established Antarctic Treaty system. I am sure that Senator Coulter would wish that that approach continue.

ANSWER.PARA: As to his second question-are the considerations centred upon a draft document prepared for this meeting?-yes, the draft to form the basis for a convention is an evolving document resulting from negotiations over six years and 12 separate sessions. Concerning the final parts of his question, in accordance with normal international practice, this type of document is regarded as confidential among the parties involved in the negotiations. While it may be informally discussed by governments with non-governmental groups this is done, by convention, on a confidential basis. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has adhered to this practice in making the document available to a number of non-governmental groups. The same practice would apply should Senator Coulter wish to see a copy. I do not know whether the American Government has taken the same line on this matter, but I can find out if the honourable senator wishes me to do so.

As to the substance of the negotiations, Australia has been at the forefront in pressing for strong environmental protection measures in the convention-as no doubt Senator Richardson is acutely aware; and he has been in the forefront of that endeavour-and Australia's position is to ensure stringent environmental safeguards to protect its national interests should mining ever proceed. The Government's representatives at the negotiations have clear instructions to pursue these objectives. Their performance has been applauded by concerned environmental organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is it Australia's position that liability in the event of environmental damage will extend to prospecting as well as the exploitation of minerals in the Antarctic?
—I will take that part of the question on notice.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I refer to bilateral agreements for space rockets to be launched from Woomera in South Australia by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) of the United States of America and by the West German Space Research Organisation. How many sounding rockets have been launched so far from Woomera to investigate and explore the supernova phenomenon? How many more rockets are to go up in this welcome reactivation of the Woomera space facility? Are there any prospects of further agreements being signed for the use of Woomera by foreign countries? What has been the impact on the local economy of the current agreements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The launching of sounding rockets from Woomera has attracted some attention in recent months. The Government has concluded a 10-year agreement with the United States and a five-year agreement with the Federal Republic of Germany to permit the launch of sounding rockets from Woomera for scientific purposes. To date, NASA has launched six sounding rockets and the German Space Research Organisation has launched one. All of these missions have been to investigate supernova 1987. NASA has advised the Government that it intends to launch a further series of three rockets during February 1989. The German agency has no further launches scheduled.

ANSWER.PARA: Funding for the launch activities of NASA and the German agency is provided through a trust fund managed by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Total expenditure on these activities to date has been $1.4m, primarily in reimbursement of the direct costs and overhead charges incurred by the Department of Defence in operating the Woomera range. There are currently no other proposals to launch sounding rockets from Australia to investigate the supernova. However, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has received preliminary approaches from a number of overseas companies wishing to explore the potential for the launch of sounding rockets for other scientific purposes such as microgravity experiments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister representing the Minister for Defence of the recommendations of defence ministerial consultant Robert Cooksey 18 months ago that our currently very small defence export industry could be increased substantially-in the view of some officials up to $1 billion a year-and particularly that significant increases could be achieved simply `by certain modest changes to policy and administration without financial cost to government or impost on the economy'. Is it not the case that some of such recommendations concerning a reversal of the onus of proof placed on prospective exporters have been bogged down in Cabinet since February? Why have these matters not been dealt with? Is it the case that internal party differences have meant that these matters have been deferred to less sensitive times after the Australian Labor Party's Federal Conference, at a consequent cost to the nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is strong industry and union support for revising defence export controls to better balance Australia's defence, foreign policy and commercial interests. The customs regulations will be revised to restrict controls on those goods that are, firstly, specifically designed or adapted for military purposes and inherently lethal, incapacitating or destructive; and, secondly, of major military significance.

ANSWER.PARA: Deciding whether or not to permit export of a particular military product to a particular customer will always be a sensitive matter. We will not export defence goods to certain states against which there are arms embargoes imposed by the United Nations Security Council or by any other international instruments to which Australia is a party. Also, we will not be exporting to those countries which threaten the strategic interests of Australia or its friends or allies. The Australian Government expressly reserves the right to prohibit the export of military goods to governments that seriously violate the human rights or constitutional rights of their citizens and also, in particular cases, where specified Australian foreign policy interests could outweigh the export benefits. Australia insists on firm assurances by any overseas suppliers that they will continue supporting equipment we buy from them.

I could add even more information than I have, but the final point is that I do not believe there is a final Government decision on this matter. The honourable senator speculates as to the motives of that. I do not believe that those motives are true, but I do not have any compelling evidence at this stage to put them to rest in the honourable senator's mind. There have been many decisions and many emphases to make in the defence area. This one, though, still remains reasonably high up on the list of priorities. If I can add anything to the particular answer I have given the honourable senator, I will do so at a future time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the Senate of details of the preliminary 1987-88 financial results reported today by Qantas Airways Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can. I have a great deal of pleasure in doing so. Qantas continued its strong growth in 1987-88, with total revenue earned by the group reaching a record $3,085m, which is an increase of 20 per cent over the previous year. Of this amount, 65 per cent or nearly $2 billion was earned in foreign currencies. Qantas this year also returned its highest ever operating profit of $153.3m, which is an increase of 47 per cent over the previous year's record profit of $104.3m. This increase resulted mainly from an increase in seat utilisation from 67 per cent in 1986-87 to 70 per cent, and by restricting expenditure growth to 19 per cent over the previous year. The growth of inbound tourism has also contributed to the latest result.

ANSWER.PARA: After including provision for income tax of $87.5m, and the proceeds from the sale of aircraft of $65.5m, Qantas returned a net profit of $131.1m for 1987-88 compared with just $63.8m in the previous year. There is just one further statistic: since 1984, Qantas's turnover has more than doubled, from $1,435m to this year's record of $3,085m that I have already mentioned. Over this period the company has returned $423m in profit on airline operations. That is over 80 per cent of total operating profits earned since the Government acquired all the shares of Qantas back in 1947. I believe that Qantas staff and management deserve very strong congratulations on these outstanding results.

I should say finally, however, that while Qantas's latest results are a record profit, the result is in no way sufficient to fund the company's capital expansion internally. The issue of Qantas's capital basis is therefore an issue that still remains to be addressed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HELSHAM COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE LEMONTHYME AND SOUTHERN FORESTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories received representations from either the Tasmanian Government or the Tasmanian Opposition about the findings of the report of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests on World Heritage listing? If so, what is the attitude of the Government and the Opposition in my State to the findings of the inquiry? Finally, I ask the Minister whether he fully agrees with his colleague the Minister for Resources, who was reported to have said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Tasmania on Friday that the Government was `obliged to accept the Helsham inquiry report'?
—That is not an accurate quote. If you are going to quote me, get it right, will you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have the pleasure, I think along with Senator Cook, very shortly of seeing Mr Groom from Tasmania to find out his Government's attitude-within minutes, as they say. I suspect that I know what his attitude is, and what he will convey to me. I am meeting with some representatives of the Tasmanian Opposition in the next couple of days-I am not exactly sure when but it will be pretty soon-to discuss this matter with them and Senator Cook.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator alleged that Senator Cook used those words. Senator Cook has already denied having uttered them. In any event, as I have said before, I will not be commenting on the Helsham report until I have made some representations to the Government and the Government has made its decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Sheil requested from me a copy of the transcript of the conversation between the air traffic controller and the pilots of the two jetliners concerned in an incident at Coolangatta Airport with the pilot of another commercial aircraft on the ground at the same time. I have a full answer for him on this matter, and I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

I provide a record of relevant communications between the Coolangatta Tower Controller and the pilots of the two Australian Airlines aircraft involved in the reported incident. I have not provided a full transcript of the communications, as release of such transcripts is contrary to the provisions of Annex 13 to the Chicago Convention on Civil Aviation. Paragraph 5.12 of the Annex recommends that transcripts of communications between persons responsible for the safe operation of aircraft should not be made available other than to those persons charged with the responsibility for investigating for safety enhancement purposes. I am assured by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, however, that the following record is an accurate summary of the exchanges, and no relevant material has been excluded.

The aircraft involved were a Douglas DC9, registered VH-TJS; and a Boeing 737, registered VH-TAZ. The Tower Controller was processing VH-TJS to land on runway 14, and intended that this aircraft would have landed and taxied off the runway prior to the landing of VH-TAZ on runway 32-that is, one aircraft was landing into the south-east, and the other into the north-west.

At 2107 hours VH-TJS was cleared for a visual approach to a left base position in the circuit, and advised that it would be the third aircraft to land in a particular sequence. At this time VH-TAZ was 16 miles (about 30 kilometres) from the aerodrome. The pilot of VH-TAZ was informed that he would be tracking for a right base position for runway 32, and advised that the wind was less than 4 knots across the runway. The aircraft was progressively descended to ensure adequate vertical separation existed with VH-TJS.

A few seconds before 2111 hours the Controller instructed VH-TJS to turn onto the base leg, and instructed VH-TAZ to make a visual approach to the right base position (for runway 32). At 2112 VH-TJS was cleared to land, and one minute later VH-TAZ was instructed to make the base leg turn. The pilot of VH-TJS requested confirmation of the fact that his aircraft had a landing clearance, and this was given by the Controller. In response to a query from the Controller, the pilot of VH-TAZ advised at 2114 and 22 seconds that the aircraft was 5 miles (about 10 kilometres) from the aerodrome.

Some 18 seconds later, the pilot of VH-TJS asked what the light in front of the aircraft was, and was told there was nothing on the runway. The pilot replied that the light was ``heading straight at us'', and almost immediately the pilot of VH-TAZ reported that his aircraft was on final approach. Shortly afterwards the pilot of VH-TJS advised that he was going around, and the Controller indicated that VH-TAZ was 5 miles from the runway on final approach, and was ``well clear of you''. The pilot of VH-TAZ advised 9 seconds later that his aircraft was now 3 miles (about 6 kilometres) from the aerodrome, and was cleared to land. VH-TJS carried out a circuit and subsequently landed on runway 14.

Senator Sheil also referred to another commercial aircraft on the ground at the time of the incident. This aircraft was taxiing prior to take-off, and there were no transmissions to or from this aircraft which were relevant to the particular incident.

The information I have provided on this matter is purely a summary of radio communications. An investigation into the occurrence is presently being conducted by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which will look at all aspects of the incident.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 24 May, from Senator Coulter:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move:
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The necessity for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to:
(a) allow the legislation which may bring [an] Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission into existence to lie before Parliament for at least six months;
(b) more actively involve Aboriginal people and groups in consultation and in possible amendment of this legislation; and

(c) reinstate the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) as it was constituted before the recent dismissal of commissioners, and continue and fund all current Federal Aboriginal bodies until ATSIC comes into operation, or until other proposals which have widespread Aboriginal support are implemented.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: ``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The necessity for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to:
(a) allow the legislation which may bring [an] Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) into existence to lie before Parliament for at least six months;
(b) more actively involve Aboriginal people and groups in consultation and in possible amendment of this legislation; and

(c) reinstate the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) as it was constituted before the recent dismissal of commissioners, and continue and fund all current Federal Aboriginal bodies until ATSIC comes into operation, or until other proposals which have widespread Aboriginal support are implemented.''.

This is certainly an urgency motion because many of the facts which surround this development have become evident only in the last few days. Indeed, only last week we saw the sacking of the eight commissioners from the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and their replacement by eight other appointees of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand. The term of the sacked commissioners of the ADC was due to expire on 30 June 1988; in other words, they had a term to run of only a further five to six weeks. It is well known that the ADC had been putting a view to Aboriginal people and groups which was different from that which the Minister had been putting in relation to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). Indeed, the ADC had been attempting to get to Mr Hand and to put these views to him but, as I understand it, quite unsuccessfully.

This action by the Minister has undoubtedly galvanised Aboriginal people and groups into action. If they had any doubt before about the speed with which this proposal was developing, and if they had any concerns over whether Aboriginal people were to get more autonomy and independence under the ATSIC proposals, this has certainly made many of them very nervous about what lies in store for them. Clearly it has severely divided the Aboriginal community. Undoubtedly there are many in favour of the ATSIC proposals, but equally there are many who are unhappy about them, who believe that some of the present structures should be kept in place. But, particularly, there is now a large group in the middle which is really confused and needs more time to make up its mind as to which side it is really on and what sorts of proposals it would support.

Continuing chronologically, yesterday, which was the first day on which the new commissioners could meet, those commissioners met, and they changed the policy of the Aboriginal Development Commission with respect to the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to conform with the Minister's position, and a number of motions were put through. The new ADC has forced the chairwoman, Mrs Shirley McPherson, to ring the Minister and tell him that the Aboriginal Development Commission as now constituted supports the ATSIC proposal. Senators should not be surprised at that because the Minister has put in place on that Commission those people whom he knew would support his proposals. In other words, the Minister is getting extremely incestuous advice-advice which he knew he would get. There is little value in such advice going back to him.

That type of procedure reminds one of some of the worst experiences of concentration camps during the Second World War, where Jews were lined up around large pits and shot and the Jews standing on the banks of those pits were asked to urinate on the bodies in the pits before they were shot and turned in. That sort of behaviour is not the sort of behaviour expected from a Minister who says that he is working towards greater autonomy, independence and dignity for Aboriginal people.

The second decision that the new ADC made was that it would withdraw the current legal action against the Minister. That was over the Minister's right to carry out the sacking action and also the Minister's legal ability to give direction to the ADC. Again, one should not be at all surprised, if one puts onto a commission those who are in favour of what the Minister has proposed, that they take that sort of advice. Again, there is no objective value in the advice in this decision having been taken.

I would like to make the point that I am in no way reflecting on the new commissioners. I am quite prepared to believe that all of them believe that they are doing the right thing. I am quite prepared to believe that all of them believe that ATSIC is the right way to go. Today, Mr Pat Dodson from the Central Land Council rang me and I have had a telegram from that body. Mr Frank Chulung from the Kimberley Land Council has also rung me and told me that he is personally in favour of ATSIC and would like to see it come into operation quite quickly. I know that Mrs Lois O'Donoghue, who was partly responsible for the move towards ATSIC, is also one of the new commissioners and is in favour of it. One is not in any way reflecting on the honesty of those people, but one is very much reflecting on the sincerity and behaviour of the Minister, who replaces a body that is expressing an alternative viewpoint with a body that meekly supports his position. In other words, the Minister has attempted to silence an alternative viewpoint which was a legitimate viewpoint of a sizable proportion of the Aboriginal people.

The third decision which came out of yesterdays meeting related to the outgoing commissioners receiving no financial assistance if they continued to support the former ADC line. It is quite despicable that those people who have taken a line which they legitimately and rightly believe is the correct line should find themselves deprived of funds to move around the country and support that particular position. Presumably, an extension of that is that any person or group in receipt of Government funds that opposes the Minister's plan for ATSIC will similarly have their financial support withdrawn.

I note in passing that the top headline of this morning's Canberra Times reads, `The Perils of Speaking Out: Hawke Warns West'. In this case the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) was simply speaking on privatisation in line with Australian Labor Party policy. Cabinet has not yet decided to overturn party policy; nonetheless, the Prime Minister is piqued by one of his Ministers. That indicates a repressive, authoritarian line being pursued in this Government and particularly by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

This is a matter of urgency. These events have occurred over the past week and some of the really important events have occurred as recently as yesterday. They vitally concern the ongoing welfare and the independence of indigenous people in Australia. As I have indicated in previous speeches in the Senate, those people have been in Australia for an incredibly long time, not 200 years but 200 times 200 years. In the short time Europeans have occupied this country, we have substantially deprived them of their dignity. Their dignity needs to be handed back to them and that is not achieved by treating them as the Minister has treated genuinely concerned Aborigines on the Aboriginal Development Commission until last week. Not surprisingly Aboriginal groups around Australia are now very concerned and divided.

The history of the development of the concept of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission goes back to the Whitlam years when Dr Coombs, a man who has had a long interest in Aboriginal welfare, first proposed a body of this type. The concept was more recently updated by Mrs Lois O'Donoghue, the Chairman of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and now a commissioner for the Aboriginal Development Commission. A giant difference exists between the concept which has been around for quite a long time and the detailed implementation of that concept. The detail will be as important as, if not more important than, the concept itself in determining whether the ATSIC concept and everything that goes with it will work.

The first statement of the Minister on this was made during the dying stages of the pre-Christmas sitting. I remind honourable senators that the document Foundations for the Future was introduced on the second last or last day of that sitting and little time was provided to debate it properly. It was not legislation; it was a concept document that made certain propositions. Honourable senators might recall that at that time I expressed cautious optimism that, in practice, that proposal would be made to work. Early this year the Minister engaged in a five-week period of frenetic consultations, as he called them. As he said-I do not doubt his word-those consultations were the most far-reaching, comprehensive and detailed that have ever involved a Minister with Aboriginal groups.

Telling people what efforts one has made to fulfil a particular function is no indication that that function has been adequately discharged. That the five-week period of consultations could be claimed as such an important new development reflects more on the lack of quality of previous ministerial consultations. Most people would be aware that Aboriginal groups would prefer to reach consensus by a slow process of discussion rather than by voting. One hears from Aboriginal group after Aboriginal group that during those five weeks the Minister would come in very quickly, tell the Aboriginal people who were present what would happen, and then quickly leave. There was little time for consultation, certainly no time for consensus and very often I hear approximately half the Aborigines present were so confused as to what was happening that they did not vote. So that the majority, taken on a vote, was no indication of the wish of the majority of people actually present at those meetings.

The statement which the Minister made in late April indicates that the elections for ATSIC will be held over the months of October, November and December. It is clear that, with the Parliament resuming on 22 August, there will be as little as five weeks available for Aboriginal groups and others to see the final legislation, give consideration to it and make representations to the Government and to the Minister as to whether that adequately meets their needs. Again, given the way in which Aborigines consider these matters and given the way in which they would prefer to come to a consensus about matters like this, that is far too little time in which that process can occur.

We should note also that between the December announcement and the announcement at the end of April considerable modification had already been made to the proposals. We see that the number of areas has been doubled-it was not a moderate increase; it was a substantial increase-one whole section of the zonal councils has been deleted; the size of ATSIC has been increased and there has been a change in the distribution between appointed and elected representatives. They are all ideas which very significantly change the structure which was originally put to Aboriginal people and on which, presumably, their considerations were then based. Furthermore, these ideas need to be got back to Aboriginal people and groups so that they can properly consider them.

The history of the ADC is that it came in under a coalition government in 1980. Senator Bonner who, of course, was the only Aboriginal senator ever in the Senate, in speaking to that ADC legislation, very strongly praised the concept of the ADC. Like many other bodies drawn from disadvantaged groups it was not surprising that, in its early years, the ADC, along with a number of other Aboriginal groups, did not function as well as groups that would be drawn from the more literate, well-educated groups in society. Undoubtedly, there was a tendency in some areas towards nepotism and there was perhaps some inefficiency and non-professionalism in relation to the handling of funds. But it is quite clear that, over the intervening years, not only the ADC but also Aboriginal Hostels Ltd have very substantially lifted their game. I believe that the Minister has anticipated the sorts of legislation which we might see come forward by taking the action he has against the ADC. I commend the motion which is before the Senate to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be rejecting this urgency motion brought forward by Senator Coulter on behalf of the Australian Democrats to do with the Government's proposal to bring about a situation on 1 January 1989 whereby the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities around Australia will exercise executive and real authority in relation to their affairs. It is a remarkable proposal which, for the first time, will enable Aboriginal and Islander communities to exercise real authority and power by way of self-determination of matters of concern to them. They will do so as an elected body.

SPEECH.PARA: The way Senator Coulter would take this Parliament and this Government, if his motion were adopted and acted upon by the Government would result in a great tragedy. The organisation whose life Senator Coulter would wish to see continue beyond 1 January 1989 is a non-elected body. The members of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) are appointed by the Minister-they are there by sheer patronage-whereas 12 out of the 15 members of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) will be elected by the communities themselves. That is a tremendous expression of their right to self-determination in relation to their affairs. It would be extremely unfortunate if that day were put off, as Senator Coulter seems to suggest should be the case.

The Aboriginal people are already telling Senator Coulter that they do not want that to happen.
