I received a telex today, for example, from Mr Wenten Rubuntja, the Chairman of the Central Land Council, which makes it very clear that on behalf of all executive and Council members of the Central Land Council he is making a plea to Senator Coulter-I am sure that he would have received the telex-not to be part of any tactic to delay the implementation of the legislation for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It goes on to say:
Our Council-made up of elected representatives-
elected representatives, not through patronage, not appointed members, as with the ADC-
of all major communities and cultural groups of the central region has spent a lot of time talking and thinking about the new Commission.
There have also been many meetings of people with the Minister.
Those elected representatives support the Commission in principle. To save time, I table the telex. A telex from the Chairman of the Northern Land Council, Galarrwuy Yunupingu, says:

The 45th meeting of the Full Council of the NLC today resolved, in principle, to support the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the establishment of ATSIC by the 1st of January, 1989. And further resolved to strongly oppose any delays in the establishment of ATSIC by other political parties.
The resolution was unanimous.

So the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council have made their point of view very clear. They wish to see the new Commission of elected representatives of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people put into place by 1 January 1989. The interesting thing is that Senator Coulter himself thinks it is a very good idea. In a letter addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Hon. Gerry Hand, dated 31 March 1988, Senator Coulter said:

I am writing to express the concern of Democrat Senators at the extremely short timeframe allowed for consultation and for the necessary legislative processes to take place to enable the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (or the separate Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissions as we have proposed) to commence operations on 1 July 1988.
We cannot see how this Bill can be dealt with in order for this deadline to be accommodated and suggest a more suitable commencement date would be 1 January 1989.
This is a letter from Senator Coulter on behalf of all Democrat senators to the responsible Minister, written only a few weeks ago. It continues:

If this longer period of consultation and debate is accepted then it will be necessary to extend the existence of those bodies and the employment of those people who work within the present structures. The uncertainty of employment for these people should be promptly removed.
Thus we suggest that you make a decision as quickly as possible about extending the date for the commencement of the operations of ATSIC to 1 January 1989.
The Minister responded on 29 April, saying:
I refer to your letter dated 31 March in which you indicated certain concerns regarding the timetable relating to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

I have noted your comments and as you know the suggested date in your letter is just the date the government has chosen to start up this new Commission. I indicated the reasons for this in my speech on April 27.

So there is complete harmony between the Minister and the Democrats in relation to the start-up date of 1 January 1989, which is completely at odds with the proposition that has now been put to the chamber. The Minister, in his letter to Senator Coulter, continued:
Might I suggest that if you have any further queries please don't hesitate to contact either myself or Geoff Pryor in my office. I would be pleased to discuss this with you.

There has been a deafening silence from the Democrats. They have made no approach either to the Minister, Mr Gerry Hand, or to Geoff Pryor, his Senior Private Secretary, to discuss their concerns about this matter since that letter was received by them at the end of April 1988, some three weeks ago.

The motion that Senator Coulter has moved is a very artificial device and is absolutely at odds with the Democrats' preferred position that 1 January 1989 be the commencing date for the Commission. Indeed, it is the preferred position, as I say, of the Northern Land Council and of the Central Land Council.

The other parts of the urgency motion brought forward by Senator Coulter are equally flimsy. I refer, for example, to the implied suggestion that sufficient consultation has not been taking place. I doubt whether I have ever seen such a program of consultation as has been undertaken by this Minister in relation to this matter. Certainly, I have never undertaken any such extensive consultation with bodies within my portfolio. I doubt whether any other Ministers have consulted so widely. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has conducted 46 meetings, involving an estimated 6,000 representatives of some 1,200 organisations and groups around Australia between 23 January and 10 March. In those consultations he found support in principle in all but a few areas for the ATSIC proposal.

The consultations led to considerable change. In particular, I recall, as we all do, the fact that the Torres Strait Islanders felt that they were not given sufficient distinct recognition in the arrangements put forward by the Minister in those early rounds. Indeed, their wishes in relation to their concerns have now been accommodated. The consultations with representatives of all communities and organisations were real consultations. This was no public relations exercise. The Aboriginal and Islander communities were listened to, and changes were therefore made in relation to the Government's proposals.

The major proposal-what has been so attractive and what gives an air of urgency to the implementation of these proposals-is that the majority of commissioners, 12 out of 15, will be selected by Aboriginal communities and organisations, as opposed to the present situation where the ADC is appointed by the Minister and subject to that process of gaining a guernsey in this important area. That is why it is so crucial that the matter be proceeded with as expeditiously as possible. Of course, there will be time for debate within this chamber in the Budget session, which will allow--

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be lots of time.
—There will be time for debate, of course.
—Six months, I would think.

—Not necessarily. Senator Chaney may see some reason between now and the Budget session in relation to the passage of the legislation. In fact, over the winter recess, as both he-because of his well-regarded interest in Aboriginal affairs-and Senator Coulter move around Aboriginal communities, they may find that those communities plead with them to pass this legislation in a way which allows the Commission to come into operation on 1 January 1989. I am sure that Senator Chaney has not closed his mind to the possibility that his consultations with these communities may lead to that conclusion.
—I hope the Minister doesn't put pressure on these communities. He controls their grants, you know.

—I suggest that it would be improper for the Minister to apply undue or untoward pressure. It would be very patronising to suggest that the Aboriginal and Islander communities would succumb to any such pressure. As far as I am concerned, there has been no suggestion-it would be improper; I notice that it does not directly fall from Senator Chaney's lips-that either the Northern Land Council or the Central Land Council is making its representations to this chamber today otherwise than in accordance with the unanimous view of those who have gathered to consider these matters as representatives of the members of those councils.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a few minutes left to deal with the aspect of the urgency motion dealing with the Aboriginal Development Corporation. It is well known that the Federal Court of Australia, whilst lifting certain interlocutory injunctions, is yet finally to determine certain matters; nevertheless by lifting those injunctions it has allowed, by its action, a situation to develop so that the new Aboriginal Development Commission commissioners could meet. In fact, they did meet yesterday, with Mrs Shirley McPherson as the Chairperson of that Commission meeting and Mr Pat Dodson as the Deputy Chairman. The other members are Mr Charles Perkins, Miss Lois O'Donoghue, Mr Terence O'Shane, Mr Getano Lui, Mr Peter Yu, Miss Esther Carroll, Mrs Zona Martin-I think she was a member of the previous Commission-and Mr Robert Lee. We know that the commissioners agreed to cooperate on the establishment of ATSIC.

The Aboriginal Development Commission, with its new membership, has met and is operating in accordance with the permission-that is probably the way to put it-of the Federal Court. It is acting in such a way that it is already fully exercising those powers which are vested in it, both to deal with the ordinary business that comes before it from time to time in the normal course of allocating moneys and funds and passing ordinary resolutions, and in relation to expressing, through its meeting, support for the establishment of ATSIC.

The urgency motion brought forward by the Democrats runs counter to their own expectations and wishes in relation to the bringing into being of the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I believe that there is urgency involved, but the urgency is for this chamber to deal, not in a partial or rushed way, but in a considered way, during the Budget session, with the legislation that will be brought into the chamber. I believe that this chamber is well equipped and well able to give that legislation a fair, not unduly rushed, consideration during the Budget session in such a timely way that the Aboriginal and Islander people, by an Act of this Parliament, can exercise real executive authority and control over those matters of concern to them. That will be a great achievement by this Parliament on behalf of the Aboriginal and Islander people of Australia. I hope that the passage of this motion, which seems inevitable this afternoon, does not prevent members of this and the other side of the chamber from listening to Aboriginal and Islander communities over the winter recess in a way which may lead to the speedy passage of the legislation on behalf of the Aboriginal and Islander people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the urgency motion relating to Aboriginal matters, I think it is very important to point out that Prime Minister Hawke, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, and the Minister representing that Minister in this place-the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate-have in effect become peddlers of false hope. I think they are setting out in many instances to delude Aboriginals with a very artificial series of dates that are totally unachievable. They have been doing so for many months.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to remind ourselves of the series of events that have taken place in this very important bicentennial year; the very important commitments that the Prime Minister initially gave to a compact-a treaty-to the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, and to the formation of the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Almost at the same time Minister Hand chose to boycott all bicentennial events for the year. He showed a very arrogant, hypocritical attitude at that time. Since then I admit that he has become involved in a very comprehensive consultation process on the first round, by putting out his document entitled Foundations for the Future last December.

The motion that has been put forward today by Senator Coulter puts the Government on firm notice that it now has absolutely no prospect of forcing inadequate proposals for the creation of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission on the Aboriginal people or on the Australian community, in particular without referral to this Parliament. We do not want to see the Minister's cunning and guile just forcing an issue. The Prime Minister may have had a dream of a compact or treaty but because of the very devious actions that have gone on by a few ideologues the proposal is now harming the very people it was meant to help, the Aboriginal community.

The Minister has had absolutely lousy timing throughout the year. The consultation process has been ineffective and it has, in effect, destroyed confidence throughout Australia. Let us look at the Minister's statement of last December, Foundations for the Future. I give a few quotes:
We must ensure that Aboriginal and Islander people are properly involved at all levels of the decision making process in order that the right decisions are taken about their lives.
He said further:
The proposals which I will now describe will be circulated widely amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people for discussion and consideration.
He also said:
The Government must be satisfied that the proposals have been endorsed by the people it will directly affect.
He said further:

The Government makes no claim to special wisdom in this matter. Nor would it be appropriate to seek to impose a particular set of propositions on Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people, for an imposed solution is unlikely to gain sufficient acceptance.
I stress that last point. He continued:
It is much too important a task to be rushed. No artificial deadlines will be set. No hasty drafting will be done. This time we must get it right.

The Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, brought down in this place on 27 April a series of options and changes. He pointed out that there were very significant changes in the whole structure of the proposed organisation in areas such as land acquisition and voting arrangements-how they would be carried out and with regard to a whole series of things for elections to be held in October, November and December. Those issues have to go back to the very people who need to be consulted.

The Minister's actions in the last weeks with regard to the Aboriginal Development Commission must create a precedent. Aboriginal people throughout Australia would be wondering about the spectre of authoritarianism which will now affect all future Aboriginal dealings and organisations. The Aboriginal Development Commission, as it was invited to do by the Minister last December, put forward alternative proposals, which were thrown out with scant regard. When the Minister made his statement on 27 April he did not even refer to the Aboriginal Development Commission's proposals and alternative propositions which it had canvassed from Aboriginal people throughout Australia. We have now seen a number of people sacked, whether commissioners of the ADC or consultants. A quote in today's Press by one of the sacked consultants, Mr John Newfong, puts it very well:
Things have not changed since Aboriginal people were put in chains and other blacks were given a saddle or a portion of bully beef to bring them in . . . You don't survive unless you conform.

What a damning quote on the attitudes of the Minister and the way in which he has chosen to ride right across this proposal. The Minister has certainly jackbooted his way through the ADC because it chose to show a different view. Minister Tate came into the House a few minutes ago and read from telegrams from the Central Land Council and the Northern Land Council. I could get just as many quotes from other organisations around the community. It is important to remind ourselves that Pat Dodson, the Director of the Central Land Council, whom the Minister just quoted, has just been appointed one of the new commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission. Warren Snowdon, a member of the House of Representatives, left the staff of the Central Land Council only just before coming to this place. A member of his staff has just been appointed to the Northern Land Council. So it is not surprising that the Minister can walk in here with trumped up new support for the proposal. I am concerned about the Aboriginals out there in the general community and the fact that the Minister, last December, said, `Our kick start date will be 1 July 1988'. On 27 April he changed it to 1 January 1989. We know that the legislation cannot be presented to this Parliament until late August at the earliest. Therefore, it will not be properly processed until September or October-and, by the Government's legislative program, it will probably be November or December. The Aboriginal people are desperately crying out to see the legislation in its final form-not the changes, the options, the preambles and the early statements. They then want to talk about the legislation, as do many other people in the community.

Mrs McPherson, the Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission, whom the Minister was not able to sack because of a technicality, gave evidence to a Senate Estimates committee hearing on 14 April. She said:
The majority of the responses that we-
the ADC-

have received have indicated that people would like more time to be made fully aware of the Government's option and for more time to put up any other options that they would like included in the proposal.
She further said:
They are indicating that they would like to have time to review the draft legislation. At this stage they are being given no indication that they will be able to view that before it is presented.

That is certainly true, because the cavalier attitude of this Government will see it bring in the legislation and jackboot it through this place. The other night in answer to a question on appropriations, Senator Tate was asked some questions about how the proposed elections would be conducted in the absence of any legislation and in the absence of any way of knowing what structures would finally be agreed upon by the Parliament. The Minister said that the intention would be that the legislation would validate the elections and the Commission could not operate except with the passage of the legislation. He said further that these elections would be conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission in the hope-I stress those words-that the legislation would be passed by this Parliament in the Budget session. How presumptuous of the Minister to say that the Aboriginal people and constituency will agree to the legislation when it comes in here. How presumptuous to think that the Government will force the Australian Electoral Commission to put some sort of guidelines instead of proper regulations into place to run such a form of elections.

It is very interesting to look at the groups that give support right around Australia to Aboriginal affairs. They are very widespread. There is confidence in the electorate that Aboriginal people are coming to grips with self-management but when we get this sort of pious and hypocritical clandestine attitude of the Government to the project, how can we possibly expect that Aboriginal people can stand up with continuing dignity?

There are implications in this legislation which are constitutional in their import-for example, land acquisition and antecedent native title. What about the business and commercial opportunities and situations that have to be faced up to? The new structures will require special consideration of State and Northern Territory governments. On 27 April, the Minister did not report on any of his consultations in this regard. He has not had the honesty to come in here and bring these points forward. What about the implications for the public servants, the thousands of employees of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the ADC, the Institute of Aboriginal Studies and the departments of education which will all have to be transferred? What about the agencies and the hundreds and hundreds of Aboriginal organisations which will have to adapt? There is no way that they can get their act together to implement such a proposal by 1 January 1989. Again, the Minister is setting unachievable targets and unachievable dates. He has not even had this matter passed by Cabinet or put through the Labor Caucus committees yet. There is no formulation. The Labor Party has not properly addressed it and we have been treated to the pious simple statements as to how this would be done. Warren Snowdon, the member for the Northern Territory in the House of Representatives, recently reported to the Labor Party's conference in the Northern Territory two paragraphs on this issue. He said:
The fruits of those consultations have now paid dividends with the Minister announcing this week that the new Commission will commence operations on 1 January 1989.
Significantly, several changes have now been made to the original proposal which accommodate concerns which were raised by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders over the past few months.

Those two paragraphs are his only report to the Labor conference in the Northern Territory. Sure, some of the Aboriginal issues have been picked up in the options paper, but a lot of other things have not. They have not been publicly put. Mr Snowdon did not have the honesty to report on any of them to his Labor Party conference or to his electorate. They have not been picked up and put in place in a proper way. What about the other members of parliament throughout Australia with significant Aboriginal representation in their electorates? I get the impression that they are a mob of silent dummies, particularly the politicians inside the Labor camp. We have not heard from Mr Campbell from Kalgoorlie. We have not heard from the inner suburban Sydney or Melbourne seats that will be vitally affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Campbell will not say anything which offends his white constituents, I suspect.

—No, the only people those politicians tune to are people such as Mansell with his radicalism, because this whole proposal seems to be in this area. There has not been any response from the Government to the excellent document by the Aboriginal Development Commission which looked at alternative proposals. It was prepared by a group of very well qualified commissioners in the ADC who represented a very broad constituency. They did not do it without knowledge or understanding. All those proposals have been ridden over roughshod without any critical analysis publicly by the Government. What are we playing a tune to? Where is the degree of leadership and confidence that anyone should be able to expect, when the Aboriginal Development Commission is treated so disrespectfully?

SPEECH.PARA: What about the so-called active and involved Aboriginal consultation? The Minister went out in early January, February and March and talked with the community. The mark 2 version of the options paper went out in April and we have not seen any further response to it. Obviously we will not be shown it. The legislation will be brought in and rammed through-and the Aboriginal people will not be given appropriate time to respond to it. It is also very interesting to look at a couple of people who have also spoken out on this issue. Ex-senator Neville Bonner has been referred to-a very eminent Aboriginal Australian. He has very severely criticised the Government. Ken Colbung, a leading Western Australian Aboriginal is another of these people who are very strong in the political area. We do not want people who are prepared to be patsies and stooges taking over the running of this issue. There is support in the community for changes to Aboriginal administration but we do not want that done in such a dreadful manner as the Government has done it. I am pleased to support the motion by Senator Coulter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too am very pleased, on behalf of the Opposition, to support the motion of urgency which has been brought forward by Senator Coulter. In the Senate in recent times we have heard a number of expressions of concern about the adequacy and effectiveness of the consultation which has been taking place about the proposal to terminate the role of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), hostels and the Institute of Aboriginal Studies, and to combine them in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, commonly known as ATSIC. I thank the Australian Democrats for bringing forward this motion because it represents the clearest possible message that could be delivered to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) that he is not entitled simply to rush on with this proposal. He does not have the capacity to do so because the Opposition in the Senate, like the Australian Democrats, is determined to ensure that the Minister does not put in place new arrangements which are not the subject of a genuine consultation process which leads to a genuine understanding on the part of the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister not only has to satisfy the Aboriginal community that the changes he is making are for the better; he has to satisfy us that he has achieved that and that what he is doing is right. I must say that over recent months when I have been casting about in my mind as to how one delivers an effective message to Minister Hand, I had not thought of this procedure. That is why I am pleased that the matter has been brought forward in this way by Senator Coulter because the passage of this motion-and pass it will-is a clear message to the Minister that his legislation cannot simply be pushed through this chamber in the way he can push it through the House of Representatives, with a flick of the finger. What the Minister has to face up to is that there is a real problem for us-and by that I mean the Opposition and those others examining what he is doing-as to how we can be satisfied about the bona fides of the process he has undertaken and its effectiveness. I say that because I cannot recall any precedent for the sort of action that the Minister has undertaken in the sacking of eight of the ADC commissioners.

I can recall numerous precedents when successive Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs, including me, have been embarrassed, put upon and rendered at times extremely cross at the opposition we have received from sections of the Aboriginal community. I cannot remember when we have engaged in the sort of action that Minister Hand has engaged in, when he silenced these people by dismissing them. It is suggested in the statement put out by Mrs McPherson that the only reason he did not dismiss her was that he could not. That is quite an extraordinary way for a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to behave and puts me-and the Opposition-on inquiry as to what the Minister is up to. It does not impress me very much to get messages from Wenten Rubuntja and Galarrwuy Yunupingu-not because they are not very important and impressive men; they are. Both of them have had long-standing involvement in the land councils-in the central and northern land councils respectively.

But the land councils have not been touched by this ATSIC proposal. The most constant complaints I have heard of the Minister's office is that the only people he listens to are those on the land councils. I have absolutely no doubt that the land councils, whatever the state of dissatisfaction of others, are perfectly satisfied with what is going on because they are calling the shots. I for one will need to be convinced that more than the land councils are being served by what the Government is proposing. I am sure that if Senator Coulter and I wanted to, we could engage in an exchanging message for message exercise with the Minister. I am sure that over the next few months we could collect lots of messages which said that people disagreed with what the Minister was doing and he could collect lots of messages saying that people agreed with what he was doing.

Again I put the Government on notice that that is not the way this matter is going to be determined. Senator Jenkins and I received a common message today from people dubbing themselves the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress of Western Australia-people whom Senator Jenkins tells me she knows well and some of whom I know. They have asked us to take action in the Senate to condemn the action of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, in sacking the eight Aboriginal commissioners for the Aboriginal Development Commission. Indeed, they asked for Mr Hand's dismissal. They also asked for more time. Senator Jenkins and I, and Senator Tambling who has just resumed his seat, have all said publicly, both outside this place and certainly, as far as Senator Tambling and I are concerned, in this place-and perhaps Senator Jenkins as well, I am not sure-that the impromptu consultations that we have undertaken with the Aboriginal community have given us a very different picture from that outlined by Government representatives. We get a picture of people badly needing more time to really comprehend what is being done.

The simple message that I hope the Minister takes from the passage of this motion is that he has to adopt an approach which is different from the one he has adopted to this point. The Minister will have to be much more open and will have to be involved in discussion with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats on the basis that he ensures that we have a complete understanding of what he is doing. He needs to understand that we will not rubber stamp what he is doing; we will need to be satisfied that what he is doing is right. I do not intend to try to repeat the sorts of concerns I expressed in the Senate as recently as 19 May, just late last week, about my view as to the state of Aboriginal affairs in this country. I think it is pathetic. I think that if the Government is to be condemned for anything it should be condemned for the last five years. I regard the last five years as years of going backwards. I find very few voices in the Aboriginal community that quarrel with that and I find very few people who work with the Aboriginal community who quarrel with that. Indeed I cannot, as I stand here speaking to the Senate today, think of anybody who claims that the last five years have been years of advance. I cannot think of a single person who has tried to deliver that message to me over recent years.

That is why I am so pleased to be in support of this motion-because the Government now can be left under no illusion that it is not entitled to just run along its present track. There is no future in its just running along its present track, sacking people who get in the way and who do not actually fit in with its little preconceived notions. It is not going to get through this Parliament legislation which does not satisfy us in this chamber as to its bona fides. I think that is the simple message for this afternoon.

I said last Thursday and I wish to say again that I do not make a criticism in a personal sense of the Minister. I think that he is sincere and he is dedicated, but I do not think that he listens to all of those around him who are capable of giving him very useful and good advice. The shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Chris Miles, said in the House of Representatives on 27 April that he thought this legislation had to be delayed into next year. He said that he thought that more time was required for consultation. I refer to what he had to say on that date, 27 April, at page 2176 of Hansard. I mention that because the Minister cannot claim that he has been short of complaints, warnings or expressions of concern whether from within the Parliament or from outside the Parliament. I have come to the unhappy conclusion that the only way that the Opposition will have any influence on what the Minister does is not by argument but by the use of what powers we have in this chamber to require that the Minister meet the requirements of consultation which have been referred to by Senator Coulter in moving this motion. I believe that he cannot now escape the obligation to carry us with him if he wishes to make the sorts of changes that he is making.

Again, I do not wish to go through in detail some of the doubts that I have about it-doubts, for example, about the incorporation of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies, a relatively minor matter. It is something which I think in the long term is of importance to all Aboriginal people in Australia because it is a repository and a permanent store of things which would otherwise be lost and forgotten.

I do not wish to delay the Senate further. I simply hope that the Minister will take this matter seriously and that he will look at the terms of this motion, including the reinstatement of the Aboriginal Development Commission commissioners that he chose to dismiss. I have the warmest of respect and regard for some of the people that he has appointed in lieu of the existing commissioners-people such as Lois O'Donoghue. There would be no finer person that I have ever worked with from the Aboriginal community or, indeed, from any part of the community. But I do not think that is the point; I think that for the Minister to have in place of the ADC, or running the ADC, what appears, and must now appear to every Aboriginal person in Australia, as his hand-picked stacked deck is scarcely the way to proceed to determine whether or not the ADC should be abolished. I think it is a very silly approach; in fact, I cannot think of a sillier approach for a Minister to adopt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly after the motions yesterday.

—Yes. As my colleague Senator Tambling points out, particularly after the motions yesterday. We had the quite extraordinary situation-extraordinary in terms of the history of these matters-where the ADC decided to withdraw from legal action, we are told, on behalf of the eight sacked commissioners and where we have Mrs McPherson being forced to take stances which are utterly at odds with the position she adopted a few weeks ago. She described the dismissal of her colleagues as an outrageous and intolerable political jack boot action. I must say that I am surprised that Mr Hand should dress himself up in some sort of Genghis Khan guise and adopt this high-handed and oppressive attitude which he appears to be adopting. I think it would be a great shame if, after his conscientious attempts to come to grips with this most difficult portfolio, he were to go down a path which would leave him, I think, alienated from a substantial section of the Aboriginal community, which must increase the deep divisions which exist in the Aboriginal community and if he is seen in the end as a prisoner of a section of the Aboriginal community and a section of his own political Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the Australian Democrat senator who brought this motion forward has performed a useful service in firing a clear shot across the Minister's bows. The Opposition supports the basis of this motion. We call upon the Minister to consider it very carefully indeed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STRENGTHENING AUSTRALIA'S SCHOOLS: A CONSIDERATION OF THE FOCUS AND CONTENT OF SCHOOLING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a paper in which the Government has outlined some of its proposals for the future on education. It is entitled Strengthening Australia's Schools: A Consideration of the Focus and Content of Schooling. In some ways there is not a great deal of depth to the paper, but in other respects it has got within it things that ought to be considered. It deals with the possibility of moving to a situation where there is more uniformity in education throughout the various States. The paper refers to local communities and their interest in education and, to a limited extent, to their role in education and certainly their expectations.

Appendix A outlines quite extensively the reviews of schooling which have taken place in this country since 1981. It is certainly a very long list. It causes one to wonder whether or not anything really comes out of all these inquiries and reports. As I said, it is a quite lengthy list and refers to several reports which have taken place in the Australian Capital Territory. The most recent report, about which I have spoken on other occasions, Community schools for Canberra 1989-2000, was put out by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. This report started last year. It was first presented in October last year when we learned that some nine schools in Canberra were to close-one high school and eight primary schools. Consequent to that, the schools involved had certain things to do. Those that were closing were able to put in submissions and some 250 submissions were put in to the Schools Authority in relation to the closure of the nine schools. The other schools which were to be enlarged were told to get on with the job of preparing for enlargement.

On 6 May this year the Government presented the final report dealing with the submissions that were put in. Of the nine schools that were to close, five are to remain open and four will still close. What surprised most people was that one school that it was announced would be closing-it had never been mentioned for annihilation and was to have proceeded as an enlarged school, according to the first report-was the Page Primary School. The parents of the other nine schools which were scheduled for closure had the opportunity to present their case to the Schools Authority as to why those schools should not close. Five schools presented cases which resulted in their remaining open. One was the Griffith school. I saw some of the parents of that school. They put in a most comprehensive statement. They pointed out some quite significant mistakes which had been made in the first decision that would close them; namely, electricity charges of the O'Connell Education Centre were charged against the Griffith school as were costs relating to the watering of an oval that was used only in part by the Griffith school, and other facts of that nature.

The Holder Primary School put in a submission, which I also saw. It was a very comprehensive document that related to the distances children had to walk and other matters. They are two of the schools which will remain open. Scullin, which we might say was the school in competition with Page, will also stay open. The reasons that it put forward-on the grounds of safety-were very compelling indeed, and I have no quarrel with that school staying open. But I find it extraordinary that the parents in Page will just get wiped out, as I have indicated, without having any opportunity to put in submissions as to why the Page school should remain open. It is strange indeed that nearby there are three schools-Macquarie, Cook and Aranda, all in a row-which are to remain open. Forty per cent of the suburb of Page is now not covered by one of the circles which are supposed to cover the maximum distance beyond which children should not have to travel to go to a primary school. As I said, I have spoken on this before. I think these parents have been treated in an unprincipled way. I have called upon the Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory, the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch), to annul the whole of the proposals with respect to the South Belconnen area and to ask or direct the Schools Authority to look at the matter again. It may be that the Page school will still close, but at least the parents of that community will have had the opportunity to present their arguments and be heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are looking today at the paper put down yesterday by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) entitled Strengthening Australia's Schools: A Consideration of the Focus and Content of Schooling. I am not at all sure of the reason for bringing down this paper at this time. If one goes through the paper and examines each section, one will see that it does not hang together. There is a vague wish, which I suppose one could agree with, that there be a national objective with regard to our schools. However, once one sought to go beyond that, I would suggest, the type of debate that would be entered into would be pretty horrific.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I have only five minutes in which to speak, I wish to concentrate on only one point, and that is the section headed `Priorities for Improving the Training of Teachers' on page 5 of the printed copy of the statement. It starts off with the following statement, which is unexceptional:

The quality of teaching is central to the quality of our schools. Teachers must be appropriately qualified to teach a curriculum attuned to current expectations held of schools. Qualifications which were once appropriate may no longer be in demand.
I think that can be accepted. It is the next stage of the Government's current thinking which strikes me as quite extraordinary. It states:

We must ensure that there are sufficient numbers of teachers in all subject areas. For example, increased participation and achievement in mathematics and science can only be realised if we have an adequate number of appropriately trained teachers.

That is something we do not have in Australia. We have an appalling lack of appropriately trained teachers in science and mathematics. It seems that this Government is proposing, in terms of the ready adoption by the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of the report of the Wran Committee on Higher Education Funding, the creation of a situation in which maths and science teachers will earn less than history teachers. I do not by that comment wish to denigrate history teachers, but it so happens that we have a sufficient number of history teachers at the moment. History and English teachers-we have a shortage of English teachers-are certainly in demand, but maths and science teachers are very much in demand. The Government is proposing, under the structures coming out of the Wran Committee's report, to pay them less. Quite frankly, that is what I would call a massive disincentive that it wishes to build into the system. At the same time the Minister wishes to flourish this paper in which he says that we need to have increased participation and achievement in maths and sciences. I can but agree. We certainly do. We need incentives, not disincentives. It is extraordinary that these pieces of paper come out of the Minister's office, with no connection to one another, and we are expected to accept the statements on their face value when in fact they are basically in conflict.

We have had difficulty in the past with the spreading of rumours which are unfounded and undifferentiated. For example, various State governments said a few years ago that we had too many teachers. That was never the case. We might have too many if we wish to keep some large numbers in the primary and secondary schools. In any event, we have never had enough maths and science teachers. We now have an alarming dearth of maths and science teachers, for a number of reasons. Most of our maths teachers had to go across and teach computer science, leaving a gap in the maths area which had to be filled by many of the science graduates, thereby leaving a gap in the science area which in my State of Queensland was filled by domestic science teachers-and why not, it has got `science' in the title!

This is the way in which we believe we are building up the foundations of our education system. It is quite ludicrous. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), is herself an educator and she knows it is quite ludicrous. We really do need to have a thrust at the primary and secondary levels. Our tertiary system is firmly based upon the primary and secondary levels. If we are interested in having equity, participation or any of the other matters that the Government goes on to talk about in terms of keeping children in school, we have to have the teachers there. The teachers are the major resource upon which students draw for their learning. If we are not willing to put massive incentives into getting bright young graduates in maths and science into teaching, we are certainly not going to do the best that we can for the next generation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to make some comments on the ministerial paper entitled Strengthening Australia's Schools: A Consideration of the Focus and Content of Schooling. In the introduction to this paper the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) makes the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: From its inception public schooling has played a crucial role in the intellectual and social development of Australia's children.

He goes on in the paper to refer to the expectation of parents and the community generally, and points to the central tradition of schools in the whole business of developing the nature of Australian society and the Australian economy.

The paper talks quite a lot about making the most effective use of a whole range of resources which go to supporting and making up the school system. On page 2 of the printed copy of the report the Minister, quite rightly, points to the fact that the States have had, and will continue to have, primary responsibility for the education of our young people. As a senator for Victoria I would particularly like to take the opportunity here to comment on a Press report which I saw recently in the Melbourne Age, in which the spokesperson on education for the Liberal Opposition in Victoria was castigating the relatively new Minister for Education in Victoria, the Honourable Caroline Hogg, for requesting from, I believe, her departmental regional officers information, stories and anecdotes about good, productive and positive things that were going on in the schools in their region. Mr Haddon Storey, the shadow Minister, was quoted in this article. It said that he believed the Minister was in fact engaging in a party political exercise of government promotion by asking her departmental people to come up with information about positive things that were going on in the public school system in Victoria.

I would like to place on record, as a former parent and community activist in the education field subsequent to a career in teaching, that I believe the Victorian Minister is in fact doing a great service to the public education sector. I say that because one of the things that we lack and that we need if we are going to strengthen Australia's schools is a correct public perception as against some of the myths and, in fact, misrepresentations that exist in the community about what does go on in Australia's public school system-a school system very much under seige all too often in recent years. It is a school system which bears the burden of the responsibility for educating Australia's children, and we must never forget that it is a system which cannot reject any student who comes through its doors, unlike the private school sector, which can pick and choose, and does, and which at the same time is quite heavily funded by government sources, at both State and Federal level. As a president of my own children's parents club and later as a co-convenor of a pilot community joint schools council, some decade ago in Victoria, one of the matters to which I gave priority and to which my committees gave priority was doing exactly at the local level what Minister Hogg is proposing to do at State level, which is to ensure that our communities are aware of the facts of what is going on in our community schools, such as the sorts of subjects undertaken, the work the students do, the contacts students have, the relationship between students and teachers, and the generally positive results that occurred in those schools. I commend Minister Hogg for her actions in support of the public school sector in Victoria. If anyone was playing party political opportunism in that exercise, it was the Liberal Party Opposition in Victoria.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to pass some remarks on the Australia-Japan Foundation annual report 1986-87. The Australia-Japan Foundation was formed by Act of Parliament in 1976 and the same Act also established the Australia-Japan Fund, which the Foundation administers. The objects of the Australia-Japan Foundation are to deepen and strengthen relations between Australia and Japan by fostering greater mutual awareness and understanding through people to people contact and by promoting study and other activities to elucidate to each other the society, culture, language and outlook of the two peoples.

The functions of the Foundation are to be commended. They are to encourage a closer relationship between the peoples of Australia and Japan; to further the mutual knowledge and understanding of those peoples, in particular, to promote the study by the people of each of those countries of the language, culture and traditions, the social and political institutions and the economic and industrial organisation of the people of the other country; to promote the study by the people of each of those countries of the physical features, climate and ecology of the other country; to encourage people of each of those countries to visit the other country; and, of course, to administer the Fund.

The Foundation is responsible to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The report contains a list and brief description of all the Foundation's programs. These are many and varied and I would like to mention in particular the Japan Broadcasting Corporation-that is, the NHK-and its television series on Australia. The Japan Broadcasting Corporation produced in association with the Foundation a major television documentary and drama series featuring Australia. The programs have attracted a combined audience of 45 million people, and the broadcasts started going to air in October 1986.
One element of the report gives rise to concern, and that is an operational problem. I quote from the report at page 11:

The Foundation wishes to draw attention again to the severe problems experienced by small organisations when confronted with staff resignations. Existing Public Service procedures, combined with a variety of other restraints, do not allow for rapid action. Notwithstanding every effort made to obtain expeditious relief, positions can remain vacant for months leading to a substantial disruption of the activities of the organisation.
In the Chairman's message at the start of the report, there is this plea:
It is considered imperative that the Foundation be able as a matter of course to appoint permanent officers to fill gaps left by resignations.

In conclusion, I would like to draw attention to another matter of concern. Notwithstanding Australia's invaluable educational and cultural links with Japan through the Foundation, the Government is urged strongly from a number of sides and through its Foreign Investment Review Board to compile a full register of all property held by overseas investors. I quote from today's Australian:
The Japanese have bought more than $700m worth of real estate in Queensland in the past two years and are involved in more than $2.7 billion worth of development in the State.

The total amount of overseas investment is not on register in Australia. Although, of course, it is close to all our hearts to maintain our cultural and educational links with Japan, it is not in the interests of Australians to have overseas investments of that amount not on record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Frankly, I do not know how an Australia-Japan Foundation lecture series involving Dr Alan Trounson's visit to Japan to lecture on the medical and ethical aspects of invitro fertilisation (IVF) in Australia fits within the object or functions as described and well noted by Senator Jenkins and which are contained at page 8 of the report. It is a sick joke to suggest that Dr Alan Trounson should be able to lecture the Japanese or anyone else on the ethics of IVF. After all, it was he who admitted to the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation that he held views that would enable human embryo experimentation to take place. In answer to a question from Senator Walters, he said: `Well, if we could extend that to 28 days, there could well be an argument for that to occur'. He then went on to say, `We could go beyond 28 days'.

SPEECH.PARA: In effect, Dr Trounson holds views on this matter that are diametrically opposed to the well established views that were outlined in the Helsinki Agreement; that is, of course, that any medical research involving human subjects must allow the well-being of the human subject to take precedence over the interests of science and society. Dr Trounson is involved in the commercialisation of IVF; so much so that, recently, a company known as the Infertility Medical Centre Pty Ltd was established in Victoria. Its shareholders are the Monash University, Dr Carl Wood and Dr Alan Trounson. It is important to note what Dr Robyn Rowlan said about that company. She said that when IVF Australia was established, objections were raised to publicly funded universities being associated with a private company. She said that the explanation was that any profits from the venture would go into general university funds and benefit the whole university. I am quoting from an article in the Herald of 31 March. She went on to say:
It is different with this new company. Now the funds will go directly back to embryo experimentation.
She said the doctors involved in the Epworth Hospital program were:
trying to drain all the money off into their own research. It is another business which will hinge on women as a raw material. They are doing it for scientific kudos.

The taxpayer-funded Australia-Japan Foundation is using taxpayers' money to send Dr Trounson to lecture the Japanese on the ethics of in vitro fertilisation-and has used $15,655 to do so. I do not know how much the air fare is and I do not know how much he was paid to do it. However, I would certainly like to know on whose recommendation this was done. If it was on the recommendation of, for example, the National Health and Medical Research Council, the recommendation is suspect since it is the organisation which recommended that $450,000 of medical research grants funds to go to the Monash Centre for Bioethics and Dr Peter Singer for the purposes of developing an ethical framework in which human embryo experimentation and foetal tissue transplantation can take place. He holds a utilitarian view that no human has an inherent right to life until well after birth. That is inconsistent with the general attitude of the community and certainly the Foundation should not be spending taxpayers' money on sending people to Japan to lecture when they have that sort of attitude. It certainly does not represent the view of the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation or the view of the majority of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have but a couple of minutes. I know not of the matter to which Senator Harradine referred but I commend the Australia-Japan Foundation for its work, which is known to me, in the year in question. Its work included the Japanese television series on Australia that I know to have been a great success; the work it sponsored at the Australian Studies Centre at Nanzan University in Japan; the Australian studies symposium it sponsors in Japan; the Japanese high school teachers' visit which the Foundation sponsored; its co-sponsorship of the Sydney Dance Company tour of Japan; and the office and library it provides in Tokyo. In the year in question, in excess of 8,800 visitors used this library on Australia. It is most worth while to have that centre available to Japanese in their capital city.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to put into context that when one thinks of the Foundation, one must remember the Government's well-publicised attempt to get rid of the Australia-Japan Foundation. It was saved by public outcry, which was headed by its Chairman, Mr Sleigh. It is beyond my comprehension why the Government would want to bring an end to this body, which worked towards fostering a better understanding between Australia and Japan. Apparently the Foundation did not fit the bureaucratic model, because of its office being in Sydney, the greater independence that it had from our normal bureaucracy or the direct contact it had with the public. In any event and for whatever reason, obviously the Government wanted the Foundation disbanded. When the Government looked at how it wanted the Foundation disbanded it discovered that it had been set up by legislation and that it would not be able to get legislation to disband it through the Senate, so it had to abandon its attempt. Nevertheless the Government has done its best to limit the effectiveness of the Foundation.

Now the Foundation has had to move office from a high profile centre of Sydney location to be absorbed in the Department in Canberra. It has had its staff reduced from seven to four and, while it had been headed by an officer from outside the Public Service, it will now be headed from within that bureaucracy with the level of the senior officer bearer being reduced. All the Government can say positively about all that is that it saves $67,000. That is a minute saving compared with the challenges that abound in a relationship with our principal trading partner, a relationship involving approximately $15 billion worth of trade a year. Everyone understands that if that is to be sustained and built upon, a better understanding is needed of the Japanese and the Japanese need a better understanding of Australians. There is no better way of achieving that than through cultural exchanges and through building a better understanding as is fostered by such bodies as the Australia-Japan Foundation.

I condemn the attempt of the Government to downgrade this body. I wish it well in future. It has a major responsibility. It has my support and the support of the other members on this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Since 1978 when the Australia New Zealand Foundation was set up it has proved to be a very good project. I commend the Foundation to everyone in both Australia and New Zealand. Australia is not nearly close enough to its New Zealand neighbour and as we lurch down the road of internationalism, finding the best relationship possible with neighbours of a similar culture is becoming more important all the time. Too often we concentrate on our differences and not enough on what we have in common. Concentrating on what we have in common is more necessary than ever now. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memoranda relating to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1988
I seek leave to have the second reading speech for the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988 incorporated in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1987 was introduced and passed in the Parliament in the last session to provide grants to the States and the Northern Territory for universities, advanced education, institutes of tertiary education and technical and further education for 1988. The main purpose of this Bill is to amend that Act to adjust for cost movements in the tertiary education grants. It will also provide additional funds for superannuation in higher education to cater for the 3 per cent productivity claim and emerging costs for the States.

SPEECH.PARA: Provision is also made for a program designed to provide interim additional funding for institutions providing higher education courses that will not be in a position to achieve immediately the productivity gains which are a condition of the second tier national wage decision. The Government's decision that bridging funds should be made available in the short-term is to provide assistance to institutions in meeting their obligations while productivity gains are achieved, and recognises the rights of workers to receive negotiated salary increases as early as possible. The amount to be provided under this program will be some $46.3m and institutions will need to be in a position to seek funds in sufficient time for determinations to be made and for payments to be finalised by 30 June 1988.

As part of the Government's drug offensive it has been decided that funds should be made available for the coordination of drug and alcohol education in teaching hospitals. It is felt that an important means of combating drug and alcohol abuse is to ensure that the curriculum for undergraduate students in medical schools brings out the dangers and problems that arise from this abuse. Consequently provision is made in this Bill for funds to be made available under a new program for the 10 university teaching hospitals presently receiving recurrent funds from the Commonwealth Government. The funding for this new program is to be provided initially through the Department of Employment, Education and Training, and in 1988 will amount to some $560,000.

In total the Bill will provide for additional Government expenditure of some $112.8m of which $42.9m will result from the Government's agreed procedures to make retrospective adjustment for cost variations, $23.0m will be provided in connection with superannuation in higher education institutions, $46.3m as assistance to the higher education sector to implement the second tier national wage decisions and $0.6m in the drug and alcohol offensive.

In introducing this Bill we have also taken the opportunity to make a number of minor technical amendments. Non-government teachers colleges have been provided with grants under the special assistance for students program in line with other higher education institutions. They have not however been required to produce as a condition of this grant statistical and other information pertinent to this program. In line with the requirements for other higher education institutions we have now included this as a condition of grant under this program.

We have also, consistent with grants for higher education institutions, made provision for grants under the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 to be offset in accounting procedures by institutes of tertiary education. In the tertiary and further education sector we have recognised that building work undertaken up to the end of a particular year and commitments entered into for the purchase of equipment during the year cannot necessarily be paid for within that year. Consequently grants for 1988 need not necessarily be expended in 1988 but may be carried over for later payment.

It is to be stressed that this Bill is of a routine variety consistent with amending Acts made in previous years to legislation providing funds for tertiary education. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1988
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the second reading speech for the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Education Legislation

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1984 to supplement for cost increases grants already appropriated for government and non-government schools programs in 1988.

The Bill also modifies certain existing provisions in the Act relating to non-government schools which change their location. Under the new provisions, where the change is to a location adjacent to the school and where it does not involve a change in the level of education being provided by the school, the school or school system will no longer be required to notify the Minister of the change. These new provisions will apply to schools which are seeking approval this year to change their location in 1990.
Further amendments include:
extension of the provisional approval period to two years for new non-government schools or for a school undergoing a notifiable change;
new non-government schools will now be eligible for establishment grants if they serve a developing area. Previously these schools were required to be situated in a developing area.
The total amount of supplementation to be provided by this Bill is $21 million.
I commend the Bill to the Senate
