TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We have listened very carefully to the words of Senator Puplick and it would help if there were some definition of what he terms `personal abuse'. We had the scenario here yesterday where an error was made by honourable senators on the other side of the chamber for which we, in turn, were punished as the Opposition made the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) read a very long second reading speech. It was not our fault but, nonetheless, we were the ones who were punished. We have been told that that will happen again. I hope that discussions can take place between the Government and the Opposition as to the definition of `personal abuse'. We are involved in politics and there is the old saying: If you do not like the heat you ought to get out of the kitchen. Let us just find out how much heat can be generated from each side in this very difficult period when we, as senators, want to get on with the business of the Senate and the business of governing this nation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill amends the Audit Act 1901. The principal amendments are intended to enhance the Commonwealth's financial reporting, administration and audit and to bring certain penalty provisions into line with present day criminal law policy.

Financial reporting will be facilitated through an amendment to section 49 which will enable the form of the Minister for Finance's monthly statement to be changed by regulation. This amendment accords with suggestions made during the debates on the statute law Bill in October 1987 that parliamentary control over the form should be retained.

Amendments are proposed in relation to the preparation of annual financial statements and fall into two categories. The first concerns the financial statements for the financial year ending 30 June 1988. The proposed amendment will provide for departmental transactions on functions lost to another department through the administrative arrangements order of 24 July 1987 to be shown in the financial statements of the department gaining the functions. In this way the 1987-88 statements will be made more meaningful by removing the requirement that would otherwise exist for separate statements covering the period from 1 July to 23 July.

The second category involves amendments which will enhance the accountability of departments. They will establish the responsibility of departmental secretaries to prepare annual financial statements of their departments and for those statements to be audited. The statements will be prepared in accordance with guidelines given by the Minister for Finance as to their form and content and will be included in departments' annual reports. Also, since a detailed level of information will be given in these departmental reports, the need for the present detailed reports by the Minister for Finance will disappear. The amendment provides instead that the Minister for Finance shall prepare a report showing aggregate totals only. These amendments were foreshadowed in the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports tabled in Parliament in November 1987.

Currently, the Auditor-General has a discretion not to report on immaterial breaches of establishing legislation by certain statutory bodies. One amendment, requested by the Auditor-General, will permit that discretion to apply to all statutory bodies.

I mention here that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has indicated that it does not support this amendment. However, I should point out that there is already a great degree of trust involved in relying upon the competence and integrity of the Auditor-General in the performance of the audit task. This extension is entirely consistent with that trust. Moreover, the amendment is in step with the statutory discretion which the Auditor-General already has not to report breaches which he considers too minor to mention. Such a discretion exists for audits of departments and a wide range of statutory bodies.

Another amendment will repeal the general `catch-all' penalty provision currently contained in section 69 of the Audit Act and substitute specific penalties in the relevant sections of the Act. The amendment stems from advice from the Attorney-General's Department on the desirability for Audit Act penalties to be consistent with the Commonwealth's policy on criminal law, generally.

Other amendments concern the creation of a specific offence for the misuse of credit cards issued to the Commonwealth, clarifying the Minister for Finance's powers to write-off irrecoverable revenue and debts that are uneconomic to pursue, and minor legislative tidying up. All proposed amendments have already been considered by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and, apart from the proposal concerning rounding off the Auditor-General's discretion not to have to report immaterial matters, the Committee has raised no objection to them.

The proposed change to the future reporting requirements aimed at enhancing departmental accountability is likely to give rise to some additional resource costs, including to the Australian Audit Office. However, it is expected that the improved accountability will lead to greater efficiencies in departmental management. It is not possible, at this stage, to quantify in financial terms the costs or the benefits.

The amendment concerning the preparation of annual statements for the 1987-88 financial year's report should reduce administrative effort and costs from the levels that would otherwise have been required, by permitting rationalisation of reports to reflect changed administrative arrangements effective from 24 July 1987.

The other changes, including those effecting the penalty provisions, the duties of the Auditor-General and the write-off powers of the Minister for Finance, are not expected to have any significant financial impact on Commonwealth revenue or expenditure.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to make 3 small but important groups of amendments to Acts in the Defence portfolio.

One group of amendments relates to the commutation of pensions by retiring members of the Defence Force under the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973. The Act enables retirees in receipt of retirement pay and some categories of recipients of invalidity pay to elect to commute a proportion of their entitlements to a lump sum. As the Act stands, the election cannot be made until after a person has retired, and it is not effective until it is received by the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority.

There has been concern that if a retiree died before being able to make an election, no lump sum payment could be made. As a result, it is common for potential retirees, in order to protect the interests of their dependants, to take out short term insurance to provide a lump sum payment in the event of their death during the critical period.

In more common cases, the time necessarily taken for the processing of an election and payment of a commutation amount can cause complications for retiring members in their adjustment from service to civilian life. These substantial payments are an important part of post-retirement financial planning. As an example, delay caused by the inability of retirees to make an election until after retirement may require retirees to take out short term bridging finance to cover house purchases.

The Bill amends the Act to enable retiring members to make the election up to 3 months before retirement to be effective on retirement, thus eliminating the necessity for taking out insurance. Timely payment will also assist members in their resettlement arrangements. It should perhaps be added that, if a member dies or is retired on invalidity grounds before an election becomes effective, no commutation payment is made.

Another group of amendments relates to the constitution of the Defence Housing Authority. Under section 12 of the Defence Housing Authority Act 1987, the Authority comprises 9 persons being the chairperson, the managing director, 3 members of the Defence Force, a member of the Public Service and 3 appointed members, the latter being persons with expertise in housing operations, property development or management, business management, etc.

It was announced in October last that, in recognition of the need for service spouses, as the people most affected by decisions regarding service housing, to have a direct input into the making of those decisions, the Act would be amended so that a service spouse could be appointed to the Authority. The Bill amends the Act accordingly and also provides for an extra appointed member who will bring additional financial expertise to the Authority. Subject to passage of the Bill, an announcement will be made later regarding the persons to be appointed.

The last group of amendments relates to the bringing into force of amendments made to the Defence Act 1903 and the Naval Defence Act 1910 by the Defence Legislation Amendment Act 1987. These amendments introduced the concept of open-ended or permanent enlistment to retiring age for soldiers and sailors as an alternative to the traditional system of successive fixed-term engagements and reengagements. Under the new system, permanent enlistees will be able to claim discharge short of retiring age by giving appropriate notice. This right is subject to certain constraints, particularly a return-of-service obligation where a member has successfully completed a course of training. Planning for the introduction of the new scheme in July this year has revealed the need to clarify the references to the courses concerned, and the Bill therefore amends these references. The Bill also includes similar amendments to corresponding provisions related to officers' resignations.

To avoid possible misunderstanding, I should emphasise that these legislative changes do not foreshadow a more restrictive approach to voluntary separations from the Defence Force. So far as soldiers and sailors are concerned, the change is one of fine-tuning the new permanent enlistment scheme. This has been widely welcomed in the Defence Force for the greater certainty it gives to members in their career planning and the significant reduction it will bring in administrative effort. With regard to officers, the amendment will enable return of service obligations to be more clearly specified, particularly where initial training is concerned.
Financial Impact Statement

It is estimated that the fees and travelling expenses of the two additional members of the Defence Housing Authority will be $10,000 in the financial year 1988-89 and corresponding amounts in subsequent years. The other amendments have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES' REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION BILL 1988UNITED STATES NAVAL COMMUNICATION STATION (CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speeches in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES' REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION BILL 1988

This Bill seeks to repeal the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and to introduce a new scheme of compensation and rehabilitation for persons who are injured in the course of their employment by the Commonwealth.

Between 1976 and 1986, the Commonwealth's expenditure on workers' compensation increased by over 700%, from $25.04m to $203.29m per annum. Clearly, Mr President, this situation could not be allowed to continue. Accordingly, the Government decided that the Compensation Act should be reviewed with the aim of establishing a more equitable and cost-effective compensation system, with particular emphasis on the rehabilitation of injured employees.

The result is a Bill which, when it comes into operation, will provide for many important changes in the compensation system and the circumstances in which compensation will be payable. The Bill will minimise the human and financial cost of work-caused injury and disease while at the same time providing adequate compensation and support for long term incapacitated employees.

The main aspects of the new scheme are the provision of a better range of benefits for injured employees and the establishment of a new body to administer the Act. The Bill will also provide incentives for injured employees to return to work as soon as possible and will provide greater powers in relation to rehabilitation.
The Office of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation will be abolished and replaced by the new Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees.

The new Commission will consist of three persons to be appointed by the Governor-General-a Chief Executive Officer and two part-time Commissioners-one to represent the Commonwealth and the other to represent the interests of employees. This structure will allow employees and employing agencies to participate directly in the administration of the compensation and rehabilitation system.
Some specific functions of the Commission will be:
to determine claims accurately and expeditiously;
to minimise the duration of incapacity by arranging for the assessment of the rehabilitation needs and prospects of employees;
to co-operate with other bodies with the aim of reducing the incidence of work-related injuries; and
to conduct and promote research into the incidence and prevention of work-related injuries.
Rehabilitation and Compensation Legislation
The Commission will be required to comply with directions of a general nature issued to it by the Minister.

While the new scheme will be administered primarily by the Commission, the Bill makes provision for statutory authorities to be appointed in the future as self-administrators by Ministerial notice in the Gazette. Those authorities will have all the powers and functions of the Commission in relation to the determination of claims lodged by its employees but will also be required to comply with Ministerial directions. The Commission will be required to report on the operations of self-administrators under the legislation and the Chief Executive Officer will be empowered to require the provision of such information as is necessary for that purpose.

Self-administration will help to instil an awareness in those authorities of the costs of compensation and the benefits to be derived from effective rehabilitation and occupational health and safety measures.

Under the existing Act, the Commissioner determines the liability of the Commonwealth to pay compensation. This legislation will impose that liability to pay compensation on the Commission or self-administrator. In order to fund the system, the Commission will be required to calculate, on the basis of each organisation's claims record, the contributions to be made by Departments and statutory authorities to the Consolidated Revenue Fund. These contributions will act as a direct financial inducement to each department and statutory authority to reduce workers' compensation costs by effective rehabilitation and occupational health and safety measures.

Mr President, I turn now to the benefit which will be payable under this legislation. The benefits package is aimed specifically at assisting those employees most in need-that is-long-term incapacitated workers.

At the heart of the new scheme is the change from a system of fixed long-term benefits adjusted by regulation to one of weekly benefits calculated on the basis of the individual employee's Normal Weekly Earnings.

An employee's Normal Weekly Earnings will be based on his or her pre-injury salary and will take into account certain allowances and regular rostered overtime which the employee is required to work as a condition of his or her employment.
Employees who are incapacitated for work will receive weekly benefits equal to 100% of Normal Weekly Earnings for the equivalent of the first 45 weeks of that incapacity.

Where appropriate, the Bill will encourage employees to return to work on a gradual basis by allowing their income to increase according to the number of hours worked. For example, an employee who returns to work for 50% of the number of hours he or she worked before the injury would be entitled to an amount of compensation which, combined with the income from that employment, would provide the employee with 85% of his or her Normal Weekly Earnings.
There will be upper and lower limits on weekly payments so as to provide a measure of equality and a guaranteed minimum income for those who are on a low wage.

The maximum amount payable will be an amount equal to 150% of Average Weekly Earnings for all Employees in the Australian work force. The minimum amount will be either $202 per week plus $50 for a dependent spouse and $25 for each dependent child, or 90% of the employee's Normal Weekly Earnings, whichever is the lower. These benefits will be indexed automatically in line with movements in the Consumer Price Index.

The level of weekly benefits payable to an injured employee who is capable of returning to work will be calculated by subtracting the amount the employee is earning, or would be able to earn in suitable employment, from his or her Normal Weekly Earnings.

``Suitable employment'' for an employee who is permanently employed by the Commonwealth will mean employment by the Commonwealth or a statutory authority. In the case of a casual employee, suitable employment may include self-employment or employment in private industry. This distinction reflects the Government's commitment to maintaining the employer/employee relationship and reinforces the nexus between an employee's contract of employment and his or her rights to compensation.

Given that benefits under the scheme have been set at levels which are fair and equitable, the Government has decided that it would no longer be appropriate for employees to be able to redeem weekly benefits for lump sums except where those weekly payments are below $50 per week.
Weekly payments will cease at age 65. This Government does not consider it appropriate that employees should continue to receive workers' compensation benefits after the normal retirement age.

Mr President, under the existing Act an employee was required to establish only that his or her employment was a contributing factor in the contraction of a disease. This test does not adequately reflect the rights and obligations of the Commonwealth and its employees in relation to work-related disease and frequently results in the Commonwealth being liable to pay compensation for diseases which have little, if any, connection with employment.
This Bill seeks to remedy that situation by requiring an employee to show that his or her employment contributed in a material degree to the contraction of the disease.
The Government believes that this is a test which is firm but fair and which properly reflects the balance between the interests of the Commonwealth as employer and its employees.

An employee will not be required to show that his or her employment caused the disease, or even that it was the most important factor in the contraction of the disease. It is intended that the test will require an employee to demonstrate that his or her employment was more than a mere contributing factor in the contraction of the disease. Accordingly, it will be necessary for an employee to show that there is a close connection between the disease and the employment in which he or she was engaged.

In determining whether employment contributed in a material degree to the contraction of a disease in a particular case, regard would be had to whether the employment in which the employee was engaged carried an inherent risk of the employee contracting the disease in question and whether some characteristic or feature of the employment tended to cause, aggravate or accelerate the disease.

A disease which has been contributed to in a material degree by employment will be deemed to be an injury. Compensation will be payable if that injury results in the death, incapacity or permanent impairment of the employee.

The Bill will also contain disease provisions, similar to those contained in the existing Act, under which an employee suffering a specified disease will automatically be entitled to compensation if he or she had been engaged in certain specified kinds of employment.

The Bill will extend coverage to employees injured in ordinary recesses, such as lunch breaks, and by acts of violence arising as a result of their employment by the Commonwealth, for example, staff working overseas injured by warfare or terrorism.
The journey provisions in the existing Act have been modified to require that journeys to or from the place of employment must commence or terminate at the employee's place of residence.

Mr President, a significant factor in the escalation of compensation costs which I described earlier is the length of time that employees remain on compensation. It is obvious to this Government that the only way to reduce the period spent on compensation is by the effective rehabilitation of injured employees.

To this end, the Bill will encourage the speedy rehabilitation of employees who are injured by enabling employing agencies or the Commission to arrange for the assessment of the rehabilitation needs of the employee and the type of work which that person could perform following appropriate retraining.

Consistent with the goal of minimising incapacity and impairment, employing agencies and the Commission will have much broader powers in relation to the provision of rehabilitation programs than were previously available. The Commission will be able to approve persons and organisations as rehabilitation program providers and to arrange directly with them for the provision of rehabilitation programs tailored to the individual needs of employers. If an employee refuses to undertake a rehabilitation program, his or her rights to compensation will be suspended. On the other hand, employing agencies will be required to take all reasonable steps to provide suitable employment for employees who have undertaken rehabilitation programs. The Commission will also examine the introduction of a new system of ``work trials'' for injured employees to enable them to participate fully in the work force.
The Commission will have the power to arrange for the provision of necessary aids and appliances and home, vehicle or workplace modifications.

In conjunction with this, the Bill will provide for the payment of up to $200 per week in compensation if, after four weeks of incapacity, the employee reasonably requires another person to provide household services, such as cooking, cleaning and household maintenance. A further amount, up to a maximum of $200 per week, will be payable if he or she reasonably requires attendant care services, such as feeding, bathing, supply of medication or other services of a personal nature.

In addition to the weekly benefits which I have already outlined, the Bill will provide for the payment of lump sums for permanent impairment and non-economic loss. These payments will replace awards of damages at common law for losses of a non-economic nature.
A maximum of $80,000 will be payable for injuries which result in a permanent impairment and up to $30,000 for non-economic loss.

Under the existing Act, lump sum payments are made on the basis of a table of maims, with the level of payment being determined having regard to the loss, or loss of the efficient use, of various parts of the body.
That approach has been abandoned and the level of payments in future will be determined using a ``whole person'' approach, similar to that used under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

The ``whole person'' approach allows the degree of impairment to be assessed on a more accurate basis and expressed as a percentage loss of the use of the ability of the person to undertake normal living activities. A Guide to the Assessment of the Degree of Permanent Impairment will be prepared by the Commission for the purposes of the Bill, subject to Ministerial approval.
There will be a minimum threshold of 10% impairment under which compensation will not be payable, except where the impairment results from the loss of a finger or toe.

In recognition that a permanent impairment may lead to considerable pain and suffering and loss of enjoyment of life, up to $30,000 will also be payable for any non-economic loss suffered by an employee.
The non-economic loss element of compensation will also be assessed in accordance with the approved Guide.

Mr President, this Government recognises that special provision must be made for the dependants of an employee who has died as a result of a work-related injury. Accordingly, the death benefit payable under this legislation will be raised to $120,000, more than double that which was payable under the existing Act, and a further $40 per week will be payable for each dependent child of the employee.

It is intended that, in administering the Act, the Commission will expedite the payment of death benefits in order to avoid creating hardship, particularly in cases where the surviving spouse and children were living in the same household as the deceased employee.

Mr President, perhaps the most controversial aspect of the new legislation is that common law actions against the Commonwealth will be replaced by the comprehensive benefits which I have described. It is clear to this Government that the common law negligence action which bases its entitlement on proof of fault is a costly, inefficient and inappropriate mechanism for compensating injured workers. Delays in settling these actions act as a positive disincentive for employees to return to work and encourage them to maximise the extent and duration of their injuries.

The provision of an adequate level of weekly income, substantially increased lump-sum payments on death or impairment, payments for additional expenses for medical costs, aids and appliances and household help, combined with a commitment to rehabilitation and the return to suitable employment, make redundant any need for redress to the courts.
Accordingly, it will no longer be possible for an employee to sue the Commonwealth or a fellow employee.

Actions against third parties will also be discouraged. Employees or their dependants who sue third parties will not be entitled to receive further benefits under the scheme and will be required to pay back any amount of compensation they have received. The Commission will pursue third parties if necessary by taking over an action in place of the employee.

Mr President, there are some other matters which this Bill will address. For example, under the current system, an employee is deemed to be on unauthorised absence after two years absence from work as a result of an injury. This unjust situation will be remedied in this Bill. An employee who is incapacitated for work following a compensable injury will be considered to be on ``compensation leave''. Compensation leave is designed to continue the employer/employee relationship during the period of incapacity. This is a significant improvement on the current system.

An employee on compensation leave will, for the first 45 weeks of incapacity, continue to accrue sick leave and annual leave entitlements. Long service leave entitlements will continue to accrue throughout the whole period of incapacity.

Mr President, this Bill will also seek to reduce the unreasonable costs associated with work-related injuries by introducing measures to prevent ``double dipping'' by employees using sick leave payments or superannuation entitlements while on compensation. For example, many employees who have been retired on invalidity grounds under the current legislation enjoy benefits under both compensation and superannuation schemes at a rate considerably in excess of their previous income. Special transitional provisions relating to the combined superannuation and compensation benefits payable to employees who have been invalided out of employment are contained in the Bill.

``Top up'' of weekly benefits from sick leave entitlements will be prohibited. Payments by way of salary, wages or pay or under compensation schemes in force in the States will reduce compensation accordingly. No make-up pay or additional benefits under awards will be allowed where an employee receives benefits under this legislation.

The review and appeal provisions contained in the Bill are significantly different from those contained in the existing Act, under which the Commonwealth is generally the respondent in proceedings for review of determinations made by the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation.

This Bill will provide for the Commission to be respondent in proceedings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the courts, and will also introduce compulsory reconsideration by the Commission before application can be made to the Tribunal for review of a determination. Reconsideration will be an informal procedure under which the original determination of the Commission will be reviewed by an officer of the Commission not involved in the original decision. Parties will be encouraged to adduce all relevant evidence at the reconsideration stage so as to resolve as many disputes as possible before the matter is heard by the Tribunal.

These measures will facilitate the settlement of many applications for review before a formal hearing is held and improve the quality of primary decision-making, thereby reducing the number of appeals to the Tribunal. In short, the Commission's direct involvement in review proceedings will be of mutual benefit to the Commission and the Tribunal.

Mr President, the Government considers that this Bill will create a progressive compensation and rehabilitation system for Commonwealth employees which will result in fewer injuries, less suffering, lower costs and a better quality of life for those employees unfortunate enough to be injured in the course of their employment.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
UNITED STATES NAVAL COMMUNICATIONS STATION (CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES) BILL 1988

The purpose of this Bill is to apply the provisions of the proposed Commonwealth Employee's Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 to civilian employees of the Government of the United States at the naval communication station at North West Cape. These persons are currently covered by the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971, which is to be repealed.

The proposals put forward in this Bill will have no impact on Government expenditure since, under the terms of the agreement between the Governments of Australia and the United States which establishes the station at North West Cape, the Government of the United States will reimburse the Commonwealth for any expenditure incurred under this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is an important component of the Government's program of reform in employment, education and training. The Bill establishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training; four Councils to deal with specialist advising related to schools, higher education, employment and skills formation, and research; and a Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee.

The Bill also maintains the Government's commitment to a Commonwealth Employment Service within the Department of Employment, Education and Training consistent with Australia's obligations under ILO Convention 88; provides for Grants for Innovative Projects and for Curriculum Projects as well as for administrative support for the National Board and its Councils.

The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Act 1977, the Commonwealth Schools Commission Act 1973 and the Commonwealth Employment Service Act 1978, have until now provided for the statutory advisory structures in employment, education and training. These Acts are now to be repealed in this Bill.

The central purpose of the Bill is to enhance and streamline advisory structures in employment, education and training in a manner consistent with the high economic and social priority placed on these activities by the Government. The provisions of the Bill enable the Government to obtain independent advice on employment, education, training and research policies and programs within a single co-ordinated framework.

The functions of the following non-statutory bodies-the Australian Council for Employment and Training (ACET), the Marine Research Allocations Advisory Committee, the National Research Fellowships Advisory Committee, and the Australian Research Grants Committee (ARGC)-will also be subsumed under the new arrangements.
Background

Following the significant reorganisation of the Australian Government's administration in 1987 a task force was established under the chairmanship of Mr Charles Halton, to report on advisory arrangements for employment, education, training and research matters.

The outcome of this review and the subsequent intensive consultations is the formation of a National Board of Employment, Education and Training supported by four Councils. The key features of this arrangement are that it provides for independent advice to Government, provides for specialist advice in four vital areas-schools, higher education, employment and skills formation and research, ensures that advice forthcoming will be co-ordinated, and provides a mechanism through which Board and Council members can bring the benefit of their expertise to assist the Department of Employment, Education and Training to administer its policies and programs.

The new arrangements reflect the Government's determination to complement its commitment to restructure the Australian economy by revitalising education and training policies and programs to develop a highly adaptable and skilled work force. Equality of opportunity and the fulfilment of broad social goals are integral to this strategy. Effective and timely advice to Government are essential ingredients to ensure that these objectives are realised in the most effective way available.

The work program for the Board will be a mix of formal references from the Minister and matters initiated by the Board itself within its area of responsibilities. The Councils will advise the Board on matters in their respective specialist fields. The work programs for the Councils will be based on formal references from the Minister and the Board. Councils may also initiate activities through the Board and through the Minister.

The Government's intention is to make the reports of the Board and its Councils generally available for public scrutiny. Reports requested by the Minister, together with the annual report, must be tabled before Parliament. In addition, Councils can invite public comment or submissions on matters referred to them by the Board or Minister. The Councils may also consult with persons or authorities as considered necessary and prepare draft papers and reports for external comment.

There has been extensive consultation with a wide variety of interest groups about possible nominees to serve on the Board and its Councils when established. Many groups consider they should be individually represented. Apart from the practical impossibility of accommodating all such requests, the Government's objective is to draw membership of the Board and its Councils from high calibre individuals who can bring extensive experience and expertise to the work of the Board and Councils. As well, other mechanisms have been provided to permit all interest groups ready access to the Board and its Councils.

An important aspect of the new arrangements is the establishment of a Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee. The functions of this Committee are to inform and advise the Board or its Councils on matters relating to Commonwealth, State and Territory policies and priorities in the fields of employment, education and training and research.
I turn now to the major features of the Bill.
The Functions of the Advisory Structures

The Bill establishes a National Board of Employment, Education and Training whose functions encompass advice on all matters currently within the Employment, Education and Training Ministry. It will inquire into and provide information and advice on matters relating to:
education (other than migrant adult education);
youth affairs;
employment and training; and
national research priorities and the co-ordination of research policy,
as well as matters arising under the legislation within the Employment, Education and Training Ministry.
The scope of the Board's responsibilities in these areas is defined in broad terms. The primary function of the Board is to provide advice and report on matters referred to it by the Minister.
The Board may also initiate inquiries into other matters within its responsibilities and report its findings to the Minister.

Its recommendations will take account of any directions or guidelines from the Minister on the Government's broad social, economic and budgetary priorities. The Minister is required to table in both Houses of Parliament a copy of such directions or guidelines provided to the Board as soon as practicable. The Board also is given power to do all things necessary for the performance of its functions.
Councils
There will be four Councils reporting to the National Board:
Schools Council
Higher Education Council
Employment and Skills Formation Council
Australian Research Council.

The Schools Council will provide advice and information on any matter relating to schools, and primary and secondary education. The Council will frame its deliberations against such relevant matters as the need for improving primary and secondary educational facilities in Australia and providing increased equality of opportunity in both government and non-government schools.

The Higher Education Council will advise on such matters as the general development of higher education in Australia, priorities and arrangements for the funding of higher education institutions and the overseas marketing of Australian higher education services.

The Employment and Skills Formation Council will cover matters such as technical and further education, employment and skills formation policies, programs and services, and the promotion of effective training throughout business and industry. Provision is made in the Bill for the Minister to establish National, Regional and Local Committees to advise both the Council and the National Director on the operations of the Commonwealth Employment Service. These will be in place of the National Advisory Committee on the Commonwealth Employment Service which is being abolished.

The functions of the Australian Research Council fall into two categories. The Council will provide information and advice to the Board on matters relating to national research priorities or the co-ordination of research policy. However, in respect of the distribution of resources allocated to research schemes referred to the Council by the Minister and the administrative and other costs of these schemes, the Council will make recommendations direct to the Minister. The Bill specifically provides that the Board may not direct or furnish guidelines to the Australian Research Council in respect of recommendations for particular grants of assistance.
Membership of the Board, the Councils and the Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee

Board members are to be appointed by virtue of their individual skills, expertise and relevant experience rather than as representatives of associations, States or Territories or other bodies which have particular interests. The Board will have up to five full-time members and a total membership of no more than 13 members. The Chairperson may be appointed either on a full-time or part-time basis. All members of the Board will be appointed by the Governor-General. Close co-operation between the Board and its Councils will be facilitated by interlocking membership between the Board and the Councils with two of the members of each Council being Board members. One of these will be the Council Chairperson.

The composition of the Board provides for a broad spectrum of interests to be represented. The Bill provides that at least seven members of the Board have expertise in matters relating to education or training, two members have expertise relating to trade unions and two members have expertise relating to business or industry. Appointments to the remaining positions will provide for balanced advice from across interested sectors, including additional members from nominated areas of expertise. Gender and geographical balance will be further considerations.
Membership of Councils will also be determined on the basis of expertise first and sectoral representation second.

There have been suggestions that the consumers and providers of education and training will not be adequately represented on the Board. This will not be so. The Chairpersons of the Schools and the Higher Education Councils and the Australian Research Council are most likely to be drawn from among the Board members possessing specific expertise in education and training. Similarly, the membership of the relevant Councils will largely be drawn from the sectors the Councils represent. Added scope in this regard is also provided for by allowing Council membership to vary in size to a maximum of between nine and eleven members.
Counsellors

In addition, provision has been made for the appointment of up to four Counsellors whose skills will augment the experience and expertise of the Board and its Councils, giving them additional capacity to interact with client organisations in areas of focused interest. Examples of this might be the negotiation of educational profiles with higher education institutions and negotiations with unions and employers in industrial restructuring.

These Counsellors may be part-time members of the Board or of a council. The Bill specifically requires consultation between the Minister and the Chairperson of the Board on appointments of Counsellors, their tasks and the reporting arrangements for each Counsellor.
Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee

This Committee will comprise nine members-the Secretary of the Department of Employment, Education and Training who will chair the Committee, and eight State and Territory ministerial nominees. The Committee will provide an important means of identifying broad State and Territory Government priorities in the field of employment, education, training and research and reflecting those priorities in the Board's deliberations. It will also provide the forum for early resolution of significant Commonwealth/State issues in relevant areas. It is anticipated that there will be a high degree of commonality in the agenda for the Committee and the Board.
Board members will not be members of the Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee to avoid conflicts of interest and to ensure representation of the widest practicable spectrum of views.
Reporting Responsibilities

The Board will be required to provide an annual report to Parliament through the Minister. The report will include information on references from the Minister to the Board and reports prepared by the Board for the Minister during the previous twelve months. It will also include information about advice from the Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee, each of the four Councils, and details of the consultative processes used by the Board and Councils in the formation of their advice.
The Board will also provide periodic reports as required on references from the Minister. These reports will also be tabled in Parliament.

The Bill contains provisions allowing the Board to decide that some or all of a particular report should remain confidential. It is expected that this provision will be used only sparingly, for example, in cases where material would not have been provided to the Board had confidentiality not been guaranteed or where a reference relates to budgetary formulation.
Committees

The Bill enables the Minister to establish, where requested to do so by the Board, various Committees to assist the Board and Councils in their work. Based on the interim structures, it is expected that the Australian Research Council, through the Board, will request to be assisted by four Advisory Committees in:
the Engineering, Earth and Applied Sciences;
the Mathematical, Physical and Chemical Sciences;
the Biomedical, Biological and Veterinary Sciences; and
the Humanities and Social Sciences.

The composition of these Committees may be established by the Minister on the recommendation of the Australian Research Council to the Board and in consultation with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

Reference has already been made to the provision for the establishment of Advisory Committees on the operations of the Commonwealth Employment Service. Arrangements outside of the NBEET structure will be made to assist in the development of specialist advice on topics such as women's issues and Aboriginal employment, education and training matters.

Given the relevance of curriculum development to three of the four Councils and the program nature of the work, curriculum development functions (which were formerly with the Curriculum Development Council operating under the auspices of the Commonwealth Schools Commission) have been transferred to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. A Curriculum Development Centre has been established within the Department to carry out these functions and to provide support to the Board.

The scope of activities undertaken by the Curriculum Development Centre will be enlarged to include developing curricula for use in higher and further education as well as in schools. It is anticipated that the Board will in due course recommend to the Minister that he establish a Curriculum Development Advisory Committee.
Commonwealth Employment Service

The Bill maintains the Government's commitment to a public employment agency by including provisions dealing with the Commonwealth Employment Service. The Bill provides mechanisms whereby advice to the Minister on the functioning of the Commonwealth Employment Service can be given within the broader framework of employment, education and training established by this Government.
Grants for Innovative and Curriculum Projects

The Bill makes provision for the Minister to approve grants for innovative and curriculum projects. An innovative project is one aimed at encouraging diversity or innovation or designed to test new approaches and techniques. A curriculum project could involve research in the development of curricula and educational materials and the publication of those educational materials. The Minister can delegate to the Board Chairperson powers to make grants.
Secretariat

Provision has been made for a small administrative support group, to be provided within the Department to service the Board, Councils and Committees. The Bill provides for the Director of the Secretariat to be appointed by the Secretary of the Department of Employment, Education and Training after consultation with the Chairperson of the Board. It is intended that the responsibility to make appointments to the Secretariat below the level of Director will be delegated to the Director, subject to normal departmental procedures and subject to the Director being required to consult with the Chairperson of the Board as appropriate,

The Director and his staff will function as a link between the Board and the Department, to enable the Department's resources to be marshalled and sources of expertise to be utilised to assist the Board and its Councils in the most constructive way possible.
Program Delivery

All program delivery; some of which was undertaken by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and the Commonwealth Schools Commission, has now been transferred to the Department. As an integral part of the advisory role, the full-time Board members and Counsellors will be involved with the Department in the on-going process of assisting with program implementation through consultation and liaison with individual sectors, organisations and institutions on which programs impact.
Working Relationships between the Board, its Councils, the Secretariat and the Department

An integral part of the proposed new arrangements for the Employment, Education and Training portfolio is the maintenance of a clear distinction between responsibility for program delivery and management on the one hand and, on the other, formal advice on policy and resource allocation issues; and accordingly between the relevant lines of authority. This will provide a strong basis for teamwork and mutual trust within the portfolio.

Under these arrangements the Department will serve as a resource to the Board and Councils, just as to the Minister. The Department will play a major role in ensuring that the Board and Councils have the best possible basis for their advice and in assisting them to make the maximum contribution to the activities of the portfolio generally, including in the delivery of its programs.
Mr President, I seek leave to table the document ``Working Relationships between the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, its Councils and Secretariat, and the Department''.
Financial Impact

There will be resource savings over time resulting from rationalisation of the advisory arrangements. On the basis of the new statutory arrangements coming into operation on 1 July 1988, the net savings to the Commonwealth are estimated to be in the order of $500,000 in 1988-89.

Funding in respect of curriculum and innovative projects will be decided in the Budget context. They are not expected to lead to any additional demands for resources, with the funds becoming available from the relocation of funding for existing programs such as curriculum development. The amount of $2,345,600 was appropriated in 1987-88 for curriculum development by the Commonwealth Schools Commission, and will be available for these purposes.
Consequential Changes
As the Bill incorporates provision for a Commonwealth Employment Service within the Department, it therefore repeals the separate Commonwealth Employment Service Act 1978.

The Bill repeals the Commonwealth Schools Commission Act 1973 and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Act 1977. Consequential amendments as a result of those repeals are included in the Bill.
Conclusion

This opportunity must be taken to thank the former Chairmen and members of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Australian Council for Employment and Training. These people along with the many who served on the various committees have over the years been responsible for many innovations within the training, employment and education fields in dedicated pursuit of the goals reflected in the legislation under which they worked.

While the passing of these institutions is a matter of regret to some, the new arrangements proposed in this Bill will provide a sure foundation for carrying on their work in the changed circumstances of the 1980s.

The Government is determined that the education and training systems will play an active role in responding to the major economic challenges facing Australia. These challenges will make heavy demands on our human intellectual resources and labour force skills.
This Bill by rationalising the advisory structures for employment, education, training and research will make a substantial contribution to that end.

Like other successful economies in the world, Australia must give a high priority to education and skills formation and to improving the quality and flexibility of our education and training, employment and research systems. The Government has already signalled its strong commitment to the objectives of reform in the range of activities of the Employment, Education and Training Ministry. These improved advisory structures will ensure that the advice received by the Government will be timely and relevant, and will assist Australia in increasing its productivity in these years of challenging economic and social reform.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION BENEFIT (INTERIM ARRANGEMENT) BILL 1988DEFENCE (SUPERANNUATION INTERIM ARRANGEMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

SUPERANNUATION BENEFIT (INTERIM ARRANGEMENT) BILL 1988
The propose of this Bill is to provide, under an interim arrangement, lump sum superannuation benefits for:
Commonwealth civilian employees and employees of Commonwealth Authorities and bodies who are eligible employees under the Superannuation Act 1976; and
Commonwealth civilian employees and employees of certain Commonwealth authorities and bodies who have no employer-sponsored superannuation.
The major features of the interim arrangement are that:
it is an interim arrangement;

it provides a benefit for those without any superannuation cover and an additional benefit for those with superannuation cover. Existing superannuation arrangements are not affected by the interim arrangement;
employees do not contribute;
it is an `unfunded' arrangement. Rather than pay contributions on an on-going basis, employers will be required to pay benefits as they fall due; and

the basis for calculation of the benefits simulates the benefits that would have accrued had the employer paid contributions to an invested accumulation fund earning interest. The rate of interest provided for in the calculation of the benefit is the long-term bond rate at the start of each year.

The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's June 1986 national wage case decision made provision for employers and unions to negotiate new and/or additional superannuation agreements costing up to 3 per cent of ordinary time wages.

The Government agreed to a 3 per cent overall superannuation benefit for Commonwealth sector employees generally, with 1.5 per cent commencing on 1 January 1988 and the balance no later than 1 January 1989.
This Bill gives effect to that agreement from 1 January 1988.
For the benefit of honourable senators I highlight some of the major features of the arrangement.

Time constraints and the Government's general review of superannuation precluded finalisation of the longer-term form of the benefits for the 325,000 eligible employees under the Superannuation Act 1976 or the 75,000 Commonwealth sector employees with no superannuation cover. Accordingly, the Bill sets up an interim arrangement which can be operated without the need for a central administrator.

The arrangement is a simple one because the administration of the arrangement, including record-keeping and calculation of the benefit, has been devolved to each employer in respect of its employees. The simplicity of the arrangement and its factual nature have obviated the need for review powers.

Longer-term arrangements for the benefit will be negotiated in 1988. The Government has already announced a comprehensive review of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme later this year. The benefit under the interim arrangement may be subsumed within any revised scheme.
The Bill provides that certain regulations can be made with effect from 1 January 1988.

One such power relates to the inclusion of certain groups of persons in the interim arrangement from 1 January 1988. This power has been provided so that authorities which provide superannuation benefits other than under the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, could choose to cover their employees, particularly employees with no superannuation cover, under the interim arrangement until their separate longer-term arrangements are finalised.

Another power is to exclude certain groups of persons from the interim arrangement with effect from 1 January 1988. This power has been provided so that, where longer-term arrangements with effect from 1 January 1988 are put in place for certain groups of employees initially covered by the interim arrangement, those groups can be excluded from the interim arrangement so that they do not become entitled to double benefits.

The Government recognised that a substantial number of employees in the Commonwealth sector have no superannuation cover. In the main, these workers are at the lower end of the income scale. The Government considered it appropriate to arrange the benefit in a way that would favour these employees. The arrangement provides proportionately higher benefits for lower income earners than for higher income earners. This arrangement is a major step in the provision of superannuation for all Commonwealth employees.
Lump sum benefits are payable on termination of employment with the Commonwealth or an authority that is an approved authority for the purpose of the Superannuation Act 1976.

In accordance with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner's requirements applicable to 3 per cent benefits provided under prescribed agreements or awards made by Commonwealth or State industrial authorities, benefits of $500 or more are required to be preserved in the approved fund of the person's choice until genuine retirement from the work force. Honourable Members will note that this Bill refers to, or uses, the provisions of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 in several places.
Where a benefit is less than $500, the benefit can be paid to the individual. The person has the option to roll-over all or part of the benefit to an approved preservation fund.

There is a qualifying period of three months service, or its equivalent in part-time service, for eligibility for the benefit. If employers had to process very small amounts, the costs of doing so could exceed the amount of the benefit. Continuous service prior to 1 January 1988 counts towards this qualifying period but not for benefits. Once eligibility for the benefit is established, the calculation of the benefit takes into account service from 1 January 1988 or the date of commencement of service, whichever is the later.
Finally, I would like to advise honourable senators of the financial implications of the 3 per cent superannuation benefit.

The Bill provides for regulations to specify the basis for calculation of the benefits in 1989 and later years. The rates of employer contribution used in the calculation will result in an overall cost of 3 per cent of salaries for superannuation purposes in those years.

The interim arrangement implies an accruing financial commitment by employers of 1.5 per cent of the salaries for superannuation purposes of the persons covered in the calendar year 1988 and 3 per cent in subsequent years. In 1987-88 prices, this accruing liability would be $130.5 million in 1988 and $271 million in later years.

The benefits under the interim arrangement will not, however, be met by employers paying contributions to a fund or to a central body. Rather each employer will be required to finance only the benefits that become payable. This would be much less than the full accruing cost.

I commend the Bill to the Senate.
DEFENCE (SUPERANNUATION INTERIM ARRANGEMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The purpose of this Bill is to enable the application to members of the Defence Force of the 3 per cent productivity superannuation benefit. This benefit flows on from the June 1986 decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on this subject. Because there are complex superannuation issues involved in the application of the benefit to the Government employment area the final form of the benefit has not yet been decided.

In applying the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decision to the Public Service and to the Defence Force it was found that, because of factors peculiar to the Defence Force, there would need to be differences in matters of detail in the application of the scheme to the Defence Force and the Public Service. These differences include:
There is only one `employer' (if I may use that expression) for the Defence Force as distinct from the many `employers' in the Public Service sector.
The Defence Force scheme does not apply to part time service.
The Defence Force scheme has to have regard to concepts in the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973 which differ from those in the Superannuation Act 1976.
The Defence Force scheme has to have regard to the conditions of service peculiar to the Defence Force.
The Defence Force has a centralised pay system.

As the scheme is an interim one and will shortly be replaced by a permanent scheme, it is proposed to empower the Minister for Defence to determine details of the scheme and to provide that any determinations made by him are to be subject to the usual tabling and disallowance provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

The Bill sets out guidelines that the Minister will be required to have regard to in making a determination. These are: the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the scheme for the Public Service as set out in the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill 1988, the terms and conditions of service of members of the Defence Force and the arrangements for the administration of the Defence Force.
