PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide national legislation for the clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. This is an area of regulation of critical importance to Australia's primary industry, to our international trade in primary products, to the protection of Australia's unique environment and to the safeguarding of the health of all Australians.

The availability of a wide range of agricultural and veterinary chemicals has been one of the more important factors in farm development throughout the world over the past 40 years. They rank with mechanisation of farms, the development of new varieties of plants and breeds of livestock and the improved storage of products as the more significant developments facilitating the bountiful supply of food and fibre we enjoy. The benefits have not been confined to farm production and their use for control of insect vectors of major diseases, such as malaria, or for control of domestic pests are well known.
Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill

These chemicals are however, by their very nature and purpose, biologically active. Misuse can result in unintended effects on plants, animals, non-target species, the users of chemicals, the consumers of plant or animal products or workers involved in their handling, transport or storage. Contaminants of formulated chemical products are cause for concern as is misrepresentation of the potential benefits or impact of chemical use. Consumers of food products are justifiably sensitive to residues of chemicals in food. There are some groups in our community who question the use of artificially formulated chemicals in food production at all. However, as with the motor car and the television set, the benefits of controlled use have more than justified their use.

Honourable senators may be aware that since 1967 the Australian Government and the governments of the States and more recently of the Northern Territory have cooperated voluntarily in an administratively based system for the assessment and clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals prior to their registration for use in the individual States and Territories under separate State and Territory legislation.

The increasing complexity of chemical products and the realities of international trade require that improvements be effected in the regulatory framework governing the clearance and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. To bring about this improvement the Government believes that the most appropriate step is to provide a legislative foundation for natural assessment and clearance of these chemicals. The cooperation of State and Territory governments has enabled this approach to be adopted.

A legislative approach has been recommended by the Australian Agricultural Council. The legislation I have introduced is based on the detailed considerations of a working party of that Council and on earlier recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy announced in October 1986 that legislation dealing with these chemical products would be developed and since that announcement the States, Territories, industry and consumer groups have been consulted on its development.
The Government has four basic objectives in developing this legislation:
(i) to ensure that agricultural and veterinary chemical products perform as intended,
(ii) to minimise any possible hazard to the public, the environment, users or to agricultural produce and livestock from the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals,
(iii) to enhance the export market potential of our agricultural products, and
(iv) to enhance the uniformity of assessment and registration of these products within Australia.

The legislation will provide the basis of the clearance process which ensures that efficacy, toxicity and environmental impact are fully evaluated, to ensure that claims are made by manufacturers can be substantiated and that there are no unintended side effects from the use of agricultural and veterinary chemical products. Some newly developed chemicals are quite complex and designed to be specific in their action while others may have a broad spectrum of use. Assessment of chemicals already in use is ongoing and it is appropriate that the clearance authority have access to the results of such assessments.

The Government has a clear role through the clearance system to ensure that chemical products perform as claimed, and do not jeopardise the quality, or indeed the very production of crops and livestock. The clearance process ensures that agricultural and veterinary chemicals approved for use within Australia perform in the manner intended, producing the expected performance when used according to recommendations.

Of equal importance is the assessment of the potentially damaging effects of misuse of chemical products. A product which is perfectly safe at the correct dosage may be dangerous to the user or to plants or animals at a higher dosage. A product which works well on one crop may, if used on another crop, reduce the crop value to zero. The chemical user must be provided with practical information on the potential problems associated with use of these products outside the recommended parameters.

Honourable senators will be well aware of the importance our major primary produce export markets place on purchase of high quality products. It is increasingly important to be able to demonstrate to foreign governments and their marketing agencies and to international corporations that Australia has coherent national standards for clearance of chemicals and control of undesirable residues. The Government believes that this legislation will further strengthen the international standing of Australia's clearance and registration processes, thereby enhancing the export market potential of our agricultural products. Corresponding benefits can also be expected in the domestic market, where the Commonwealth has a strong interest but for which the States have prime responsibility.

Australia has taken a lead role in the development of international standards for the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals through the Codex Alimentaris Commission, sponsored by the World Health Organisation and the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. While international harmonisation will take many years to achieve, Australia will be in a better position with appropriate national legislation and a national clearance system.

While there has been a high degree of cooperation between State and Commonwealth agencies in the clearance of new chemicals, for a small country such as Australia, the only cost effective way to assess these products is on a nationwide basis.

This legislation will clarify the obligations and responsibilities of both individual proponents of new chemicals requiring clearance of their products and public officers evaluating applications for grants of clearance. Present processes for clearance and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals have evolved over many years. They now need to be clearly defined in federal legislation for the benefit of manufacturers, users, our overseas trading partners, domestic consumers and specific interest groups.

It is important to note that the regulation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals described in the Bill is similar to that in other countries comparable to Australia, including those who share a federal system of government such as Canada and the USA.

The legislation and supporting agreements with the States and Territories will enhance the uniformity of agricultural and veterinary chemical assessment within Australia. As might be expected, the present system with seven separate State and Territory registration authorities, has been required to cope with sometimes marked divergence in State requirements. Honourable senators may care to reflect on the difficulties of negotiating a path through the some 120 separate pieces of State and Territory legislation controlling the registration, sale and use of agricultural and veterinary chemical products in Australia. The inevitable result has been a lengthy and costly assessment process. In particular, chemical product manufacturers have been required to make separate applications to both the appropriate national coordinating secretariat and to State and Territory agencies to acquire all necessary approvals prior to marketing a product. The Government believes that a significantly more efficient system will result from a cooperative `one stop shop' for clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Enhanced uniformity, in tandem with the streamlined processing system minimising the instances of multiple submissions for approval will reduce both the cost in, and elapsed time of, the assessment and clearance process.

To achieve these objectives the Bill provides for the establishment of an Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council. The Council will be responsible for coordinating the evaluation of chemicals proposed for registration in Australia, involving assessments of toxicology, human safety, environmental hazard and efficacy of manufacturers claims, and will grant certificates of clearance for those chemicals, the safety and effectiveness of which it is satisfied.

To support the legislation, the Commonwealth proposes to enter into agreements with individual State and Territory governments along the lines of the draft agreement attached as a schedule to the Bill. For the Commonwealth's part, the essence of these agreements will be satisfied by the passage of this legislation and the implementation of an effective and efficient clearance system. Governments of the States and the Northern Territory are being asked to amend their laws to allow the automatic registration of cleared chemicals in participating States or Territories in all but exceptional circumstances. States and Territories represented at Australian Agricultural Council have agreed in principle with this approach. They will also continue to exercise control over the final registration process and maintain the responsibility for control and monitoring of the sale and actual use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals within their jurisdiction. I re-emphasise the cooperative nature of this venture between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories.

The functions of the Council are detailed in part II of the Bill. These functions include the issuance, variation or withdrawal of clearances for the registration of agricultural and veterinary chemical products in Australia, the evaluation of the effects of the use of these products and the development of codes of practice, standards and guidelines for their use. Council is empowered to collect, interpret, disseminate and publish information relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their use and may advise the Minister on any matter relating to them.

All common agricultural and veterinary chemicals will fall within the scope of the Act including products for the control of insects, fungi, weeds, algae, bacteria, rodents, animal parasites and a wide variety of other agricultural pests. Also covered will be products promoting growth or affecting the reproductive cycle of animals. The legislation does not, however, aim to cover such products as fertilisers, non-medicated animal feeds or individual preparations prepared by veterinary surgeons.

Aside from particular circumstances, to be defined in detail in the agreement with States and Territories, all new agricultural and veterinary chemicals must be cleared by the Council before they will be registered by State authorities. The same process will be required for variations in the use of already cleared and registered products although this requirement, which is now undertaken fully in each State and Territory, may require phased introduction. Council will be empowered to develop a `fast track' system for minor changes. Council will only issue certificates of clearance when it is satisfied that all necessary information has been placed before it, that the product is effective for its stated uses, poses no threat to persons using it or products containing its residues and that the product will have no unintended effects on animals, plants or any other objects.

Chemicals presently in the marketplace will be treated as if cleared by the new system under conditions applying to their present State or Territory registration. Any requirement for change in their use or new information concerning their impact or efficiency will trigger Council consideration of such chemicals.

Applicants for certificates of clearance will be required to provide full and factual information to Council for the purposes of its assessments and to inform Council of any change to information supplied subsequent to clearance of a product being granted. Failure to comply will result in the possible application of penalties.

The Council is to comprise up to twelve part time members appointed by the Minister. The Chairperson, to be nominated by the Minister, is expected to be a senior officer of the Minister's Department. Each participating State or Territory, i.e. each State or Territory entering into an agreement with the Commonwealth, shall have the right to nominate a Council member. One member will represent both the Australian Environment Council and the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers. The remaining two members will represent the National Health and Medical Research Council and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. All organisations represented in Council are participating parties in the clearance process.

Appointments made by the Minister will be for periods up to three years, but members will be eligible for reappointment on the expiration of their appointments. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will be writing to the appropriate Ministers as soon as possible to finalise the composition of the first Council.

In undertaking its functions the Council will be administratively supported by the Department and the Bill makes specific provision for an officer within the Department, to be known as the Chemicals Coordinator, to undertake the duties of Executive Officer to the Council. The present critical roles played by the National Health and Medical Research Council and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission in the evaluation and assessment of chemicals will continue undiminished, these bodies working closely and cooperatively with the new Council.

The Council will delegate powers to the Chemicals Coordinator or to expert committees to facilitate expeditious clearance of products, especially where minor changes to chemicals clearance or to labels on chemical products are required. The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council also will have the power to establish one, or a number, of expert committees to assist and facilitate its operations. I expect consultative committees with industry, consumer and environmental groups now operating under the Australian Agricultural Council sub-committee system to be re-established under this council.

The legislation provides for fees to be levied in respect of the effort necessary to process applications. It is the Government's intention that Council operate at a cost recovery level of fifty per cent. As a corollary to the charging of fees the Government recognises that every effort must be made to reduce the elapsed time taken to process applications. The cost of additional administrative support necessary to meet Council requirements is estimated at $600,000 over the first three years of operation. This figure includes additional staff together with the costs of fares and travel allowances for members of Council. These additional resource requirements are presently being progressed through the normal budget processes. Consistent with the cooperative nature of this scheme the Department will be discussing with State and Territory departments the secondment of State and Territory officers on a rotational basis to the central secretariat.
Some other administrative aspects of the Bill are also worthy of specific mention.

First, applicants for, or holders of, clearance certificates will have the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against decisions of the Council to reject applications for clearance, to impose conditions on clearance or to withdraw clearance for a chemical product. Users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals, and other persons with a direct interest in their use and safety, will also be able to raise technical evidence which disputes the manufacturers or distributors recommendations or claims direct with the Council under the legislation.

Second, the Council is accountable to Parliament through the requirement to report on an annual basis to the Minister and for the Minister to table such reports. These reports will also be made available to State and Territory Ministers for the purpose of tabling in the State legislatures.

Confidentiality of information will be enforced sensibly to protect sensitive commercial data. The definition of information deemed to be confidential is based on relevant provisions in the Freedom of Information Act.

Finally, the Government expects further rationalisation in the regulation of primary and supporting industries during the next three to five years. This House has recently moved to establish a Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, the terms of reference of which include review of the adequacy of this legislation I have now brought forward. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will be writing to the incoming Chairperson of that Select Committee when it is established asking that attention be given in particular to industry concerns about proprietary rights to the data packages prepared and submitted with applications for clearance, confidentiality of data and the time taken to assess applications and also community concerns on right of access to data and adequate right of appeal on decisions under the legislation. A five year sunset clause has also been included within this legislation, thereby ensuring a comprehensive reconsideration of the processes of clearance and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals by 1992-93.

Honourable senators, this Bill also provides another strong plank in the Government's platform to ensure that a significant environmental issue confronting society is managed effectively and safely. Chemicals in the environment do not generate the hype of some other environmental issues but the efficiency and accountability of the provisions contained in this Bill show that the Government is not ignoring this important issue.
Honourable senators, I believe that this Bill represents a highly appropriate step in the rationalisation of an extremely complex regulatory area.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988
Introduction
The Industrial Relations Bill 1988 represents the most substantial revision of Australia's federal industrial relations system undertaken since the system was established in 1904.
It originates from the Hancock Committee of Review into Australia's Industrial Relations Law and Systems which the Hawke Labor Government established soon after we came to office.
On receipt of the Committee's report, the Government instituted an extensive series of consultations with the major parties, each of which was broadly supportive of the report.

The Industrial Relations Bill 1987, which came before the other place in May last year, but which subsequently lapsed, reflected a wide measure of agreement between the parties and the Government as to the changes that should be made. There were, however, some important areas of non-agreement, and that continues to be the case.

The Industrial Relations Bill 1988 is very similar to the 1987 Bill albeit with a few major changes and a number of minor amendments. I will later spell out the important differences in this Bill together with the circumstances in which the 1987 Bill was withdrawn.
The Government regards this Bill as a very important element in the process of industrial relations reform that has been instituted since the Hawke Government came to office in 1983.
That reform process has placed great emphasis on consultation rather than confrontation and has resulted in spectacular improvements in industrial relations outcomes.

Its principal mechanism has been the accord between the Government and the trade union movement. The cooperative spirit developed by the accord has been the genesis for a reduction in the level of time lost in industrial disputes to less than half the level that prevailed under the previous Government.
The wages outcome also has been dramatically reduced, with the average annual level of increase in nominal earnings being about half the level that prevailed during the Fraser years.

The ability of the wages system to adjust to the acute economic difficulties created by the terms of trade collapse in May 1984, without resort to severe recessionary policies to induce that outcome, has been a major success story of the Hawke Government's period of office.

More importantly perhaps than either of these changes has been the attitudinal change of the parties. Although there are some spectacular exceptions on both sides, there is now, in general, a much more constructive, cooperative attitude by the parties than previously prevailed.
Industrial Relations Legislation

By and large, unions have recognised their need to be economically responsible; they have agreed to real wage declines, have accepted the need to develop participative, competitive enterprises, and therefore to increase productivity; they have agreed they have a positive role to play in that regard, and have accepted a wage system which, for the first time in our history, gives positive impetus to productivity improvement.
These are very encouraging developments indeed and give real hope for long-term improvement in our industrial and economic outcomes.
They have certainly provided a basis for cooperation between the parties at the national, industry and enterprise level that would have been unimaginable a few years ago.

In the near future they seem certain to result in a highly desirable process of award restructuring and enhanced skill formation processes in many industries. As a consequence, we should develop, over the next few years, a more skilled, flexible and productive work force thus improving competitiveness, economic growth and our capacity to improve living standards.
At the national level there have been a number of major agreements by the parties which are indicative of the extraordinary attitudinal change.

The joint statement by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) and the Business Council of Australia in September 1986 on restrictive work practices was a major recognition by the parties, and the unions in particular, of the need to eliminate restrictive work practices to improve productivity and competitiveness. This agreement was the forerunner of the current two-tier wages system which has, in turn, resulted in great progress in this area.

Similarly, the tripartite report on labour market flexibility which was developed by the Government, the ACTU and the CAI through the national labour consultative council demonstrated a remarkable level of consensus in an area which has proved very divisive in many countries. The report strongly supports the need for increased flexibility and emphasises that this can be achieved within a system of conciliation and arbitration.

Most recently the ACTU and the CAI produced a joint statement on participative practices. This statement provides, uniquely in Australia's history, a strong expression of support for increased worker participation in decision making at the enterprise level and an agreed set of principles to govern this development. Most encouragingly, support for this development was set strongly in the context of the need for productivity enhancement.
The statement is hopefully the precursor to a major expansion of worker participation in our enterprises, a process which the Government will be seeking to encourage and assist.
It is therefore a very positive encouraging industrial relations context in which the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 is being introduced. The Bill sits well with these developments.
It is itself very largely agreed by the major parties, each of which recognises the need for the legislative framework which covers the system to be thoroughly overhauled and modernised.
The Bill will consolidate the major achievements of the past few years and provide a firm basis on which the progress of the recent past can be continued in the years ahead.
Key Elements

I turn now to the Bill itself. Full details of the Bill are provided in the explanatory memorandum. Here I propose to mention its most significant features, including key areas where there have been changes from the earlier version.

Although the legislation introduces sweeping changes in many of the most important areas of operation of our Federal industrial relations system, it retains the system of conciliation and arbitration as the means by which Australia's industrial relationships are regulated.

Retention of the model of conciliation and arbitration is favoured not only by this Government but also by the major parties in the system. The Government does so because it recognises the immense social and industrial benefits which have stemmed from our system. Historically these arrangements have meant that all workers, whatever their industrial bargaining power, have enjoyed minimum standards of award entitlements which are protected by law. Protection of workers through the award system is one of the real achievements of the conciliation and arbitration machinery. Indeed, by the operation of this system we have, to a far greater extent than most other comparable industrialised countries, been able to prevent exploitation of the industrially weak.

Further, the existing conciliation and arbitration framework has provided the opportunity for the development and delivery of a responsible national wages policy which has been utilised so effectively by this Government over the past five years.

Both the constitutional constraints imposed on the Commonwealth at Federation and the need for consistency of operation between the Federal body and the State industrial relations tribunals, which work in parallel with the Federal system, are additional reasons why continuation of our conciliation and arbitration system is vital.

Since the earlier version of the Bill lapsed last year, there have been some extremely important High Court of Australia decisions which have had significant consequences for our industrial relations legislation and which have allowed modifications to the previously proposed Bill. The Government has continued to consult with the industrial parties about the contents of the Bill. In certain areas the parties have revised their earlier attitudes and have been prepared to see this version of the Bill take additional positive steps towards achieving further progress.

The first of the major changes involves unfair dismissals. In the recent Ranger uranium case the High Court decided that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has the power to hear and determine disputes involving claims concerning alleged unfair dismissals.

This is clearly preferable to the processes involved in taking legal action before a court. It means that such disputes can be dealt with more speedily, more informally and more cheaply. Accordingly, the proposed Industrial Relations Commission will be able to deal with such matters and the express legislative prescription which vested reinstatement powers in the proposed labour court has been omitted from the Bill.

Secondly, it will be remembered that when this Bill was introduced last year in its earlier form, it included a new and comprehensive sanctions package. The package had been developed to provide effective yet equitable measures to ensure that the Commission had complete authority to enforce adherence by the parties within the Federal industrial relations system to standards applying under that system.

The proposed measures would have guaranteed a swift and workable response to deal with industrial misbehaviour. They comprised a new directions and injunction process, non-adherence to which could lead to the imposition of significantly increased monetary penalties or an array of non-monetary penalties.

In view of this marked increase in the effectiveness of the compliance provisions under Federal industrial law, it was considered unnecessary and inappropriate to retain access to injunctive remedies under common law for industrial action. Accordingly, the Bill prevented access to such injunctions, whilst continuing to allow the pursuit of compensatory damages at common law.

The Bill also proposed to transfer the jurisdiction to deal with contraventions by trade unions of sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act 1974 to the proposed labour court without amending the remedies available under that Act. Access to the Trade Practices Act for injunctions or damages for contraventions of sections 45d and 45e was prevented until conciliation of the underlying dispute had been attempted.

The compliance provisions of the previous Bill thus represented a balanced and rational approach. They sought to provide enhanced compliance measures within the Federal industrial legislative code and to restrict, as far as reasonably possible, resort to legal avenues outside that statutory code.

Not to do so was to place unions in a situation of serious double jeopardy. They would be open to large increased penalties under the Industrial Relations Act yet, for the same industrial action, could still be liable for severe penalties under the common law.

Such a situation would have been, in the Government's view, grossly unfair and totally unnecessary. There was simply no need for employers to have access to common law injunctions once the enhanced compliance provisions including injunctions, were contained in Federal industrial law.

Unfortunately, the new compliance measures received a hostile reception from employer groups. Whilst they welcomed the new directions and injunctions process, they adamantly demanded the retention of common law penalties and immediate access to actions under the Trade Practices Act.

The Government considered that the employers' intransigent opposition to these provisions had the capacity to undermine the parties' commitment to, and the public's confidence in, the new industrial relations system. It therefore decided to remove the proposed compliance package from the legislation and to preserve the system which currently exists. Accordingly, this Bill retains the bans clause procedures under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which have been redrafted to make them more easily understood. Monetary penalty levels for award breaches and non-adherence to compliance provisions remain unchanged from those which currently prevail but a number of non-monetary penalties for industrial misconduct contained in the previous Bill have been retained.

The third major change embodied in this Bill is the decision not to proceed with a separate labour court. The High Court's ruling on the Commission's ability to deal with alleged unfair dismissal disputes and the Government's decision not to retain the proposed compliance package diminished the need for such a court. Therefore the Industrial Division of the Federal Court will continue to deal with appropriate matters.
The remaining two changes of substance in this Bill involve the registration and amalgamation of organisations.
It is widely accepted that Australia has too many trade unions.

Small, craft-based unions cannot effectively represent the interests of their members due to their limited human and financial resources. Further, as employers and employees work together to pursue the mandatory changes which are necessary to make their industry or enterprise as productive as possible, small unions can often be seen as an inhibiting factor to change.

Accordingly, to address these problems this Bill provides for speedier amalgamations. In addition to the less onerous voting requirements proposed in the previous Bill, this legislation now reduces the opportunities for objections to amalgamations. Where the Commission determines that an amalgamation will not involve any extension in the overall coverage of participating unions, the current objection procedures will not apply.

Whilst there has been considerable activity amongst the larger unions to achieve union restructuring through amalgamations, the smaller unions have lagged behind in their endeavours to seek suitable partners for amalgamation purposes. Accordingly, the Government has decided to increase the minimum number of members required for registration purposes to ensure sufficient encouragement for smaller unions to actively pursue amalgamation.

Unions will now be required, except in special cases, to have 3,000 members before they can be registered. At present the threshold is 100 members, whilst the previous Bill provided for 1,000 members. Currently there are almost half of the 148 federally registered unions with memberships of less than 3,000. Yet the membership of these unions constitutes only 2.9 per cent of the total membership of all federally registered unions.

To maintain the appropriate encouragement for amalgamations, the continued registration of a union with less than the minimum number will be reviewed after a period of three years, not five years as previously proposed. The designated presidential member will then decide if the union's registration should be cancelled.

There are also a number of other more minor changes which have been made to the legislation to improve the drafting or to reflect further consideration by the Government and the parties themselves of certain provisions in the Bill.
Other Key Features
I turn now to deal with the key initiatives which were contained in the previous Bill and which are retained in this legislation.
Institutional Framework and Jurisdiction

The Bill provides for the establishment of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It will replace the existing Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The change in title, which was recommended by the Hancock Committee of Review into the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, reflects the expanded activities of the new Commission and places less emphasis on a pro-active determinative role.

The Office of the Industrial Registrar is to be established as a statutory authority. However, the power to register organisations or amend eligibility rules will now be decided by a deputy president of the Commission.

The Bill also affords a general rationalisation of existing specialist Federal industrial tribunals and the special jurisdictions under the existing Conciliation and Arbitration Act, all of which it incorporates into the mainstream jurisdiction. The Academic Salaries Tribunal, the Flight Crew Officers Industrial Tribunal and the present arrangements concerning the Australian Federal Police will therefore be abolished. There will no longer be a separate division of the Act to cover Commonwealth and Territory employees. They will be dealt with within the general powers and functions of the division.

In relation to the Coal Industry Tribunal, since its powers and functions are governed by both Federal and New South Wales State legislation, under an agreement between the two governments, all changes require the concurrence of the New South Wales Government. In view of the poor industrial relations performance of the coal industry, the Government believes that there is a strong case for change in, if not the complete abolition of, the Coal Industry Tribunal.

The previous New South Wales Government did not favour any major changes to the Coal Industry Tribunal's operations. However, with the change in government in New South Wales, the Minister for Industrial Relations has written to his New South Wales counterpart seeking the New South Wales Government's view on the future of the Coal Industry Tribunal and to what changes the State Government would be prepared to agree.

For its part, the Government believes that the rationalisation of tribunals should indeed extend to the State tribunals so that we would have a national integrated system of industrial relations. This we believe would be in the best interests of industrial regulation in Australia. Unfortunately, little progress towards this end was made in discussions with the States.
Without the States' agreement or an amendment to the Constitution, the Government is unable to achieve the establishment of a unitary industrial relations system on a national basis.

Nevertheless, the Bill contains specific proposals which are designed to facilitate greater cooperation between the Federal and State industrial tribunals and to promote greater uniformity of treatment of the parties between the systems.

The Bill provides that members of State and Federal tribunals will be able to hold, concurrently, dual commissions which will enable them to exercise both State and Federal powers, once the States have enacted complementary legislation. Further, meetings of the heads of tribunals will be placed on a statutory footing.

The jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will be framed as broadly as possible within the limits of the conciliation and arbitration power, subject only to the requirement that disputes relate to matters concerning employers and employees. It is intended that disputes involving all such matters will be able to come before the Commission-thus removing existing constraints on Commission involvement.

This does not mean, however, that the Commission will be arbitrating or interfering in matters which may be properly regarded as coming within managerial prerogative. Certainly, in its own area of employment, the Commonwealth will vigorously assert its right to exercise appropriate managerial prerogative without Commission interference.

The Commission will have a range of additional powers to strengthen its hand in dealing with disputes. Whilst the Commission will still be precluded from dealing with claims for payment covering periods of industrial action, the Commission will be empowered to consider claims for lost time which are justified on the grounds that the employees had a reasonable concern about their health and safety.

The Commission will also have additional obligations. In particular, the Commission will be required to take account of the economic consequences of its decisions in all proceedings, not just Full Bench matters.

There are specific new powers to enable permanent solutions to be found to resolve demarcation disputes. The Bill gives the Commission the discretion to allow the ACTU to attempt to settle a dispute before it exercises its own powers. Where the trade union movement cannot effect a timely resolution of the dispute the Commission will be able to address both the immediate and the long term issues relating to the demarcation of specific work. It will be able to make orders as to coverage and to change union rules to give effect to its decisions, thereby ensuring lasting relief.
There is a greater emphasis on the resolution of disputes on the shop-floor.

The conciliation and arbitration power does not allow the Government to require the Commission to insert grievance procedures in all awards. But where such procedures exist in the workplace for resolving differences between parties, it is imperative that they be followed. To this end, the Commission is required to take into account the extent to which grievance procedures have been followed by the parties when deciding whether it will deal with a dispute.

This will encourage employers and employees to seek the insertion of grievance procedures in their awards and to use those procedures. Model grievance procedures will be further developed through the National Labour Consultative Council to enable national union and employer organisations to encourage their members to adopt a uniform standard for inclusion in all awards. Many awards have already been varied to incorporate grievance procedures arising from negotiations under the second tier arrangements.
Certified Agreements

In order to allow the greatest possible flexibility, yet avoid the undesirable outcomes of a totally decentralised system, the Bill provides for both the currently available consent awards and for fixed-term, non-variable binding agreements which will be certified by the Commission.

Such agreements differ from the current consent award provisions in that they will have a specified life, after which they will lapse, and will not be able to be varied during that period, except in special and compelling circumstances.

Most importantly, the settlements embodied in such agreements may provide for outcomes which differ somewhat from those generally prevailing under the wages system, provided a Full Bench of the Commission is satisfied that to certify such terms in the agreement would not be contrary to the public interest.

Accordingly, where a Full Bench of the Commission considers that an agreement is in the mutual best interests of the parties themselves and that its certification would not undermine the prevailing wage fixation principles or threaten the orderly operation of the wages system or other aspects of the industrial relations system, it is required to certify the agreement.
Through such agreements, there is considerable scope for the development of arrangements designed to reflect the particular requirements of an individual employer or enterprise.

The agreements will provide individual employers guaranteed certainty in relation to the labour costs which will apply during the period of the agreement and will enable them to take appropriate management decisions in the knowledge of such predetermined stable costs. Clearly such arrangements have considerable potential for enhancing workplace productivity.

In the event that a party takes industrial action in relation to a matter embodied in the agreement, the other party will be permitted, upon the Commission's approval, to treat the agreement as terminated.

Action to secure compliance, short of terminating the agreement, will also be available through access to a bans clause. Similarly an employer will be able to apply for the insertion of a stand-down clause covering employees who cannot perform their work due to external circumstances.

The Bill also recognises the capacity of the parties to provide their own measures for securing compliance in certified agreements, for example, by providing for the suspension or termination of rights or obligations in specified circumstances. Where such measures are contained in an agreement, it will be possible to provide expressly for the exclusion or limiting of the Commission's powers to include a bans clause or a stand-down provision in the agreement.
Where all parties consent and the Commission declares that it is in the public interest, it will be possible for the agreement to be terminated.

There is provision in the legislation for the Minister to intervene in the public interest to seek to have the Commission review the operation of a certified agreement if the Minister considers such a review is warranted.
Further, the Bill prevents any flow-on to other awards of the terms contained in a certified agreement.

As all such agreements will require Commission certification before they take effect, the Commission will be able to ensure that they do not prejudice its wages system. Nevertheless certified agreements will still provide a substantial measure of flexibility currently lacking under present legislative provisions.
Organisations

In addition to the initiatives which I have already outlined in relation to the registration and amalgamation of unions, the Bill also incorporates the same voting requirements for amalgamation purposes which were introduced in the previous version.

Thus, where unions satisfy the `community of interest' test, a simple majority of votes cast in favour will approve the amalgamation. Where no `community of interest' criterion applies, at least a quarter of eligible members of the organisations will be required to vote with a simple majority of these votes being necessary to approve the amalgamation.

Special transitional arrangements will also be provided for existing office-holders in the amalgamating organisations. The Government recognises that legislative changes by themselves will not necessarily overcome all impediments to restructuring unions. The Minister for Industrial Relations is exploring possible arrangements for financial assistance on a needs basis to be made available to assist amalgamating organisations.

The future registration of unions will again, in this Bill, be restricted to associations which are industry-based, thus precluding the future registration of craft or occupationally-based associations, except in special circumstances.
These measures relating to registration requirements and amalgamations will lead to a reduction in the number of small unions and a number of important consequences:
A fall in the incidence of demarcation disputes,
a reduction in the number of unions with which employers are required to negotiate,
a stronger union affinity with the welfare of the industry in which its members work,
more efficient use of trade union resources, and
less resistance to changes which might otherwise have meant workers moving from one union's area of coverage to that of another union.
A reduction in the number of unions will also complement the Government's industrial strategy by facilitating workplace consultation and greater employee participation in decision-making.

The Government recognises that for some enterprises and projects the continued or potential presence of a multiplicity of unions represents a major impediment to higher efficiency and a discouragement to future investment.

Accordingly, in addition to promoting union amalgamations, the Government fully supports moves to rationalise arrangements for union coverage of workers on individual projects and work sites where necessary. The Government believes such rationalisation can be achieved under the provisions of this Industrial Relations Bill. But should any legislative obstacle to this process be identified, the Government will consider appropriate amendments.

Registered trade unions are required to observe a wide range of provisions regulating their affairs. They must meet proper standards of internal administration and satisfy requirements for democratic control.
The legislation contains many initiatives which will enhance the accountability and efficient operations of trade unions.

There is a requirement that all elections for offices in organisations are to be officially conducted unless an exemption is granted by the registrar. All elections by a direct voting system for offices, other than for administrative offices, are to be by secret postal ballot except where an exemption is obtained.

The individual rights that are presently contained in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act are preserved by the Bill and in some instances have been enhanced. Thus the legislation includes more comprehensive procedures dealing with records that are to be kept by organisations and provides new measures to give further access to such records by their members. Provisions are included requiring organisations to issue a statement to a member about that person's membership and financial status. In addition the rights of a member to resign from an organisation are clarified in the legislation.

The protection of non-members' rights is also strengthened. The tests to be applied for purposes of seeking a conscientious objection certificate have been eased and clarified. In addition the provision will now apply for purposes of individuals' membership of employer organisations as well as for employee organisations. The court's powers in relation to offences connected with conscientious objectors are to be extended to include the power to reinstate.

Members' rights to participate actively in the affairs of their organisation are protected. They are entitled to challenge rules, to seek their enforcement, to initiate election inquiries and to seek a secret ballot on strike action.

The scope of the current provisions protecting persons from discriminatory or industrial action has been broadened, in particular, to cover prospective employees. Likewise the provisions designed to protect independent contractors have been extended to apply to actions by an organisation to coerce an independent contractor to join that or any other organisation.
Sanctions
As I have already advised the Senate, the Government has decided not to proceed with its previous sanctions package, but instead is retaining the existing system of compliance.

The Commission will still be able to conciliate in relation to secondary boycott disputes. It is also made clear that State legislation which is inconsistent with Federal law is overridden to the extent of the inconsistency. Hence, certain Federal remedies in relation to conduct by unions are, in specified circumstances, exclusive of remedies under state or territory legislation.

The Trade Practices Act remedies for breaches of sections 45d and 45e will be exclusive of inconsistent State or Territory legislation in respect of both Federal and State registered organisations and no State or Territory legislation will apply to Federal unions in breach of a bans clause or orders relating to industrial action in the Federal public sector. However, these exemptions do not apply to breaches of criminal law or where a union is breaching an award or order of a state industrial tribunal.

Penalty levels provided for offences against provisions of the new Bill have been rationalised, as the levels under the previous Act were set in an ad hoc manner over many years and lacked internal consistency. In most cases under the bill the penalty for an individual is set at $500 while a body corporate or an organisation committing the same offence will incur a penalty of $1,000. Daily or weekly penalties are provided for offences of a continuing nature.

Finally, I wish to advise the Senate that the Government proposes to address a genuine area of concern regarding allegations of corrupt practices by or involving officers of federally registered unions. Whilst there are only rare incidences of such allegations, they have been mentioned in the reports of the Sweeney Royal Commission into Alleged Payments to Maritime Unions, the Winneke Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.
Criminal behaviour by union officials and employers is totally unacceptable and in complete breach of the spirit of the orderly operation of the federal industrial relations system.

Accordingly, the Government intends later this year to amend the Crimes Act 1914 to provide for an anti-corruption provision which makes it an offence for an officer or employee of a union to corruptly misuse his position within the union to seek or to obtain a benefit for himself or someone else on the understanding that such benefit will influence him. Similarly an employer who dishonestly offers or gives such an official any benefit in order to influence that union official will also be guilty of an offence.
Conclusion
This Bill will consolidate the Government's achievements in the industrial relations arena and positively contribute towards the creation of a more productive Australian society.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988
The Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988 has three main purposes.

The first is to repeal the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 which will be superseded by the Industrial Relations Bill 1988. As a result of the repeal of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, a number of other Acts will require amendment.

The second purpose of the Consequential Provisions Bill is therefore to amend these Acts. The consequential amendments made to other Acts are generally of a technical nature and deal primarily with the substitution of references to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act with references to the Industrial Relations Act. Other consequential amendments deal with the repeal of provisions of Acts which will become redundant on the enactment of the Industrial Relations Bill.

The third purpose of the Consequential Provisions Bill is to ensure that the transition from the system established under the previous Act to the system established by the Industrial Relations Bill is as smooth as possible. Most of the provisions contained in this Bill are designed to bring that about. For example, provision is made for the transfer of part-heard proceedings before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to the new Industrial Relations Commission on the commencement of the new Act. Registration obtained by organisations under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act will be maintained for purposes of the new Bill as will current awards and orders of the present Commission.

The repeal of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act will not result in any disadvantage to parties in the Federal system. Two general provisions are included in this Bill to deal with any difficulties which might arise as a result of the transition from the previous system to the new regime. The President of the Industrial Relations Commission is to have the power to give directions and the Federal Court is to be able to make orders to resolve any problems which occur as a result of the transition.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1988CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
Customs Tariff Legislation
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1988
The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1988, which is now before the Senate, contains a wide variety of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987.
Schedule 1 to the Bill, operative on and from 1 January 1988, contains a number of amendments.
The first set of amendments relate to revised charging arrangements for general aviation aircraft at Essendon, Coolangatta and Launceston airports.
Aircraft using aviation gasoline-Avgas-will now no longer be subject to terminal navigation, rescue and fire fighting charges for landings at these airports.
The revenue forgone as a result of this change will be offset by a half a cent per litre increase in the excise and customs duty on aviation gasoline.

These revised arrangements were introduced after consultation with the aviation industry had revealed that, under the previous charging arrangements which came into effect last July, general aviation avgas operators who used the three airports were disadvantaged compared with their competitors operating at the general aviation capital city secondary airports.
The extent of the disparity was not foreseen by either the industry or the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce at the time the changes were made last July.

The changes relating to customs duties on certain petroleum products are also included in this schedule and ensure that the rates became operative on and from 14 December 1987 are carried over to the principal Act.

The next set of amendments relate to the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries, medical and scientific equipment and glass and glassware.

The Government decided to accept the recommendations contained within the Commission's report on the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries that tariffs assisting these industries be reduced over a two-year period on a `tops down' basis to a maximum of 15 per cent. Tariffs are generally 20 to 25 per cent, but many are at 10 per cent and below. All phasing of rates would commence from 1 January 1988. Some tariff anomalies will be corrected and concessional entry allowed on coated paper and on some other types of paper not produced locally. Tariff assistance for paper-making machinery will be reduced to minimum rates.

Policy by-laws have been implemented to allow for paperboard used in cigarette packages and aseptic liquid containers to enter at minimum rates and for paperbacked textile wall coverings to enter at 15 per cent, the same rate as `paper' wallpaper. The Government rejected some of the Commission's recommendations and will not reintroduce the bounty on certain types of paper which expired last February. The pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries constitute a large and diverse sector of the Australian economy. These industries have specific areas with potential of developing into internationally competitive and technologically developed sectors of the economy.

In its decision on the medical and scientific equipment industry the Government has accepted the thrust of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations for reduced tariff assistance. Tariffs will be phased down progressively over two years commencing on 1 January 1988 with the general rate of 15 per cent being reached on 1 January 1990. The bulk of imports will continue to enter at minimum rates.

Following the receipt of the Industries Assistance Commission's report on glass and glassware the Government decided to adopt, with a few exceptions, an industry-wide tariff rate of 15 per cent for the glass and glassware industry. Tariffs above 15 per cent are to be reduced on a `Tops Down' basis over three years to reach 15 per cent on 1 January 1991.

The Government was of the opinion that the decision would minimise tariff-induced distortions in trade and investment decisions thereby improving the international competitiveness of Australian industry. The Government also decided not to grant any short term assistance to users of glass fibre rovings who were required to pay higher prices for imports at a time of tight domestic supply.
Amendments to implement certain changes in accordance with Australia's international trade agreements obligations are included.
A series of amendments made in the context of the current textiles, clothing and footwear sectoral policy are also included. These cover-
variations to the developing country exclusions from preference which are made annually;
the insertion of the 1988 tender quota rates of duty following the settlement of the relevant premium tender quota rates;
the extension of the validity of the 1987 quota allocations; and
an increase in the customs value criterion which determines whether footwear is subject to tariff quota from $1.35 to $1.45.

This schedule includes amendments to redress assistance anomalies which have become apparent following publication of the harmonised tariff. Six anomalies have been brought to notice which would have unacceptable consequences for the industries concerned.
These, and the remedial actions proposed, are:
polyethylene terephthalate-duties are reduced from 10 per cent to two per cent when used to make fibres and yarns. The change involves broadening the terms of a customs by-law;
parts for leather coats, jackets, and the like-this amendment ensures these goods continue to be subject to tariff quota;

hand-made rugs-the purpose of this amendment is to continue duty free entry of certain carpets until 30 June 1988. These rugs and carpets are made by powered machines that are held in the hand and were not to be eligible for concessional entry following the Government's review of the textiles, clothing and footwear handicraft arrangements. They were to be subject to the carpet duty rates of 40 per cent general and 30 per cent developing countries from 1 January 1988. However, after representations from importers a review of the decision resulted in a deferral of implementation until 1 July 1988 to ensure that undue hardship does not occur to importers' business operations;
men's or boy's suits-an amendment to ensure that men's and boy's suits that consist of a jacket and a pair of shorts continue to be subject to quota;

adjustable shoulder straps for brassieres-an amendment to correctly exclude these goods from quota and thus maintaining the arrangements that existed prior to the introduction of the harmonised tariff;

paper sheeters, slitters, slitter-rewinders and rewinders-this amendment will restore tariff assistance to local production of paper sheeters, slitters, slitter-rewinders and rewinders. Producers of these goods suffered a substantial loss of tariff assistance on 1 January when the previous import duty of 15 per cent was reduced to minimum rates. When Cabinet approved the introduction of the harmonised tariff it gave authority to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, in consultation with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and other relevant Ministers, to approve modifications on compelling industry grounds, before 1 January 1988. After receiving a submission on behalf of the bulk of the Australian industry and considering the arguments put forward it was concluded that this small industry could suffer serious injury, with consequent job losses, if tariff assistance were not restored. All Ministers consulted agreed that compelling industry grounds existed for restoration of the moderate 15 per cent tariff rate which applied prior to 1 January. Restoration of the Government's intended level of assistance will help to maintain the viability of the industry.
Two further amendments through the restructuring of the tariff, correct existing inconsistencies in tariff drafting. These are-
(a) blinds and fittings and mountings for curtain tracks of polymers of styrene or vinyl chloride were incorrectly classified; and

(b) the tariff structure for therapeutic respiration apparatus could result in an incorrect rate of duty being collected. This change arose from the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's report on medical and scientific equipment.
The final group of amendments includes redrafting of a minor nature.

Schedule two, operative on and from 3 February 1988, provides the basis for fulfilling the Prime Minister's commitment given at the Ruby Hutchison Memorial Address, of 13 March 1987, to limit the indexation increases for August 1987 and February 1988 to a total of around six per cent. The amendments decrease the rates of duty as applying immediately prior to indexation of the February 1988 adjustment date so that when the legislative provisions for indexation are applied (which require the use of the published consumer price index) the resultant indexation increase is 2.5 per cent. This increase, when combined with the August 1987 indexation adjustment (3.5 per cent), yields a total indexation adjustment of six per cent.
Schedule three, which is operative seven days after the royal assent, contains a variety of amendments.

The first set of amendments result from further Government decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on the chemicals and plastics industries, the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries and glass and glassware. The amendments are:
Pigments-

The changes proposed for inorganic pigments will provide significant benefits to industries using these products. The current very complex structure will be substantially simplified. This will ensure that the intent of the Government's decision on the policy for chemicals and plastics is properly realised. It will also assist industry by permitting more accurate and efficient classification of imports of these pigments;
Calendars-

The general tariff rate for calendars of a kind other than paper and paperboard of heading 4910 will be phased from 25 per cent on implementation on 1 January 1988, to 20 per cent from 1 January 1989 and to 15 per cent on 1 January 1990 in line with the phasing arrangements for the general tariff rate for calendars of paper and paperboard. This will avoid the creation of an anomaly in assistance between paper and paperboard calendars and calendars of other materials;
Tampons-

The Government decided to set the general tariff rate for tampons at two per cent. An anomaly previously existed in that tampons entered under tariff item 59.01.000 were dutiable at two per cent whilst, if entered under sub-item 48.21.900, they were dutiable at 25 per cent. This proposal avoids the anomaly.
All goods other than tampons of subheading 5601.10 are to be dutiable at 15 per cent in order to bring subheading 5601.10 into line with the long term industry rate under subheading 4818.40.

Two further amendments to apply the correct rate of customs duty where the drafting of the tariff structure could result in incorrect rates of customs duty being collected. These amendments involve the duties applying to-
Graduated rules and machine and hand scales; and
Certain types of cords, cordage, braids and sleeving of glass,
and arise from the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on medical and scientific equipment and glass and glassware.

Finally this schedule includes an amendment to part II of schedule 4 where the government has decided to admit free of customs duty national or traditional costumes imported by recognised ethnic groups. This will facilitate imports of genuine ethnic items in non-commercial quantities.
Financial Impact
The decision on the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries will result in an estimated decrease in revenue of $1.31m in 1987-88, $9.65m in 1988-89 and $21.79m in 1989-90.

The impact of the decision on medical and scientific equipment is difficult to assess and the duty reductions are likely to stimulate import growth in this already fast growing market. Such growth may completely offset the lower duty rate to be applied.
The decision on glass and glassware will result in an estimated decrease in revenue of $95,000 in 1987-88, $350,000 in 1988-89 and $700,000 in 1989-90.
The decision on the hand-made rugs will result in revenue forgone during the period 1 January 1988 to 30 June 1988 of approximately $90,000.
While it is difficult to estimate the impact in regard to the decision on pigments, it is considered that there will be a small increase in revenue.

Whilst there may be an initial reduction in revenue in regard to the decision on polyethylene terephthalate, this will be offset, at least in part, by the stronger competitive position of the relevant manufacturers.
The other changes in the Bill are expected to have minimal financial impact.
Details of the amendments contained in the Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill.
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, which is now before the Senate, gives effect to part of a package of measures announced by the Government on 13 April 1988 aimed at reinforcing the strategy and objectives of the Government's passenger motor vehicle policy and continuing the process of structural change in the automotive industry.

On 29 May 1984, when the Government announced the current motor vehicle policy, or the plan as it has become more commonly known, it was indicated that special consideration would be given in early 1988 to the state of the industry report for 1987 prepared by the automotive industry authority. The intent was to conduct a mid-term review of the plan to assess progress being made by manufacturers to model rationalisation and the success in achieving greater efficiencies in component production.
That review formed the basis of the changes now being introduced by the Government.
The plan, which was introduced in 1985 and runs through to the end of 1992, aims to:
give the industry time to restructure and modernise;
make it more efficient and internationally focused;
hold down the price of cars; and
reduce job losses in the short-term and provide long-term job stability.
The strategy for pursuing these objectives involves the following integrated elements:
Rationalisation of the assembly industry in terms of models and manufacturing groups;
rationalisation of the components sector to reduce industry fragmentation and costs;
increasing competitive pressure on the industry by gradually reducing barrier protection; and
providing a stable policy framework which will allow adjustment to occur over a period of time with minimum disruption and cost.
The Government believes that the plan has enjoyed substantial success in its first three years.

To increase industry volumes and economies of scale, the Government set the industry a target of reducing, by 1992, the number of models from thirteen to six and the number of manufacturing groups from five to three.

Through industry restructuring and rationalisation of companies and model lines, these objectives are well within reach. The automotive industry authority advises that it expects only eight models will be manufactured by the end of 1989, and following the December 1987 announcement of a joint manufacturing venture between AMI Toyota and Holden's, the number of manufacturing groups has now been reduced to four. Further co-operative manufacturing ventures are likely.

Increased investment activity associated with new product development and upgrading plant and equipment has also been apparent as the industry prepares itself for the post-1992 period. The vehicle sector, for example, has increased its investment from $194m per annum in the period 1982-1984, prior to the introduction of the plan, to $503m per annum in the period 1985-1987.
During the life of the plan we have also witnessed a dramatic increase in automotive exports.

In 1987 automotive exports reached $755m, an increase of 63 per cent over the previous year and almost double the level of exports in 1984. While devaluation has clearly been an important element in this success, the export facilitation arrangements of the plan, together with a much stronger commitment to export by industry management, have also been important.
Nevertheless, in spite of the undoubted successes of the plan so far, the Government recognises that there are changed circumstances which threaten the plan's objectives.
The major unforeseeable change since 1984 has been the fall in the value of the Australian dollar.
This has altered the relative competitiveness of locally produced and imported products to the extent that the competitive pressure now on the domestic industry is well below that envisaged in 1984.
As evidence of the substantial erosion of importers' competitiveness:
The importers' market share is now about 11.4 per cent compared to over 15.5 per cent only two years ago;
1987 and 1988 tender quotas attracted zero premiums; and
Both 1986 and 1987 quota allocations were significantly underutilised.
The depreciation has also had the effect of forcing price increases in the industry at a rate well above those occurring in the economy generally.

In summary, the Government believes that the effects of the depreciation on relative competitiveness threaten to erode the benefits of industry rationalisation achieved to date, and by reducing competitive pressure on the industry, significantly blunt the effectiveness of a major element of the plan strategy. They have also seriously hindered progress towards the plan objective of lower real prices.

Accordingly, following advice from the Automotive Industry Authority and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, and after consultation with the industry and its unions, the Government has introduced changes considered necessary to ensure the plan remains an effective mechanism for transforming the industry into a competitive force in the 1990s.
This Bill gives effect to the following changes being made to the tariff elements of the plan.

The abolition of tariff quotas, and the reduction of the 57.5 per cent tariff on completely built-up (CBU) motor vehicles to 45 per cent with effect from 13 April 1988. From 1 January 1989 there will be further annual reductions leading to an end-rate of 35 per cent in 1992. Completely knocked down (CKD) packs and certain original equipment components will also now attract the CBU tariff rates.

To retain competitive relativities, the tariff rates applying to CBU light commercial vehicles and those CBU four-wheel drive vehicles (including amphibious vehicles) not classified as passenger substitutes are to be reduced from 35 per cent and 25 per cent respectively to 20 per cent for the remainder of this year. This rate will be phased down in annual reductions to an end-rate of 15 per cent in 1992.
The tariffs on CKD light commercial vehicles and CKD four-wheel drive vehicles (including amphibious vehicles) now become 10 per cent.
Margins of preference applying to goods of developing country, Canadian and forum island country origin remain unchanged, and goods of Papua New Guinea origin remain free of duty.

Tariffs on goods of New Zealand origin will be subject to the lower of the current rate or the rate applicable to Canadian goods. Discussions are, however, now under way between Australian and New Zealand officials in the context of the Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations-Trade Agreement.

Other elements of the Government's decision which are not covered by this Bill, but which are an integral part of the overall package of changes, involve certain amendments to the local content and export facilitation arrangements of the plan. Administrative action to give effect to these changes is occurring and does not require legislation.

Briefly, the changes to the local content scheme involve the introduction of a simpler and less stringent system of penalties for non-achievement of the 85 per cent local content target. Beginning in 1989, the penalty will be the same as the duty rate applying to CBU passenger motor vehicles. This change will provide considerable additional flexibility to the vehicle manufacturers in their sourcing arrangements and, as such, increase competitive pressure on the components sector. The currency devaluation, through the local content scheme, has provided an unhealthy degree of protection to domestic component suppliers.

In relation to export facilitation, each of the three schemes in operation has been extended in slightly different ways to ensure that they continue to play a significant role in promoting rationalisation and helping the industry gain a foothold in major export markets. They are an important adjunct to the other mechanisms of the plan and the Government wants to ensure that the momentum they have created is not lost.

In conclusion, the changes outlined in this Bill form part of a package of measures introduced by the Government to reinforce the original plan framework and maintain progress towards the objectives agreed upon by industry and government in 1984. While considerable progress towards most of these objectives has occurred, the government believes the changes it has made are necessary and appropriate to accommodate the changed circumstances and build on the emerging strengths.
Financial Impact Statement

The revenue implications of the tariff changes cannot be estimated with any satisfactory degree of accuracy because of uncertainties about price and market response and the effects of other economic factors in consumer behaviour in this market.
Nevertheless, it is suggested that in 1988-89, a net revenue gain will occur.
The abolition of tariff quotas and the simplification of the local content provisions will reduce administration costs to Government and the vehicle industry.
Details of the amendments contained in the Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.
