SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just experienced the biggest travesty of the freedom of Australia that I have ever seen. We have just had 14 Bills sent up from the House of Representatives, all pushed through on a guillotine last night. Yet this Government wants to put to the people of Australian freedoms that it believes form a democracy. Last night, before the debate was interrupted, I was pointing out the misleading way this Government has worded the questions for the constitutional referendum. I had pointed out that Mr Gary Morgan, the leading pollster in Australia, a man with great credibility, had said that any public opinion polling company `who asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government proposes would completely lose credibility'. He went on:

SPEECH.PARA: It's appalling that on such a vital and serious issue as change to the Australian Constitution Labor should seek to mislead the people to get the result it wants.
That is exactly what is happening with the wording of the referendum questions.

I now come to the detail of the four questions which the people of Australia will be asked to vote on; we do not know when, but we are told some time perhaps in September. The first question is worded `to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament'. What a sham. It asks whether we agree with four-year maximum terms. There are many people who would agree with four-year maximum terms, but what this question does not tell the people is that it will alter the composition of the Parliament completely. Once again the executive government is trying to strip the Senate of its powers. On this occasion it is not just simultaneous elections the Government is trying to put forward. It is attempting to strip power from the Senate altogether.

Yesterday Senator Robert Ray misleadingly told us that it was really just simultaneous elections. I was surprised to see Paul Kelly in the Australian yesterday also talking about simultaneous elections. Obviously, he has not understood the question at all. Another thing the question does not tell the people is that in the four years four months that this Government has been in power it has called three separate elections. Yet the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wants an extension of time. He has not even used the three years he has presently got. He could have had three elections in nine years, but he chose, because he thought it was a good idea and because he thought he could win the elections, to have three elections in four years four months. This question does not stop him doing exactly the same thing in the next four years four months.

The Prime Minister has also asked, as well as four-year terms for the House of Representatives and the Senate, to be able to call them whenever he likes, in other words, that there be no fixed term. Let the people of Australia understand-no fixed term. He will be able to call an election of the House of Representatives and the whole of the Senate-not half the Senate which is usual, but the whole of the Senate-as often as he chooses. As I said, he could again have three elections in just over four years. It is because the Government recognises that a four-year term for the House of Representatives has general acceptance that it has used this vehicle to try to get rid of the powers of the Senate once and for all.

I mention just two occasions in the recent history of this Government when the Senate has saved the people from radical legislation they did not want. One occasion was the ID card. The Australian people spoke very strongly, saying that they did not want it. The other occasion was the Bill of Rights. On both occasions it was the Senate-not the House of Representatives, but the Senate-that was able to save the people of Australia from the sort of radical legislation this Government is prepared to push through purely because it has the numbers, and for no other reason.

At Federation the Premiers of the States got together and insisted upon two main things as regards the Senate. They said, `If we are going into this Federation, then the Senate must be independent of the executive or the government. It must be independent of the government of the day'. To make the Senate independent the founding fathers said that every State shall have equal numbers of senators. The founding fathers also said that only half the Senate, under normal circumstances, should go to the people at any one time. That was done deliberately to overcome the sort of government we have at the moment that introduces radical legislation which the people do not want. This referendum question takes that right away completely. On every occasion from now on, if this question is passed, the whole of the Senate-not half the Senate-will go to election whenever the Prime Minister wants. The Prime Minister will have his thumb completely on the Senate. He will have full control, against the wishes of the founding fathers who, in their wisdom, said that the Senate should be a House completely independent from the executive government of the day.

Senator Ray told the Senate that no Prime Minister wants to hold a half Senate election separate from a House of Representatives election. He is quite right, but it is only because the Prime Minister does not see it as being good for him. He never thinks about the Australian people. He does not consider what is good for the people, just what is good for him. I agree with Senator Ray that Mr Hawke certainly does not want to hold a separate half Senate election.

Let us look at what else the Prime Minister has done. At the moment the first date on which the Prime Minister can take the Senate to the people-he can take the House of Representatives whenever he likes-is 1 July 1989, which is in a couple of years' time, because the Senate has a fixed term and the Prime Minister cannot call a half Senate election under normal circumstances. He has to use the subterfuge that he used last time. He had to look around for Bills that will enable him to call a double dissolution, so that he can take the whole of the Senate, as well as the House of Representatives, to the people. Under normal circumstances he cannot do that.

Yesterday Senator Ray said that it does not suit the Prime Minister to take half the Senate to the people at any time because, if he did, it would produce the same sort of result as the by-election for Mick Young's seat. The people would show the Government just what they think of it. The Prime Minister has decided that he would not like that sort of by-election result in a Senate election. He certainly would not like Mick Young's by-election result, and so he is choosing to go for a four-year term. It is a complete and utter fraud. I cannot explain it any better to the Australian people than to say that at the moment we have the most stable type of government in the world. We could have possibly a four-year term for the House of Representatives, if the Prime Minister wants to put that sort of question forward, but not a fixed term so that the whole of the Senate would go to the people at each election.

Yesterday Senator Ray mentioned countries that have four-year terms. He tried to hoodwink the people by naming a few of our close allies as countries with four-year terms. What he did not mention are the countries that have different terms for the lower House and the upper House. I would like to mention a few of those. They include the United States of America, Austria, Canada and, of course, the United Kingdom, which we cannot count because it has an unelected House of Lords. What countries would we join that have the situation that this Government is proposing-that is, equal terms of four years or five years for the lower House and the upper House? We would join Bolivia, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, Zimbabwe and Russia. Are they the sorts of countries that have equal terms for the lower House and the upper House that we would want to join?

I do not believe that any Australian will vote for a government that wants to extend its term and destroy the concept of a fixed term for the Senate, which would stop the Prime Minister calling an election whenever he wants. The Government has held three elections in four years and four months. The people of Australia have already said that they do not trust the Prime Minister. That has been clearly established in the latest by-elections. They will not have a bar of sending any more power to Canberra. The people of Australia will not have a bar of giving any government in Canberra-not just this Government-more power.

I turn to question No. 2, which I think is possibly the worst phrased question. It states: `Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia?' Who would disagree with that? The Government does not know the first thing about democracy, as I have just pointed out. It gagged debate on 14 Bills in the House of Representatives last night. There was no debate on those Bills, which have been sent to us today. Yet the Government says it believes in democracy. What on earth are Government members on about? If they are serious about one vote one value, they would say, `Right, we will take away a couple of House of Representatives members from Tasmania'. Senator Tate, who believes in one vote one value, would be willing to stand by that sort of shonky decision by this Government. The Government would also take away Tasmanian senators, so that we would end up with two senators-that is, if it sincerely believed in one vote one value. It does not believe in one vote one value. It is trying to fix the Queensland gerrymander. The Government has not said that the Queensland gerrymander is done by boundaries. There could be an equal number of voters in every electorate and, so long as the Government draws its boundaries properly, it can win office on 26 per cent of the vote.

Let us look at what the percentages are. In Queensland the Labor Opposition has to get 51.4 per cent of the vote to win government. The Federal Opposition has to get 53 per cent of the vote to win. What is the Government talking about? Senator Robert Ray, who is the biggest schemer of all time, knows that he can fix things by changing the boundaries. That is the way the Government fixes gerrymanders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I ask Senator Walters to withdraw the comment that I can affect the boundaries of the Commonwealth. It is simply not true. It is done by an independent commission. The comment reflects on me. By the way, this is the first time in seven years that I have asked for a withdrawal.
—I ask you to withdraw that remark, Senator Walters.
—I withdraw. Senator Ray is just taking up my time. I only have seven minutes left and I would like to use that seven minutes.

—I take a brief point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. You generally rule for the Opposition to keep quiet and not make incessant interjections. The Government side has interjected non-stop during Senator Walters's speech. We would like to hear what Senator Walters has to say. I would ask you to show impartiality and ask that the Government interjections cease.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: During my speech yesterday Senator Walters must have made 100 interjections in the first five minutes. If she dishes it out, she must cop it. Senator Chaney was heard in silence during his one-hour speech. When people on the other side of the chamber accord that privilege on an important issue, it will be reciprocated. Senator Walters has not done so. It is a reflection on you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you are failing to control the Senate. You always allow a degree of interjection. If it is excessive, I will be reprimanded along with everyone else.
—Senator Knowles, there is no point of order and I would ask you to withdraw the remarks suggesting that the Chair has shown any bias towards any one party.
—I withdraw.
—It is rather flattering, because Senator Ray does not want--
—Gutless wonder.
—Order! Senator Knowles has just indicated that I am a `gutless wonder'. I ask her to withdraw that remark.
—I was not saying `gutless wonder' on air or anything else. I was talking here, in my seat.
—Senator Knowles, would you withdraw that remark.
—I will withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. I was not referring to you.
—I now have five minutes left of my speech.
—Do not blame me; blame Senator Knowles.
—I find it very flattering that Senator Ray does not want me to get across to the public the true intention of this Government.
—If you dish it out you should take it.

—I can take it. Senator Ray knows that better than most. Let us come to the question of local government. Let me explain to local government what the proposal is really all about. The Government wants to entrench forever the lack of autonomy that local government has. All the proposal says about local government is that it exists and it is under the control of the States-nothing else. The proposal does not give any protection to local government against dismissal by a State government. It does not give any guarantee of access to funding. It does not protect it from any forced amalgamations. All it does is state that local government exists. Local governments have accepted cuts in funding, accepted no guarantee of funding and accepted cuts in road funding. Local government has succumbed to the rhetoric of the mob opposite. I am staggered that local government would do so. Government senators do not even know the difference. Senator Burns even said, `Regional government is local government anyway.' That was a comment coming from the Government benches. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a comparison of Commonwealth funding in the Fraser years and in the Hawke years. I seek leave to do so.
—You have to wake him to know what to do next.
—Senator Knowles, would you please refrain from the remarks you are making. I ask you to withdraw those remarks.
—There is nothing to withdraw.
—You have said that the Chair is sleeping and I ask you to withdraw that remark.
—There is nothing at all to withdraw. I am writing material here--
—You said the Chair was asleep and I am asking you to withdraw.
—I withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now come to question No. 14, which is on the rights of people. We are told that the government wants freedom of religion, trial by jury and fair compensation. People are concerned about their real freedoms. Will the Government give the people out there freedom not to join a union? It is not interested in that one. The people out there want real freedoms but the Government is just not interested. Our Constitution does not set out freedoms for people in this country; it restricts government action. I quote from the Constitution, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth shall not make laws for establishing any religion.

(Extension of time granted) I thank the Senate. Our Constitution restricts Government action. It does not, as the American Constitution does, set out the people's rights. The American Constitution sets out the people's rights and it has a Bill of Rights. When it was in operation in the eighteenth century, although it set out the people's rights the American people were still able to treat the negroes in a disgraceful manner. It did not protect the rights of the people of America. It is the will of the people, not what is written about their rights in the Constitution, that is important. The Australian Constitution does not set out the individual rights of Australian people. This Government tried to get a Bill of Rights through. This proposed alteration of the Constitution sets out that we should have freedom of religion. Everyone knows that we have freedom of religion and trial by jury.

We know who the Government is aiming the fair compensation question at. Under the Wran Government New South Wales failed to give fair compensation to people owning property in the coal deal. That has been overcome by the new Government. The people had their say and they threw out the Government that did not give them fair compensation. So we do not need the individual rights set out in our Constitution. There is a danger if that is done because automatically if one right is not set out it is presumed that Australians do not have such a right. Exactly the same situation existed with the Bill of Rights. The Government very clearly defined the rights to join an association or a union but the right not to join a union was deliberately left out-not by accident. When we wanted to amend the legislation and put in the right not to join a union the Government refused to allow us to do so. If the people of Australia accept just three freedoms being put in our Constitution they can presume that all their other rights are denied them. It is a very dangerous proposition for this Government to put to the people that they should have their rights clearly set out in the Constitution. We know that there are only a handful of countries-indeed, 19 individual countries in the world out of 167-that have the same political and individual freedoms as we have. Our Constitution is ideal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the four Constitution alteration Bills before the Parliament. In the brief comments I make I will speak particularly on the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill. Other senators from this side will cover the remainder of the Bills. Senator Robert Ray and others already have and other senators on the Government side will. I wish to concentrate on that Bill because it is also very important for the nature of Australian politics. Over the last two or three years I have been campaigning fairly publicly for this reform, the introduction of four-year terms, because it goes beyond the issues of individual parties and partisan politics. It is important for the nature of politics and government in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In the spirit of the disclosure laws which this Government has introduced, I should declare my interest-territorial senators will have their term extended by the introduction of four-year terms for senators because at the moment we have a maximum three-year term, tied to the House of Representatives. But I believe that four-year terms are particularly important. It is a reform Australia needs and is entirely consistent with the micro-economic reform agenda which the Government is setting down as a priority for this term and into the 1990s. It is consistent with the principles which underpin the reforms that have taken place to date and which, on all public indications, will underpin the reforms to be outlined in tomorrow evening's economic statement. The economic circumstances faced in 1988 and those which we can foresee for the remainder of this century require a government willing and able to implement long term programs and to take the tough decisions that economic reform requires, without being confronted by perpetual elections.

It is hard for people to realise that we are now only 10 months past the most recent election, yet speculation about the date for the next election has already started. We have had too many elections at all levels of government. That is expensive, wasteful and annoying. I sometimes think the Australian people's greatest objection to elections is all those advertisements that disrupt their otherwise good television programs. Elections are annoying to people but, more importantly, they are disruptive to the necessary process of economic reform. The four-year term proposal is entirely consistent with the trend of politics. At State level, we have had State Labor governments in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales introduce four-year terms with the support of the people and, on many occasions, the support of the conservative parties.

Most recently a proposal almost identical to that before us-that is, four-year terms for both Houses of Parliament-was introduced into the Western Australian Parliament, with the support of the National Party in Western Australia. That could not have been carried by the Australian Labor Party alone because of the gerrymander and malapportionment which means that we cannot achieve a Labor majority in the Legislative Council. In 98 years it has never had other than a conservative majority. It is approaching a hundred not out which, unfortunately, is somewhat more than the score I ever made at cricket. It indicates that in a State which has had nearly 50 per cent Labor government in the Legislative Assembly, despite malapportionment and gerrymander in that House, the Labor Party has never been able to achieve a majority. So that is a very effective case for the second reform. But in spite of that gerrymander and malapportionment, the four-year term proposal has passed the Western Australian Parliament. It now means that in five of the six States we have four-year terms. There is no proposal from any of the conservative parties in any of those States to do away with it. All the serious economic commentators and analysts from all sides of politics support the move to a four-year term. Dr Neville Norman wrote recently:

No provision of the Constitution seems to be more limiting to the development of appropriate economic policies than the provisions . . . limiting parliamentary terms to three years . . . This short uncertain term militates against the development of bold but unpopular initiatives, most especially to the areas of tax and industrial relations.

One of this Government's proudest achievements is the extent to which it has been prepared to take tough and unpopular economic decisions and go to the people to explain the circumstances for them. That underpinned the most recent and remarkable electoral victory of July last year when the people rejected the bribes of a fistful of dollars and voted for responsible economic policies. Nevertheless, since Federation, it has been and remains an unnecessary, unreasonable and effectively unworkable constraint upon proper economic and political management. This proposal has also been supported by such prominent economists as Will Buttrose, the economist for the Macquarie Bank Ltd, and most vociferously by the Business Council of Australia. I want to pay tribute to that body and, in particular, to Eric Mayer from National Mutual, who has chaired the committee on this matter and has campaigned effectively around Australia for it. I look forward to their support once again in this referendum campaign.

The four-year term has not been opposed by anybody until now. Suddenly it is being opposed by the Opposition. The first thing to say is that what the Opposition in this Parliament is really opposed to is the people having the right to vote on whether we ought to have a four-year term. If this legislation is passed, it will not change the term of the Parliament. It proposes that the Australian people get a chance to vote on whether they want the term lengthened. It is a very strange thing to be opposed to-`in the interests of democracy we will not let the people have a vote'. Knowing full well that the proposal will go forward, this bit of grandstanding in the Parliament is really about trying to establish the grounds on which it can justify the unjustifiable, trying to establish the grounds on which it can oppose these four proposals, even though everybody knows that the shadow Cabinet wanted to support two of them and some people wanted to support all four, but they could not agree on any so they wound up opposing the lot.

The actual basis for this goes back to what can be called TSBH politics: that is, too smart by half politics. The Opposition is really trying to find clever ways to sneak up on people and suddenly look like they have had a win. They say, `We will oppose these four good ideas because the people might not realise how hypocritical we are being and might not realise that these arguments are silly-so if we have a win we will look pretty smart and look like we are on a winning streak'. I will come back to that later-but they are definitely too smart by half. They know they are wrong. That can easily be seen by the distorted arguments coming forward in the Senate and the House of Representatives in apparent attempted justification of this extraordinary decision.

It seems, after the preceding Opposition speech and other Opposition speeches, that I need to reiterate that this referendum Bill lengthens the term of the House of Representatives and makes the term of the Senate the same. It does not take away the powers of the Senate. Those extraordinary claims that somehow, if this referendum had been passed earlier, the Senate would not have been able to do what it did to the Australia Card, are absolutely unfounded. If ever there were a wrong example, that is it because that legislation could have brought about a joint sitting of the Parliament. The powers of the Senate there were exercised irrespective of the proposals about whether the Government could call another election. Other constitutional provisions overrode that proposal. It is an absolutely nonsensical proposal. It does not affect the powers of the Senate.

The Opposition's proposal also means that senators would be able to be in this chamber for 24 years, having been elected only three times-they could be here for a quarter of a century for three elections. I am only 40 years old so that is not a bad proposal. I could go through three preselections and be here until retiring age. But it will not endear itself to the Australian people that, in the interests of accountability, we ought to have senators here for 24 years, being elected only three times. What a nonsense of a proposal. Then those opposite came up with the convoluted argument that somehow this was a sneaky proposal to lengthen the term of this Government-when of course it will not change this term of the House of Representatives at all. The problem is that their cover has been blown. Paul Kelly has told the people of Australia that Opposition members are either ignorant or deliberately misleading them. Some are one and some are probably the other. Paul Kelly stated:

The `adjustment' provisions of the Government's first referendum question are hardly unique. In fact they are the same as that followed by the Fraser Government in its May 1977 simultaneous elections referendum.

People might forget that Mr Howard, who thinks that this is such a terrible thing, was a member of that Government. They may forget that the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia (Mr Peacock) was actually a senior Minister in the Cabinet in that Government. People with short memories think that others have short memories as well. Paul Kelly continued:
Mr Howard, in his attack on Mr Hawke's referendum, is attacking the very device used by his own side . . .
With his support-he voted for it in the Parliament in 1977. In the necessary recording of votes, Mr Howard voted for this proposal, but now he thinks it is a terrible outrage. Paul Kelly goes on:
There is nothing remarkable or surprising or outrageous about this provision.
It is absolutely standard and necessary and everybody knows it. It is a case of everybody is out of step but Johnny.

There are other examples of the extraordinary arguments those opposite have had to come up with to try to justify opposing these proposals. One of the most extraordinary arguments-if I may divert to one of the other questions for a moment-is that we should not have the one vote one value proposal because it might fix up malapportionment but it does not fix up gerrymanders. On the basis of that logic we would reject the polio vaccine because it does not do anything about smallpox. The logic of that is absolutely incredible. I have been waiting with bated breath for an Opposition senator to say, `What you should have done is fix up the gerrymander'. The Opposition speaker after me, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, being a National Party senator from Queensland, would have great expertise on questions of gerrymander.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just wait until I tell you the answers.

—I await with bated breath the honourable senator's proposal. When she does work out how to resolve gerrymanders, I would be happy to be the second person she told. The Government of Queensland should be the first.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to conclude-at the request of my Whip I will not go for too long-with some general points. The Constitution is not and has never been a static document. It evolves by the decisions of judges. Quite rightly, necessarily and inevitably judges in their interpretations have interpreted and effectively changed the Constitution. It has been changed eight times by referendum. But it is not just for judges to change the Constitution; the people ought to get a go every now and again. Furthermore, it is not open to the High Court of Australia to proceed gradually to reform the Constitution by judicial interpretation to achieve four-year terms. That is not an option open to it; it is not open to it to read into the Constitution recognition of local government; and it is not open to it to read into the Constitution guarantees of freedom of religion, trial by jury or compensation on just terms. It is remotely possible that it could read into the Constitution one vote one value. I would welcome that, but I do not see that as being a drastic argument against the people getting a chance to have a say, because that is all this proposal does.

At the moment the opinion polls about this proposal are essentially positive. I do not want to get carried away with that because I have seen over the last 15 years that opinion polls have often supported referendums that have subsequently been defeated. But the pathetic contortions of members of the Opposition and their too smart by half tactics which underestimate the intelligence of the Australian people may well bring them undone. If one or more of these referendum proposals are carried-I hope they all are, and there is a reasonable chance that some or all of them will be-it will be the greatest defeat for a Leader of the Opposition in recent Australian political history and it will be the most well deserved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating this afternoon the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill which, if carried, will result in four seemingly innocent questions being put to the people of Australia in September this year-so we are given to understand in the media.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take this opportunity to determine just what the Government is trying to achieve by amending the Constitution in the manner proposed. I ask: Why the unseemly haste in rushing the Bills through the Parliament before even the final report of the Constitutional Commission and then rushing them to a special referendum? Why is there such a hurry? An amount of $37.3m will be spent. I cannot understand why we cannot wait until the next election.

The first Bill deals with four-year terms. That seems unusual because the present Government, and probably some of the governments before, never seemed to be able to wait even for a three-year term before calling an election. Maybe the Government is talking about a four-year term so that we might be able to go for three years. That is one point I want to make. Then we come to the question of one vote one value which I believe is a matter for State governments and not for the Federal Parliament to determine. The third Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill, is a token gesture for local government. There is no money attached to it. The shire councils are not going to receive any money. The fourth Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill, is really, to my way of thinking, a mini-Bill of Rights. The people have already said in no uncertain terms that they do not want a Bill of Rights. I believe that this is a case where we could save $37.3m. We hear the Government crying poor all the time, saying that it needs more money, but it is spending $37m when it does not necessarily need to.

It should be noted that the wording of each question to be put to the people is quite different from the wording which actually appears in the four referendum Bills. I was interested to read in a report in the Courier-Mail on 18 May where a leading pollster branded the Government's proposed referendum questions as blatantly biased. The managing director of the Roy Morgan Research Centre, Mr Gary Morgan, has apparently said that the questions did not honestly convey the issues being asked. He said that there was no doubt that the questions were biased in order to obtain a yes vote from the voters. Mr Morgan went on to say that `any public opinion polling company that asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government proposes would completely lose credibility'. That is the opinion of an independent person with a great deal of professional experience in this area. My great fear is that many Australian voters will quite innocently fall into the trap which the Government has set for them and take the questions at face value. After reading Mr Morgan's comments on the matter it seems that my fears could be well founded.

It is our duty-indeed, it is our responsibility-to ensure that the voters of Australia fully understand the consequences of a Yes vote to any one of the four questions. They must be told just what the Government is attempting to achieve with its suggested changes to the Constitution. The first question asked: Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament? To the average Australian voter, this proposal would no doubt seem fairly innocuous. Some might think that it may even be a good idea. Many will interpret the question as a move towards a more stable system of government, an end to early elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not with this Prime Minister.
—That is right. The wording of the question raises false hopes; in fact, the proposal could well lead to more elections rather than fewer elections and they would all be double dissolutions.

SPEECH.PARA: Implementation of this proposal would effectively abandon the system of rotation of senators' terms while reducing the length of their term by two years. Some people might say, `That is a jolly good idea. We are here for too long anyway'. But I do not go along with that. I believe that it will mean the abolition of the fixed term for the Senate. The Government cannot refute the claim that the role of the Senate as a House of review will be severely undermined if this proposal is implemented.

The Constitutional Commission actually recommended that parliamentary terms for senators be twice as long as those for members of the House of Representatives. But the Government has chosen to ignore that recommendation. The Commission further recommended that the term of the House of Representatives be extended to four years, with a minimum term of three years. This proposal has also been ignored by the Government. The proposal favoured by the Government effectively introduces permanent double dissolutions, so that every time a Prime Minister is confronted with a Senate which refuses to bow to his will he will be able to call an election for both Houses and require every senator to face an election.

As I said earlier in my speech, I find it hard to understand why the Government has opted for four-year terms. In the seven years that I have been in the Senate there have been three elections. As I said, the Government has not even been able to complete a three-year term, and it is hypocritical in my opinion to suggest that we need four years. As I said, the Government probably wants four years in the hope that it may last three. If this proposal is accepted the independence of the Senate will be a thing of the past. There can be no doubt that this proposal, if adopted, will seriously jeopardise the Senate's ability to act against bad Government legislation. If it were not for the Senate we would now have the identity card and the infamous Bill of Rights.

I now come to the second question. That will ask whether Australians approve of an amendment to the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. Without a doubt every thinking voter would at first glance approve of fair and democratic elections. But one has to look beyond those words in order to discover just what the Government is attempting to achieve with this amendment. In effect this proposal will extend the principle of one vote one value to State parliaments. Surely the procedures and rules applicable to State elections are matters which should properly be dealt with by the individual State parliaments. Why is there a sudden lack of regard for the federal system of government? Since when has the Federal government had the right to dictate electoral terms and conditions for the States? The proposal represents yet another attempt by the Government to infringe the rights of the States.

The bottom line is that the Government is attempting to force its will upon the State electoral systems. The Government claims that the proposal will apply a numerical equality in the number of electors in each electoral division for the House of Representatives and either House of the Parliament of a State or Territory assembly. However, such an equality will not apply in the House of Representatives. For example, Tasmania, despite its small population, is guaranteed five seats in the House of Representatives. How can the Government claim that the one vote one value system will provide for fair elections? Where is the fairness in concentrating the bulk of the electors in the south-east corner of Queensland if the one vote one value system goes ahead?

If this referendum Bill is carried and becomes law, Queensland will end up with just a handful of rural electorates, some of which will be almost the size of the Federal electorates in Queensland. For instance, look at the electorates of Maranoa and Kennedy, both of which are nearly one-third the size of Queensland anyway. I believe the State electorates will look the same as Federal electorates if this goes ahead. Why does the Australian Labor Party refuse to acknowledge that there are certain hardships associated with living in isolated rural centres, hardships which city dwellers never really have to face? The State parliamentarians representing country areas already have a difficult job trying to service their electorates effectively. At times the distances involved make their tasks almost impossible. How can the Government justify such callous treatment of rural Australians when it considers that they are the people responsible for generating export earnings worth hundreds of millions of dollars for this country?

Our political opponents and certain sections of the media take great delight in seizing every opportunity to condemn Queensland for its so-called gerrymander. At every election, and indeed when somebody wants a reason to criticise our State, there is much self-righteous rhetoric as they bemoan the dreadful electoral system which keeps the Labor Party in the political wilderness in that State. There are, however, a few hard facts which our critics should be made aware of, a few home truths which they should recall the next time they are tempted to blame the dreaded zonal system for Labor's abysmal electoral record in Queensland. They should recall that under the current electoral system in Queensland the Australian Labor Party would win office if it could attract 51.4 per cent of the vote, a percentage, I might add, which it has not even come close to achieving since 1957, and that was a long time ago. I was interested to read an article in the Weekend Australian stating that in 1986 the National Party of Australia gained government with a 56 per cent two-party preferred vote. Now anyone would think, from what the Opposition has been saying, that we got there with a vote of less than 50 per cent, and that is something I want to draw to the attention of the Senate.

In the recent State election held in New South Wales the National and Liberal parties had to obtain almost 53 per cent of the two-party preferred vote to remove the Unsworth Government from office. Now that is a gerrymander if ever there was one, and Labor knows how to do that, because this gerrymander in Queensland that the people talk about was a zonal system put in place by the Labor Party in Queensland. That is something that nobody on the other side of the chamber ever mentions.

Our critics should also be reminded that the Federal National and Liberal parties must win 52.3 per cent of the two-party preferred vote if they are ever to succeed in ridding this country of the services of the Hawke Government. That does make the Government's preoccupation with fair and democratic elections something of a laughing matter and it calls into question the motives behind the proposal.

I also want to draw attention to the pure Senate vote in Queensland. There are no boundaries associated with the Senate vote. We are all equal; we all go in without these terrible zonal electorates people talk about. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that in the last Senate election the National Party gained four senators and the Liberal Party gained two. If honourable senators opposite have the same method of addition as mine, that makes six. How many did the Labor Party gain? It gained five, and the Democrats got one. Therefore, the coalition parties in Queensland were able to get six senators from our State. I believe that if we look at those numbers there is just no reason to mention a gerrymander as far as the Senate vote is concerned. No one can say there is any gerrymander. I believe the whole question is hypocritical and is based on a false premise. The Labor Party is very adept at causing diversions in order to detract from its own failings and problems. It never fails to grab the chance to raise a hue and cry about what it sees as the so-called unfairness of the Queensland system. I advise the Labor Party in general, and the Hawke Government in particular, to put its own house in order before condemning Queensland and seeking to impose conditions upon our State electoral system.

The third question will ask whether voters approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government. I was very concerned to read a recent Press release, put out by the Australian Local Government Association, which said that local government leaders around Australia were amazed and disappointed at the Federal Opposition's decision to oppose the referendum question concerning local government recognition. The President of the Association, Councillor Peter Kyle, said that the Federal Liberal Party had made a commitment that the next Liberal Government would examine appropriate constitutional recognition of local government in Australia. Councillor Kyle went on to say that the National Party had given unequivocal support to constitutional recognition of local government.

I want to point out to Councillor Kyle that the proposed amendment to the Constitution makes no mention whatsoever of the Commonwealth Government recognising local government. While it has been coalition policy to recognise local government in the Constitution, it believes that the wording of the referendum question is nothing short of a gross misrepresentation. The question reads:
Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government?

What is being proposed is the insertion of a new section, 119a, which provides that each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer and to make by-laws for their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State. There is no mention about any move by the Commonwealth to recognise local government, except, of course, in the question being put to voters. It is nothing short of deception and dishonesty on the part of the Government.

All State governments support the system of local government. Victoria, Western Australia, South Australia and New South Wales have all amended their Constitutions to recognise local government. The proposed amendment is nothing but an attempt by the Government to force Tasmania and Queensland to follow suit. I believe that is the crux of the matter. The proposal has nothing to benefit local government. It is just a thinly disguised example of the Labor Party attempting yet again to centralise power in Canberra. It represents an intrusion into State rights; it is an attempt to impose the will of the Federal Government upon the governments of Queensland and Tasmania.

My concern is that the proposed amendment could be open to an unduly wide interpretation. It has been very broadly defined, and recent decisions of the High Court dealing with external affairs powers do little to allay my fears. The Federal Government currently enjoys unprecedented centralist powers over both State and local governments. If implemented, the proposal could mean the reintroduction of the concept of regionalism, so favoured by Mr Whitlam, and the use of funding arrangements to force amalgamations. It is interesting to note that the proposed law is to be confined to the States. It will not apply to the Government's own areas of responsibility-namely, the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory, Christmas Island and Norfolk Island. That provides clear evidence of the fact that the Labor Party is trying to impose on the rights of the States.

The Federal Government is currently proposing a form of Aboriginal compact that would create about 52 regional Aboriginal councils throughout Australia with local government-type functions. I find it disturbing to note that this proposal will not be examined in detail by Parliament until after the referendum has taken place. The proposed amendment contains nothing to allay the fears so often expressed by local government. It contains no provision to protect local councils from dismissal by State Governments and no provision to protect them from amalgamation.

Primarily, local government has sought through constitutional recognition a guaranteed proportion of revenue, and no such guarantee has been given. On any interpretation of the clause, one point is absolutely clear: local government would receive no benefits whatsoever if the Bill became law.

I want to mention what the Liberal-National coalition has done for local government over the years. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that it was a Liberal-National Government that first gave local government a fixed funding arrangement through personal income tax sharing. That Government provided for local government representation on the State Grants Commission and provided for the distribution of personal income tax sharing. When Ralph Hunt was Minister for Transport in that Government, he introduced the bicentennial road funding levy of 2c per litre on fuel to provide more funds for road works for local government. It was the Liberal and National parties that made a major submission to the Self inquiry in 1985 to review the Commonwealth-local government financial arrangements. That same Government set up a forum for local government in the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations.

The coalition parties over many years in government have provided practical support and have shown empathy for local government. However, the Labor Party has done very little for local government. The road funding crisis is a perfect example of the Hawke Government's lack of commitment to the needs of local government. For example, Federal spending on roads has been at the same level since 1984-85, but when inflation is taken into account funding has declined in real terms by 25 per cent. That works out to a reduction of more than $300m. Only about a week ago I made a speech on this matter in the Senate. Local authorities are very concerned about the smaller amount of money given to them for road works in their areas.

As I mentioned earlier, the Federal Liberal-National Government was instrumental in implementing personal income tax sharing for local government which guaranteed local government 2 per cent of total Commonwealth revenue from personal income tax. It should be noted that the level of funding has steadily declined since the Hawke Government came to power in 1983. The allocation for the 1988-89 financial year is 1.66 per cent of personal income tax.

I now come to the fourth and final question, which will ask voters whether they approve of altering the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend the freedom of religion and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by the Government. I want to ask: Why should the people of Australia be asked if they want the right to freedom of religion which, under common law, they already have? What new freedom will we have that we do not already enjoy? All that this proposal means is that the Government has decided to have another attempt at bringing in a Bill of Rights, but this time it is trying to do it through the back door by using the Constitution. The Government has chosen to ignore the fact that the Bill of Rights concept has already been firmly rejected by the Australian people.

The question has, of course, been cleverly worded. Who could possibly be against voting for the right to trial by jury, the right to freedom of religion and the right to fair compensation for property acquired by government? However, those rights already exist within the Constitution, and I believe that once one starts to clearly define such basic rights, carefully spelling each one out, those rights then become limited. They become open to misinterpretation, if not now at some time in the future; and that is my greatest concern. My concern is shared by the vast majority of Australians. I am not aware of any unrest in the community resulting from religious persecution or discrimination, and I have yet to receive a single complaint from any person who has been wrongly deprived of a trial by jury. The problem lies in delays in court hearings that cannot be alleviated by constitutional change but can be overcome through administrative change under existing powers.

Landholders receive compensation when their properties are resumed by the Government. If they are not happy with the level of compensation, avenues of appeal are open to them. Furthermore, there is no guarantee that compensation will be greater if this proposal is implemented. I sincerely hope that the voters of this country will realise that referendum question No. 4, if carried, will provide us with a condensed form of a Bill of Rights which the Hawke Government tried unsuccessfully to force through some time ago. It contained seemingly innocent proposals to give us rights that we already possess. These rights already exist in the Constitution and to attempt to write in further human rights provisions can cause dangerous complications. For example, the section in the Bill relating to religion provides:
. . . that the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory shall not establish any religion, impose any religious observance or prohibit the free exercise of any religion-

Does this mean that state schools will be prohibited from providing religious studies or observance? Does this mean that religious administrators will be prevented from ministering to the sick in government-run hospitals? Does it mean that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will no longer be able to broadcast or televise religious services?

My great fear is that if this referendum Bill becomes law, the day will arrive when the Bill of Rights clause of the Constitution will require clarification and interpretation. It is bound to happen one day. It could be 10 or 20 years from now but when it finally happens I fear that Australians will find their rights limited and their freedom restricted. I want no part in leaving such a dreadful legacy to our future countrymen and women.

In conclusion, I must ask again why the Government is moving with such speed on this matter. Just four days after receiving only the first of two reports of the Constitutional Commission, the Government introduced its referenda proposals and is aiming for the referendum questions to be put in the first two weeks of September. None of the questions is of such gripping importance that it must be put to the people of Australia as a matter of urgency. The Government seems keen to put the referendum questions before voters have a chance to fully absorb, consider and understand the ramifications of each proposed amendment. The Government is acting as though it has something to hide. The proposed changes to the Constitution are unnecessary; they are fundamentally wrong. I urge all Australians to register their rejection by voting no to all four referenda questions.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been said that these Constitution alteration Bills have been brought on too quickly and more time should be given to consider them. The fact is that they are either needed or they are not. The changes to the Constitution are either needed or they are not. It is for the House of Representatives, the Senate and then, if the Bills are passed, the people to decide that. The Constitutional Commission has produced material which is now available to the people. If that is accepted and if the referenda find favour in the eyes of the people, they will be passed.

SPEECH.PARA: The founding fathers, of whom we have heard much today, foresaw the need for constitutional change. That great figure of Henry Bournes Higgins had this to say at the Federal Convention held in Melbourne on 9 February 1898:

. . . I want to have nothing absolutely rigid or unchangeable in the Constitution. From the point of view of ethics, I cannot see what right we have in this generation to dictate absolutely as to what future generations shall do.
Later in the same speech he said:

. . . I simply want to give the next generations which follow us the same liberty to control the Constitution as we have ourselves. Why should we say that all wisdom for the purpose of constructive federation is deposited in the present generation?

These Bills give the Australian people the opportunity to do what their forebears so nobly did almost 100 years ago. When considering that, it is appropriate to look at the considerations they should take into account. Much has been made of States rights in this matter. Henry Bournes Higgins said the following about that:

This Commonwealth has to make laws which are to operate upon persons, upon individuals, and which are not to operate upon States, and therefore the laws of the Commonwealth ought to be decided by persons, by individuals, and not by States.
I turn to the question of four-year terms about which much has been made. It is instructive in that context to look at the making of the Constitution when considering the Bill.

During the constitutional conventions, the debate about the relationship to be established between the Commonwealth and the States was intense but that about the relationship between the States was even more so. The powers of the Senate must be considered within that relationship. At the conventions important debate was directed to whether the Senate ought to be popularly elected rather than nominated by the various State legislatures. The draft Constitution discussed at the 1891 convention provided for the Senate to terminate on a fixed date. That was when the Senate was to be elected by the legislatures of the various colonies and it was pointed out that where a particular date had to be established the colonies had to be enabled to accommodate that position, to have their people elected, so that the Senate could sit on a specific day. It was in that context that fixed terms for the Senate were provided for. Later a change was made in the draft Constitution to provide for the Senate to be elected by the people. That is to be remembered now when this discussion is taking place. Fixed terms were to accommodate the colonies and not to set up the power of the Senate against the Executive.

The most intense debate about the Senate was on whether equal representation should be given to all States in the Senate or whether representation in the Senate ought to be dependent upon the number of people in the various States. It was decided as part of the compact reached between the States that they would have equal representation in the Senate. That decision cannot be used as a precedent for having disparity between the number of people who are in the various electorates. An attempt has been made to do that in this debate. The question of equal representation of the States in the Senate is a special provision in a special compact. It is a special circumstance. The Federal conventions decided the States should have equal representation in the Senate. The legislation which is now before this chamber does nothing about disturbing the balance between the States. In other words, the essential thrust in the Constitution that the States should maintain equality in the Senate is maintained. It is wrong to say that the Senate's powers are diminished by the Bill now before us.

The question arises as to whether we ought to have eight-year terms. None of the other federal conventions drawing up this Constitution ever suggested eight-year terms. Indeed, a four-year term was suggested by Henry Bournes Higgins, who said that it ought to be a four-year term because it would put the Senate `more in touch with the people, so that they may not have six years before they are called to account for voting against that on which the people may have expressed their will'. It is most pertinent to quote that in a situation where eight-year terms have become an issue.

I have this to say about the proposed four-year term for the House of Representatives: The founding fathers, about whom we have heard much, allotted three-year terms to that House because the various colonial parliaments then had three-year terms. They wanted to reflect in the Federal Parliament what was going on in the States. On 21 April 1897, Mr Barton, later to be the first Prime Minister of Australia, moved for four-year terms, but Sir George Turner from Victoria argued against this on the grounds that `the people had got used to the period of three years'. In contemporary Australia in every State but Queensland the people have got used to a period of four years. In the spirit in which our Constitution was written, now that people have got used to four-year terms in the State legislatures they should be allowed to get used to four-year terms in the Commonwealth Parliament. The basis upon which our Constitution was written was that what was happening in the State parliaments ought to be reflected in the Federal Parliament. There are four-year terms in the State parliaments; that is the most efficient term to have.

It has been argued that if senators are given identical terms to members in the House of Representatives the Prime Minister's power will be increased, unhappily, because he can advise a dissolution of parliament and the Senate will go to the people at the same time as the House of Representatives. Honourable senators might well ask, `Why should it not?'. What is so special about the Senate to entitle it to longer terms than the House of Representatives? If there were no Ministers in the Senate and if it were simply a House of review there might be an argument to make along those lines. The situation is different where Ministers of the Government are in the Senate. The Government goes to the people so that the people might pass judgment on the Government. Why should we have a position where nine Ministers of the Crown-and that is the number now in this Senate-do not have to face the electors at the next election simply because one House is given twice the term of the other? If we clear out the Ministers in the Senate and we make it a House of review there might be an argument for it. But while we have Ministers in the Senate it is proper that, when Ministers in the House of Representatives face the people, so should Ministers in the Senate. This means simultaneous elections for both Houses.

Criticism has been made of the Prime Minister being able to advise on his own initiative as to when elections should be held. That is a convention that is in the British Constitution from which we draw so much of our own. The Prime Minister has the right to call elections. As I have said, that is the situation in the place which is the mother or father of parliamentary democracy. To complain that the Prime Minister in Australia has a particular power to call an election is beside the point because he simply exercises a power that every other Prime Minister has, in particular, the Prime Minister in the United Kingdom.

To sum up, the four-year term is more efficient. It is proper that we should have four-year terms for both Houses to enable the whole of the Government to be adjudged by the people. This does not mean that the Senate will be the servant or the foot stool of either the Prime Minister or the House of Representatives. Earlier in the day Senator Walters said that the Senate had saved the people from the identity card and the Bill of Rights. That is evidence not for the proposition that she was putting forward, that the Senate ought to have twice the term of the House of Representatives, but for the contrary proposition. In respect of both those issues-the ID card and the Bill of Rights-the Senate which rejected them was a Senate which was elected at exactly the same time as the House of Representatives. Therefore, it is evidence which supports our proposition.

I turn now to the question of fair elections. Many a statement has been made in this Senate that special provisions ought to be made for special people, whether they are in remote districts, or perhaps in the poorer parts of a city, or what have you. A series of cases were decided in the Supreme Court of the United States of America which dealt with that very question-great cases such as Baker v. Carr, Wesbury v. Sanders and Reynolds v. Sims. In Reynolds v. Sims the Chief Justice, Earl Warren, made some statements which put paid to the propositions which are before us now. In the short time that I have left to me I will not read those statements but, in summary, they say that legislatures and governments represent people. They do not represent trees, they do not represent sheep, they do not represent great houses of the merchants nor the poor houses of the downtrodden. They represent people. That is the proposition which is accepted in all the great democratic countries and that is the proposition that we should adopt here today.

Let me quickly mention the legislation concerning local government. It is proper that local government be enshrined in our Constitution. Our Constitution is the blueprint, if you like, of the way we are governed. It provides for the separation of powers; it provides for a judiciary, for an executive and for a parliament; it provides for the States and it provides for the Commonwealth Government. In that context, is it not proper that it should provide for that other great arm of government-local government? Either we are in support of local government or we are not. If we are in support of local government we put it in the blueprint for the government of the people of this nation. The simple proposition which the people of Australia will have to decide is whether they want local government and whether they want the maintenance of local government provided for in the Constitution, which has all other arms of government provided for in it?

I come now to the last Bill, which provides for trial by jury, freedom of religion and adequate compensation for land when it is acquired by any government. It has been said here today that the common law protects those rights. That is quite wrong. Any legislature other than the Commonwealth legislature can legislate away those rights. To use an example, ordinances in the Australian Capital Territory took away the right to juries in certain instances and it had to be restored. Those three provisions reflect what is already in the Constitution in so far as it governs the Commonwealth. Is it not proper that those protections which are given against the Commonwealth Government should also be given against the State governments?

In conclusion, let me read from the Annotated Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth by John Quick, a member of the Victorian contingent to the National Australian Convention in 1897-98, and Robert Randolph Garran, who was at the New South Wales Bar at that time. This book was written in 1901, just as our Constitution was coming into operation. Talking about the amending power of the Constitution, they said:

Nor is the scope of the amending power restricted to the structure and functions of the Federal Government; it extends to the structure and functions of the Governments of the States. Indeed, nearly every extension of powers and functions granted to the Federal Government would involve a consequential contraction of powers and functions in the Governments of the States; and if a constitutional amendment could so alter the powers and functions of the Government of the States, why should it not be capable of dealing, if necessary, with the Constitutions and political organization of the States?

Each Australian has a responsibility to every other Australian, no matter what State he lives in. If in a State there is a maladjustment of the boundaries, if there is unequal representation in parliament, we should do something about it. If there are provisions protecting people's rights against the Commonwealth, whether in relation to freedom of religion, the right to trial by jury, or the right to fair compensation for the acquisition of property by the Commonwealth, why should we not extend these rights to every Australian, so they exist not only against the Federal Government but also against the States? Why would we go only half way?

What would honourable senators opposite, who have got up here today and said that those rights should not be put in the Constitution, say if we said that the right to freedom of religion, to trial by jury, to fair compensation for the acquisition of property, all now existing against the Commonwealth, should be removed from the Constitution? If we proposed to remove those rights against the Commonwealth from the Constitution, what would any decent senator, any decent representative of the people, say? If protest is the probable reaction, why do those opposite refuse to extend those rights against the States, remembering, as Henry Bournes Higgins said, that what is of foremost importance in this country is not the States, and not the Commonwealth, but the individuals-the people who have to bear the burden of the laws they make?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately today four referendum Bills proposed by the Government, namely, the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections)-I almost gag at the use of those words-Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms)-again, words which ought to be put in quotation marks-Bill. In addition, a fifth Bill is being debated cognately, that proposed by Senator Macklin of the Australian Democrats, namely, the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. Proposals for altering the Constitution, it goes without saying, are among the most serious proposals ever to come before the Parliament. So it is worth while looking briefly at the manner in which the four Government Bills-they are the Bills to which I shall chiefly address my remarks-have been brought here so that we may judge whether this Government has sought to deal straightforwardly, frankly, openly and honestly with the Australian people in relation to these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: After all, we have in this country, in the various States particularly, consumer protection laws. I am beginning to think, when I look at these Bills and certain other legislation which the Government continues to bring before us, that we ought to have what might be called legislative protection laws, or legislation protection laws. If one goes to a second-hand car dealer in this country to purchase a car, one normally, if one is prudent, seeks some form of report on that second-hand vehicle. In this case, the Government set out to seek a report on the state of what it would regard as our second-hand vehicle, our second-hand Constitution, what it sometimes called our horse and buggy Constitution, from a body of its own devising-the Constitutional Commission.

Having sought that report about the motor vehicle which we are buying, as a rule-again, if we are prudent-we like to take some time to think about the report once it has been received, to consider what it has to say about the state of the chassis or cylinder block, or whatever it might be. In particular, we like to think about what that report says and, indeed, what our own eyes might tell us about whether the vehicle we are considering purchasing, or which is being offered to us, is actually what it seems, whether perhaps the new, shiny coat of paint is covering up a lot of rust underneath, for example. If we actually buy it, as the Australian people are about to be asked to buy these four proposals from the Government in a few months time, and ride off in it, it is always as well to be aware in advance how far down the track we will get before we find that it does have a cracked cylinder head and we are in real trouble, having made our purchase and irrevocably committed ourselves to living with the consequences.

As I said, the report on the car in this case was to be given at the Government's own behest by the Constitutional Commission, a body set up by the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, in December 1985, nearly 2 1/2 years ago. I say, without, I believe, fear of objective rebuttal, that the body in question is loaded with people of a certain political persuasion such as Mr Edward Gough Whitlam and one or two others, whose political views are clearly known, and, in the cases of some others, who are not of that same political persuasion, by people nevertheless with a clear commitment to what I might call centralist views as to the appropriate nature of our Constitution.

There is a distinction between, let us say, Australian Labor Party affiliations on the one hand and centralist affiliation ideologically on the other. They usually coincide, but they are not what the mathematicians call conterminous. I say this without in any way reflecting upon the Chairman of the Commission, but I would put Sir Maurice Byers clearly in that category. He is entitled to his views but it is clear that in his role as Commonwealth Solicitor-General he was a constitutional centralist, and he has remained so to this day.

I am not, as I say, going to do what the Labor Party always does when it comes into this chamber and does not like the arguments from the other side of the chamber, namely, play the man and not the ball. I am not going to pursue, so to speak, along those lines, the membership of the Constitutional Commission, but I do think it is always important to look at the people who are proposing the arguments, even while, more importantly-and I emphasise that-assessing the quality of the arguments they are proposing.

Since its inception, the Constitutional Commission has spent over $6m of taxpayers' money. Again, I think it is fair and objective and accurate to say that a good deal of that expenditure has been on what can only be called public propaganda. I am not alleging that it is political party propaganda. What I am saying is that it has been propaganda designed to convince the Australian people that our Constitution is a rickety old document, drawn up in the horse and buggy days and that it badly-very badly-needs revision.

I would be the first to concede, as all fair-minded people would, that there are some aspects of our Constitution which no doubt could be revised. Senator Collins, in a speech here a week or two ago, drew particular attention, I think, to section 25 of the Constitution in that respect. If I am recalling correctly and quoting him correctly, I agreed entirely with what he said about that section. Again, I am sure that most honourable senators on both sides of this chamber would do so. There are no doubt other sections of our Constitution which are in that category. That does not make the Constitution a horse and buggy affair or an outdated document, or one which badly and desperately and dramatically needs to be revised. It simply means that that is a particular section of the Constitution which has fallen into disuse and which, therefore, we do not need any longer.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was saying that we on the Opposition side would agree that some aspects of our Constitution no doubt could be revised and about which it would therefore almost certainly be possible quite readily to obtain a consensus among the Australian people about the need for revision, just as in 1967 an overwhelming majority of the Australian people readily agreed to amend our Constitution in respect of Aboriginal affairs matters. What I suggest is conspicuous about the four proposals which this Government is bringing before the Australian people in the next few months is that not one falls within that category of consensus proposals. The fact is that this Government is not about uniting Australians in consensus; it is about dividing us so as to produce the maximum acrimony, the maximum public fuss and bother, and therefore the maximum diversion from the real problems facing Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not an accident, I suggest, that we are debating these Bills in the same week as that in which the Government will bring down its economic statement. Tomorrow night the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will bring down that statement in the other place. It is also less than two weeks before the next Labor Party biennial conference in Hobart. It is being held in the wake of a series of disastrous electoral defeats of the Labor Party, beginning in the Adelaide by-election and, I suppose, reaching a summit in the New South Wales State election. It also follows a confession by the Treasurer as recently ago as 12 May, in his statement to the State Premiers at the Loan Council and Premiers Conference meetings, that the recent improvements in Australia's balance of payments are all due to the improvement in our international terms of trade, in other words, in our export prices-a matter over which the Australian Government exercises no responsibility whatsoever and which, in the Treasurer's own word, is therefore confessed to be `fortuitous'. The dictionary defines that word as `due to chance'. The improvement in our economic situation so far as that is reflected in our balance of payments is, by the Treasurer's own confession, due to chance. It is because the Government knows that it is extremely vulnerable on this whole question of its policies towards the economy, and the fact that it has lost 10 months since it was returned to office after the election of last July, that it has sought to bring before the people of Australia in the next four months a great diversionary tactic in the form of these four referendum Bills.

Viewed with the total cynicism which the Labor Party brings to these matters, that must be conceded to be a very clever piece of politics. But let us not have the kind of overblown rhetoric with which the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, introduced these Bills when he said that they were being introduced in the national interest and having in mind the need to revise and reform our Constitution. I suggest that before the Opposition is through with it, it may prove to have been a tactic too clever by half.

Let me return to the report of the Australian Constitutional Commission. In my analogy in my remarks before dinner I compared it to the kind of report one obtains from the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland, my own State, on the second-hand car which one is about to consider purchasing. That report has not yet been received. The first report from the Commission was published on 6 May-a Friday. The Government produced these four Bills, all printed and ready to go, at the special sitting of the House of Representatives on 10 May, which it had called some weeks earlier. It had finally decided on what Bills would be presented to the Parliament at its Cabinet meeting a week earlier, before the first report of the Commission was even formally received, and certainly before it was read by anybody in this country, including anybody in the Government.

One result of that-and I turn to the first of the Bills before us-is that the proposal for parliamentary terms is not the proposal put forward by the Constitutional Commission. The Constitutional Commission, having examined the second-hand vehicle which the Government is asking us to consider buying, has recommended against it. As we all know now, because we have had a chance to look at the report of the Commission-which, of course, the Government did not have when it made up its mind-it did not put forward that we should have what the Government has proposed, namely, four-year terms with a simultaneous dissolution of both the House of Representatives and the whole of the Senate. It recommended that senators should continue to serve for two terms of the House of Representatives. The Government has chosen to ignore those views. In arriving at those views the Constitutional Commission made it clear that the problems in instituting a four-year term for the House of Representatives-and there are considerable problems; I will come to those-can only be overcome either by extending the terms of senators from six years to eight-this is one possible alternative-or by providing that senators serve for two terms of the House of Representatives.

The Opposition sought advice from a distinguished constitutional lawyer, a man who late last year came very much to the notice of the Australian people because of his role in the dismissal of the Government's fraudulent identity card proposals, namely, Mr Ewart Smith. At the date of his retirement he was a Deputy Secretary in the Attorney-General's Department and a very distinguished public servant.
