In commenting extremely adversely on all of these proposals, Mr Ewart Smith referred to this particular proposal as `the most sinister of all the proposals' being put forward by the Government. He went on to say that while `one can agree in principle that a four-year term has been readily accepted as a proper term for Australia', this will be a great attack and a `diminution of the influence of the Senate'. Why did he use the word `sinister'? It is a very good choice of word because we have in this proposal a purported concern by the Government about the need for a longer term of the House of Representatives. What utter hypocrisy from this Government, which has singularly failed to avail itself of the three-year term available to it for the House of Representatives.

This Government was elected in March 1983. It chose to take Australia to the polls once again 21 months later, in December 1984-less than two years later. In July 1987 it took us to the polls again, even though in the course of doing so it was clearly breaking a promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) given only a few weeks earlier that he would do nothing of the kind. That is the kind of government which is now crying crocodile tears about the need to have longer terms of office for the House of Representatives in this country.

Let us look at a second consideration which might underlie Mr Ewart Smith's description of this proposal as sinister. It is that if this referendum proposal were approved by the people later this year it would in practical terms result in extending the life of the present Government by almost six months. It would do so by extending the term of Senate for that time. Half of the Senate would have to go to an election not later than early June of 1990. Before the suspension of the sittings Senator McMullan in his remarks was very critical of the position of the Opposition in advancing the views I have just advanced. He argued that the Bill did nothing of the kind: it would not extend the life of the Government by six months because, as he said, it would merely extend the date by which otherwise a half Senate election must be held; that is, it would not extend the formal term of the House of Representatives.

Technically, Senator McMullan is correct in that argument but I must say that I was rather surprised that he of all people should advance such an argument in this place. After all, he was Federal Secretary of the Australian Labor Party for many years. He is extremely knowledgeable about any matters touching upon when governments may or may not have elections. I am particularly surprised that Senator McMullan should have advanced the argument he did. He is not in the chamber at the moment but I take the opportunity of saying that I have previously thought that Senator McMullan would not advance such a sophistry, certainly not here in the Senate. He knows perfectly well, and all senators know perfectly well, that no Prime Minister is likely, firstly, to have a half Senate election in, let us say, early June 1990 under the present regime and then follow that almost six months later with a separate House of Representatives election in November 1990.

That is technically possible. It is technically open to the Prime Minister of the day to do that. But no-one who knows anything about these matters, as Senator McMullan supremely does, would imagine for a moment a Prime Minister taking such a course. On the contrary, as Senator McMullan well knows, a Prime Minister would do one of two things. He would either, if he had not done so before, take both House of Representatives and half the Senate out in, say, late 1989 or he would take both Houses out some time in the period of February to May 1990, the early June date being governed by the last date on which half the Senate must go to the people. If this Bill were to be adopted by the Australian people at the referendum, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, could comfortably take both chambers, which in that case would be the House of Representatives and the whole of the Senate-not half the Senate-out as late as November 1990. I hope that Senator McMullan will stop treating us in this chamber, and more importantly the Australian people who may have been listening to his remarks, as though we are a lot of mugs and that he will in future admit that the Opposition is correct when it argues that this proposal, if adopted, would in practice-I emphasise the key words `in practice'-as Senator McMullan well knows, give this Government another almost six months in office.

Apart from those, what are the other objectives of the Government in bringing forward this Bill, which is not even recommended by its own Constitutional Commission? I suggest that there are two other objectives; indeed, these are in some senses the main objectives, apart from extending the possible life of the Government. First, it would give the Prime Minister and hence the Executive arm of government even more power than it already has-the power to intimidate the Senate, to reduce its power, by giving the Prime Minister the power to dismiss it, effectively at any time he chooses. The Australian Labor Party has always hated the Senate, even more so since 1975 when the Senate, in the extraordinary and totally reprehensible circumstances of that time, acted to refuse Supply to Mr Whitlam and his Government, thereby forcing the government of the day to render itself accountable to the electorate of Australia.

The electorate at that time threw that Government out neck and crop. Mr Fraser was elected with a majority of I think 47 or 48 seats. It was the largest single majority received by any government in any Federal election in the history of this country. In other words, the electorate overwhelmingly endorsed the action of the Senate at that time. On that occasion, the Senate did its duty and so, I might add, did the Governor-General in exercising the powers reserved to him under the reserve powers of the Constitution for use in such extreme and extraordinary circumstances.

The Senate again did its duty when the Bill of Rights was brought before the previous Parliament. I remind the Senate that that Bill was whipped through the House of Representatives in a day. It was guillotined through the House of Representatives to prevent substantive debate just as these referendum Bills were guillotined through the House of Representatives in a single day last week before being brought into this place. But when the Bill of Rights came before the Senate, it was properly debated over a lengthy period. Meanwhile the electorate-the people to whom we are in the end responsible-gradually became aware of the true import of the mischievous nonsense this Labor Government was attempting to put over it. It rose up in its righteous wrath and the Government was eventually forced to back down and withdraw the Bill ignominiously.

Before dinner Senate Cooney argued on this point. He said that the Bill of Rights was rejected by the Senate which had been elected at the same time as the House of Representatives and therefore, he argued-making a complete non sequitur in the process of doing so-that this made nonsense of the argument of those who, like myself, point to, as I have just been doing, the importance of the role of the Senate in defeating obnoxious legislation of the Bill of Rights variety. Of course, that totally misses the point. I presume that it was a genuine gap in logic by Senator Cooney because I would not want in any way to suggest that he is guilty of seeking to mislead the electorate or the Senate. The real point is this: if the Senate had then been operating under the constitutional provisions which are now proposed-which of course it was not-and if the Senate had, in those circumstances, dared to thwart the Prime Minister of the day as the Senate then did, the Prime Minister could have sacked the Senate on the spot. He might not have dared to do so in those circumstances because it is possible that he would have feared that the electorate would have done to him what it did to Mr Whitlam in 1975, but I think he might have taken the chance and hoped that the Bill had had so little debate and there was so little public understanding of it that he might have got away with it. That is certainly a consideration which the Senate at the time would have had to have very much in mind when dealing with the Bill.

My time is fast approaching expiry. This illustrates what a totally inadequate process we are now engaged in. We have three major and one minor Bill put before us by the Government and one, I think it is fair to say, major Bill put before us by Senator Macklin. I do not agree with a lot of what is in Senator Macklin's Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill-but it is a major Bill and ought to be given proper consideration. I will not have time to refer to that Bill in my remarks and will not have time to refer to two of the other major Bills. This is what passes for debate on these constitutional proposals tonight in the Senate. It is a travesty of the legislative process, a travesty for which this Government is totally responsible. I hope the people will hold it responsible when they come to vote upon these measures later this year.

I want to devote the last two minutes of my time to dealing with what I can only call the exception to the major Bills description-that is, the Bill which is described as `An Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government'. What a total fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a fraud.

—I see that the Minister for Local Government is suggesting otherwise. I hope she will get up to defend the Bill and explain how it is not a total fraud. The Bill, for those who may not have seen it, consists of two clauses. The first clause cites the short title of the Bill-that is hardly contentious. The second clause states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution is altered by inserting after section 119 the following section:
The whole gist of the section in question is as follows:

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

That is what it says-nothing more than that. It is a total fraud. That section is already recognised in four States of the Commonwealth-only two States of the Commonwealth do not already do that. It does no more than that. It makes local authorities subject to the laws of the State because even this Government recognises that that cannot be otherwise. It is a total fraud. It is a piece of tokenism and window dressing so that the Minister for Local Government can go around the country and hoodwink local authorities by telling them that it recognises them-big deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will send you copies of my speeches.
—I do not have time to respond to the inane interjections from the Minister. I want to say only that this is in line with the attitude this Government brings to these matters.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate as I heard it from Senator Stone mirrors very much, and in places seems to me to be almost word for word, what Senator Chaney had to say and, I would imagine, one way or another what most Opposition spokespeople on this package of Bills will have to say. I simply refer people listening to the debate to speeches by members of the Government for a refutation of those claims by the Opposition. In particular, Senator Tate and Senator Ray, who spoke in this chamber yesterday, put to rest the very spurious claims by the Opposition. I support the four referendum Bills, the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988 and the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988. I want to confine my remarks principally to that Bill that talks about fairer elections. I say to Senator Stone, for the record, that to enable the Opposition to have time to debate, senators on this side are trying to be pithy and succinct and make our points within the time we have allotted ourselves. If he cannot make his points in half an hour, on his head be that problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the Bills very strongly. I want to talk about what I think is the importance of the fairer elections Bill. I have heard it said by the Opposition that this piece of legislation jeopardises States rights. I would like to pick up a point made by Senator Ray in his speech, that to pass any referendum we must have not only a majority of the people but also a majority of the States-an in-built protection of States rights in the way our referendums have to be decided. That point needs to be made. There is, within the terms of how a referendum shall be decided, the very protections for States that the Opposition seems to suggest are under enormous jeopardy if we talk about the one vote one value principle being enshrined in legislation and applicable to all elections in this country.

It is also true that Senator Chaney wanted to argue very strenuously that States rights were particularly under threat. I reiterate the point made by Senator Ray-I would like to make it again-that the determination of a referendum, that is, a majority of States as well as a majority of people, will certainly guarantee those States rights in determining any change to our Constitution. Some people opposite have argued that the fairer election Bill, one vote one value, is really a very subtle way of opposing the gerrymander in Queensland. I see absolutely no subtlety in it at all. It is quite clear; it is one of the things the Government is determined to look at-how appalling it is that within this country people in one of its States do not have the same right to a fair election as do people in the rest of the country.

We should be ashamed. Often that is the word I would use. It is mortifying that this country with its claims of democracy still enshrines in this year-and we are not talking about 100 years ago-after all the tests and changes in other States, this appalling and unfair practice in one of our States. It is to the credit of the Queensland State Liberal leader, Mr Innes, that he has stated that he will support this referendum. I feel like saying that it is about time for the Liberal Party in Queensland but I also think it is proper to appreciate the courage of that decision by Mr Innes. I will just quote a comment that is attributed to him in the Queensland Courier-Mail of 20 May 1988:
I call upon the people of Queensland and Australia to rely on their fundamental sense of justice and fairness to pass the referendum questions.

I do not think it can be put more clearly than that. The Australian people's sense of justice and fairness is the principles or senses that are enshrined in this legislation. It would be very interesting to risk anticipating the outcome of this referendum. I cannot, I suppose, but I suspect that there will be very strong support in the States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, going on past practice. I would have thought that if the Liberals and the Australian Labor Party in Queensland want to strongly get behind this referendum it may well be that we will get the majority of States necessary to pass this referendum and enshrine these principles in our Constitution. It is very heartening that the Liberal leader in Queensland has a position different-I think one would have to say he is in opposition to them-to his Federal colleagues.

It is very curious to note that Senator Chaney said that if he were a Queenslander he would do it that way too. I find it difficult to understand why Senator Chaney would feel that he could vote that way only if he were a Queenslander. He claims he strongly believes in the principle of one vote one value but I am totally unpersuaded when listening to his reasons why he is not going to support it now. My Senate colleague Senator Vanstone and I were debating this very issue at a school in Adelaide last week. Senator Vanstone was arguing the point that States have the power to change the conditions of election within their States and they can do it. But apart from Steele Hall in South Australia, no conservative ever has. It is the Labor Party that has pursued democracy and fairer elections, not the conservatives. By their record and history, they are the party of privilege and their opposition to these referendum proposals shows that they are still the same. But this time they are using tactics of cheap, political opportunism.

Just for the record, although Steele Hall made some steps towards altering the gerrymander in South Australia, he only modified it. He did not go all the way. It was not until the Dunstan Government was returned that we got one vote one value, fairer elections, in South Australia. The conservative Opposition in South Australia continued to frustrate the proposals for electoral reform under the Dunstan Labor Government. The history of how the proposals got through is also quite interesting.

The principles of fairer elections are now in place in most States in Australia. I find it very hard to accept the specious, if not curious and tortuous, arguments of the Opposition in opposing these principles for our Federal Constitution. It is not as though they are novel, it is not as though the Federal Government would be leading the way and it is not as though the Federal arena would be suggesting these things for the first time. Whether it is the four-year terms or the one vote one value principle, they are not novelties for the Australian people. As I say, a majority of States are now already well down the path of both of those principles and in some ways the referendums would simply see reflected in the Federal Constitution those things that many people around the country have already endorsed and had the opportunity to talk about, to debate and to vote on. That is why I also find it difficult to understand why Senator Stone feels that sufficient debate has not happened on this legislation. People have been debating the fairness of elections for years; in fact, there is a consistent and considerable will for fair elections in this country.

One point that Don Dunstan used constantly to make is that the right to fair elections is electorally attractive. People understand what the right to fair elections means and they want to support it at any opportunity they are given. This has been taken up particularly in the States. The Opposition also seems to argue that we are trying to run this as a kind of interference and that we ought to be doing more significant things. That is a very odd claim, given that we are doing the other things as well.

For the record I will just take one example-they are Senator Chaney's words particularly when he was talking about the simultaneous elections proposal which is also being debated here tonight. Senator Chaney opposed simultaneous elections in 1974; he supported them in 1977 and he opposes them in 1988. If one looks for what possible explanation there might be for such a change in his views, it would seem that it depends on whether he is in government or in opposition. I find that totally indefensible. It is totally unimaginable what kind of consistency there is in Senator Chaney's head between being against, for, and against on the same issue over that period. The only difference, as I say, is that he was in government when he supported it and is out of government when he opposed it. I think that approach is very limited and indefensible. It will certainly be something that the people of Australia will appreciate. The Opposition's views about these questions change depending on whether it is in government or not. That is not a very principled stance and it is certainly something that a lot of the people in the country are appreciating more and more. That is why we will find considerable support in the community for these referendum proposals.

One reason I wanted to speak on this package of Bills is that I have had a bit of an interest in the history of women and, in particular, the history of how women got the vote. Any reading of that history will show that it has been a quite extraordinary battle. As a woman in this Senate I acknowledge that battle and the heroic struggle of so many women and the men who supported them. I acknowledge too the importance of the struggle. No woman who has read that history can casually disregard those fiercely fought rights. I certainly do not, though I must say for me the rights for women and the rights for women to get the vote are really no different in kind from the rights for workers, the rights of underprivileged or the rights of non-discrimination for anybody, to name just a few areas. But I do not believe that we can read that history without being moved by it and certainly I am the beneficiary of it.

I draw to the attention of honourable senators the banner in King's Hall painted by an Australian woman and part of the fight for women's suffrage in England. That banner urges Mother England to trust the women with the vote as Australia had trusted its women with it. I recall proudly that that battle for the rights of women to have a vote was first won in my State of South Australia in 1894, though the history shows that it did not happen in a short time. It was a debate well over a decade before that achievement happened in South Australia.

The Official Record of the Debates of the Australasian Federal Convention, Third Session, held in Melbourne on 20 January to 17 March 1898 illustrates just how important the right for women to have the vote was in terms of the arguments prior to Federation. The problem was: How do we deal with people and what sort of franchise would they get in the establishment of the Federation? I will quote part of the debate. At page 1840 Mr Barton is recorded as saying:

. . . I quite agree that any elector who, at the establishment of the Commonwealth or afterwards, has, under the law in force in any state at the establishment of the Commonwealth, the right to vote at elections should not be prevented by any law of the Commonwealth from exercising that right.

This centred around particularly the women who were franchised in South Australia and in 1895 in Western Australia. It was argued that women could not be denied the right to vote in any Commonwealth Parliament if they had that vote in any other parliament. So because they had the right to vote in their States, they could not be denied that right to vote in the new Commonwealth Parliament. This created a problem because women in other States-for example, Victoria and New South Wales-did not have a right to vote in their own States. But after much debate it was agreed that if women had the right to vote in two States and, therefore, the right to vote in the new Commonwealth, things could be tipped completely out of balance if the women in two States had the right to vote, but not the women in all other States. So Australia proceeded to legislate to give women the right to vote in, I believe, 1902.

From very early Australia has given the right to vote to women, but not without some farcical debates. Because they entertained me, I thought I would entertain the Senate with them. I will quote from C. M. H. Clark's A History of Australia, volume V, subtitled `The People Make Laws, 1888-1915'. On page 192 it is stated:
In September 1900 a newspaper to do battle for women appeared for the first time in Melbourne. It was called symbolically the Australian Woman's Sphere and was edited by Vida Goldstein.
Women were arguing the importance of the vote for women. I will read a paragraph from this text, referring to women:

Like Labor they were ballot box democrats. They therefore believed the victory of their cause would begin by winning votes for women. Believing the best way to discredit their opponents was to encourage them to reveal what was in their minds, they filled their columns with the speeches of men such as Sir John Madden, the Chief Justice of Victoria. He had declared in 1895 that women's suffrage would abolish soldiers, war, racing, hunting, football, cricket and all manly games. Sir John based his stand on the Bible: `Thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee'. He spoke of the women's movement as a threat to conventional morality. `Women suffragists', he believed, `are the worst class of socialists. Their idea of freedom is polyandry, free love, lease marriages, and so on. Are those qualifications for the franchise? Are we going to allow women who would sap the very foundation of the nation to have votes?' The Australian Woman's Sphere replied with a list of the men who were not disqualified from voting: effeminate fops, drunkards, larrikins, drunken savages, opium-smoking Chinese, prize fighters, `Fat Man' politicians and wife kickers.

I find it quite entertaining reading. I remind honourable senators that the Chief Justice of Victoria made those comments. Those were the sorts of arguments that shaped the debate then. Since Labor came to office we have heard in this place very similar arguments presented in opposition to the sex discrimination legislation, affirmative action legislation and so on. Much of the prejudice against rights for women still pertains. I have taken some time tonight to endorse strongly the fairer elections Bill, because I think it enshrines those rights so bitterly and harshly fought for and won by women. Clearly I do not argue the rightness of it only in terms of rights for women, but I think that illustrates the battle that has to be fought to enshrine those rights for all people.

While it might be argued that women around Australia have the right to vote, in Queensland they have a right to vote that is not based on an equivalent principle. That is true for both women and men in Queensland. The rest of Australia has arrived at near enough to what I would call an equivalence of that principle of one vote one value. As the earlier debates argued, we have had the opportunity to legislate that principle into our Constitution once and for all. We have not really rushed things since the debates of the first convention. The period from 1898 to 1988 has been a thoughtful period for deliberation about actually legislating to enshrine in our Constitution the rights for everybody over 18 years of age-man, woman, whatever race, et cetera-to have the right to vote enshrined in this Constitution. I think it is a fearsomely fought for principle. It is the mark of democracy. It is something Australia has stood for and fought for. I do not think it is improper at all that we should consider and move to enshrine it in our Constitution.

I endorse the referendum proposals in the other pieces of legislation. I do not want to take time to speak to them in the Senate tonight. I am just pleased to say a few words on behalf of the one vote one value or fairer election principle and I look forward to the day it is part of our Constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the Government proposals for four referendums which we are debating in the Senate this evening. I think the proposals have been well outlined in this debate and in earlier debates in another place and in the Press. I feel that the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, when he led the debate in the Senate yesterday afternoon, expressed very clearly and fully the objections which the Opposition has to each of these four proposals. In fact, there are more than four proposals. One of the cunning aspects of the Government's case is that it is rolling up into one question several different ideas; and people are being asked to answer yes or not to questions which are very complicated. Choices will have to be made, and they will be very difficult choices for many people.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to confine my remarks tonight to addressing the Senate in relation to two major proposals. The first one seriously affects the role, status and powers of the Senate, and the second one seeks to incorporate into the Constitution a mini-Bill of Rights. It is not actually a Bill of Rights. If it is meant to be one, it is a totally inadequate one. I want to address that question in relation to the principle of Bills of Rights and the effect they would have on our federal system.

However, before I deal specifically with those two aspects of these proposals, I would like to make some general remarks about the Government's whole approach to this question of reforming the Constitution. It seems quite clear to me that the Hawke Government has embarked upon a total fraud on the people of Australia. The proposals are fraudulent in two respects. First, they are not genuine or effective reforms of the Constitution. If adopted by referendum, they would not in any way improve the operation of the Federal Parliament or the Federal government; they would not expand in any effective way the liberties and freedoms of the people of Australia; and they do amount to a very clear case of window dressing by a government that has not got the intellectual and moral fortitude to come forward with some realistic and effective amendments to the Constitution if they are thought necessary.

The Government embarked upon this fraudulent exercise, as it has turned out to be, some 2 1/2 years ago when it established a Constitutional Commission, with a great fanfare about the need to make major changes to the Constitution for the bicentennial year. The Commission was given the brief of doing that and reporting on 30 June 1988, which is a short time away. However, the Commission was more than an exercise in rational, sober and even legalistic analysis of a document which has been over 87 years in operation. It may be superficially thought to be in need of major change. The Opposition has never accepted that view. We have believed, and continue to believe, that the Constitution has served Australia very well. Although we do have some proposed changes for the Constitution, we have our own very clear agenda of what changes may be required. We certainly do not believe it requires the sort of root and branch review the Government has embarked upon.

Let me assume for the moment that the proposal to have a root and branch examination of the Constitution with a view to coming up with, if not a new one, a radically different one was genuine. The Constitutional Commission embarked upon this task and it had the assistance of some five advisory committees which worked away and then made their reports in October last year. The Constitutional Commission itself, the peak body, then had the very difficult task of reviewing all those recommendations and coming up with its own final report by 30 June this year.

However, early in January of this year the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, outlined what was until then very clearly the Government's hidden agenda for constitutional change. He did not wait for any interim report or first report of the Commission. He certainly did not wait until 30 June this year when the final report of the Commission would be made. He simply outlined what the Government wanted to achieve, and he even announced then that the Government was thinking about having a referendum to make all these Government changes to the Constitution by the middle of this year. Then the Government announced that there were going to be in this session of Parliament some changes to the Constitution. It did not specify whether they were the same as those outlined early in January by the Attorney-General, but it made it very clear that in this session we would be presented with the Government's proposals. It put its weight on the Constitutional Commission to come up with what we might call its interim report ahead of its final reporting date in order to give some sort of spurious cover for the Government's hidden agenda.

The Constitutional Commission had in fact indicated towards the end of last year its own proposals for reform of the Parliament. That involved fairly complicated procedures in relation to fixed terms of three years for the House of Representatives and the Senate and a fourth year during which Parliament could be brought to an early end by either an election called by the Prime Minister or one forced by the Senate. It also proposed to greatly reduce the powers of the Senate. However, it did not suggest that the Senate's term should be reduced from effectively two terms of the House of Representatives to a period that was exactly conterminous with that of the House of Representatives.

When the Government then decided under great pressure to bring forward its proposal, it entirely ignored those views of the Constitutional Commission in relation to the parliamentary terms and the powers of the Senate. As I said, the Government put the weights on the Commission to make a quick report to it on some further window-dressing proposals about what are now called rights and freedoms, local government and one vote one value. The Commission was put in the embarrassing and difficult position of having to give its views on these matters to the Government way ahead of its scheduled reporting date. It is quite clear that the Government's whole approach to constitutional reform has been one of complete fraud. All along, it had its own proposals, which it has now unveiled and which we are debating tonight.

At the same time, in order to try to further hoodwink the electorate, the Government has given titles to these Bills that are further clear evidence of the Government's fraudulent approach, so much so that Mr Gary Morgan, who runs Morgan gallup polls, the most respected and accurate polling organisation in Australia, has already pointed out that if his organisation asked questions of the electorate in the way the Government is intending to ask questions of the electorate, his organisation would lose all its credibility as an opinion testing organisation. So much for this Government's honesty and integrity in relation to constitutional reform! So much for its respect for the Australian electorate that it is prepared to hoodwink and mislead it and ask it really loaded questions like the one about which Senator Crowley has just been talking, which is called `Fair Elections'!

The electorate will be asked whether it believes in fair elections. Unless people are properly informed on the matter, of course everyone would say `Yes' to whether they want fair elections. The questions does not explain the details of it. It does not explain that it will not stop the sort of gerrymandering of electorates which State Labor governments have been so very good at over the years. In New South Wales, the Wran Government had a gerrymandered system of one vote one value which required the Liberal and National parties to get more than 52 per cent of the vote to win. The Labor Government in Western Australia has just come up with a gerrymandered electoral system which will make it extremely difficult for the Liberal and National parties Opposition to succeed in an election in Western Australia. Labor governments are very good at fixing electoral boundaries to suit themselves. Nothing in the so-called fair elections referendum will prevent the Labor Party, if it is in power, from carrying on in the same way that Labor governments, particularly State governments, have always carried on in Australia. So much for the bona fides of this Government's approach to constitutional reform in general and to the proposals it is putting forward in these Bills in particular.

As I said before, I want to speak about the Government's proposals in relation to parliamentary terms. That is what the referendum is said to be about. The long title of the Bill says that it is `A Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament'. A number of people believe that a four-year term of the House of Representatives would be a good idea. At present, the term is three years. As we know, it is not a fixed term; it is a maximum term. The Government does not propose to change that essential character of it, but simply proposes to extend the maximum from three years to four years.

I do not know how a Prime Minister with the record of Mr Bob Hawke has the gall to come forward saying `I want to do something about these early elections; it is very bad that governments in Australia do not last long because we cannot govern effectively without having a longer term'. That comes from a man who led a government that was elected in March 1983 for a maximum of three years. There did not need to be an election until March, or even later, in 1986. But he dissolved that Parliament when it suited his purpose and had an election on 1 December 1984. So much for his concerns about having fewer elections!

The Prime Minister did one better than that. He was re-elected in December 1984. The term of that Parliament would have run at a maximum until early 1988. The Prime Minister claimed to have some excuse for having an election in December 1984, but without any excuse whatever he called an election last year, in July 1987, only 2 1/2 years into his term. During the period of five years in which the Labor Party has been in office, there have been two elections. The Prime Minister is the man who is saying that it is bad that there are so many elections in Australia, yet he has been the one who has probably had more elections and shorter parliaments than most other Prime Ministers.

Where is the real honesty of purpose in the Prime Minister's proposals? There is no honesty of purpose about this. By having a four-year term, the Prime Minister is playing on the real concern of a number of Australians that parliamentary terms should be longer and that there should be fewer elections. The Prime Minister's real purpose, however, in this proposal has nothing to do with four-year terms for the House of Representatives. His real purpose in this proposal is to implement the long-standing policy of the Labor Party to destroy the Senate.

The Senate is not destroyed by seeking to abolish it; the Labor Party gave that away some time ago. The Senate is destroyed by the steady erosion of its status and powers. In particular, one makes it more accountable and more a creature of the Prime Minister's own power. The one thing that annoys Prime Ministers-and I am not speaking only of Bob Hawke; I am speaking of any Prime Minister-and the one thing that has been a bugbear for them is the fact that the Senate is not a creature of their will.

Prime Ministers love-this is one of the great features of their power-to be able to dissolve a Parliament, the House of Representatives, whenever they want to for whatever political reasons they may have. That is the basis of prime ministerial power. However, the Senate has been created by our Constitution to be as free as possible from such power. It has been given a fixed term of six years. As a House of review, it continues in a normal dissolution. Half the Senate retires every three years, but senators have a term of six years. That can be changed only if there is a double dissolution and that must be the result of a deadlock between the two Houses.

You, Mr Deputy President, have been alert to the abuse of the power of the double dissolution. Prime Ministers, relying on some unfortunate legal advice, have explored the recesses of the Constitution and have discovered that they can have double dissolutions manufactured. They can store up grounds for a double dissolution and can bring the Senate within their power in that way. The real answer to that is to amend the Constitution. The Opposition agrees with you, Mr Deputy President. In fact, you have introduced a Bill to this effect. The Opposition has agreed that there should be a change made to the Constitution to prevent this abuse of power by Prime Ministers to manufacture grounds for a double dissolution, to store them up and to use them when they like. The present Prime Minister does not want that; he wants even to relieve himself of the need for creating grounds for a double dissolution. This proposal is the way he proposes to do it. He wants to make the Senate term equal to the term of the House of Representatives so that he does not have to worry about double dissolutions or about what happens to the Senate; if he wants an early election in the House of Representatives, he will have the most enormous accession of power that any Prime Minister has had in Australia or indeed in any other country because checks and balances are built into constitutions of democratic countries to put a real brake on government by upper Houses.

If the Senate is reduced to exactly the same term as the House of Representatives, it can be dissolved whenever the Prime Minister wants an election. The fundamental pillar of the Senate's strength is cut away and destroyed. That is what the proposal seeks to achieve and what Prime Ministers have dreamt about as long as we have had a Constitution. This will be achieved by fooling the people of Australia into believing this is a simple proposal to have fewer elections to extend the life of Parliament from three years to four years. However, the Government does not state clearly that this whole proposal is designed to destroy the power and position of the Senate.

I shall now deal with the other proposal entitled `Rights and Freedoms'. This proposal amends the Constitution to deal with three matters that are already addressed, to some extent, in the Constitution. The Government is proposing that there should be a guarantee of trial by jury for any person liable for imprisonment for more than two years or any form of corporal punishment. The present guarantee of trial by jury in the Constitution applies only to the Commonwealth laws and is probably not very effective. The proposal will guarantee trial by jury against State laws as well as Commonwealth laws.

The second proposal extends the present guarantee of the acquisition of property on just terms but again it is only in relation to Commonwealth laws to State laws. The third proposal extends the guarantee of freedom of religion from Commonwealth to State laws and, according to the Government, tidies up the guarantee and makes it more effective.

I wish to speak only generally about these proposals because they amount to a mini-Bill of Rights in Australia. As I said, although some reference is made to them in the existing Constitution, they are not particularly effective and not seriously pursued by the founders of the Australian Constitution who did not believe in Bills of Rights. This is not the case with the American Constitution. The proposal of the Government introduces into the Australian Constitution a limited Bill of Rights along the lines of the American Constitution. I shall quote as an example the famous first amendment of the American Constitution:

Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech or of the Press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.

That is a wider, more effective and important proposal than anything the Government has included in this question. If one believes in entrenching a Bill of Rights in a constitution, this is at least an attempt to cover that ground. If one is to have a Bill of Rights, many other rights ought to be included; there ought to be a right of freedom of association and a right not to join a union. One should not be compelled to join a union as the Government of this country compels people to join unions by one form or another. Why does a Bill of Rights for Australia not include a true freedom of association guaranteed to people? Why is there not a guarantee of freedom of speech, freedom of the Press or freedom of assembly? The Government does not tell us why not. It says that it will guarantee the freedom of religion; that is already guaranteed in part by the present Constitution. The Government wants to apply that to the States.

If the Government wants to apply a Bill of Rights in this way, why does it not introduce an effective Bill of Rights? Why introduce a limited one? The Government wants to guarantee just terms for the acquisition of property but why does it not guarantee the right of private property? It is cool comfort to say that just compensation will be paid if one's property is taken away from one but it would be anathema to a socialist government to guarantee freedom to private property. The same applies to freedom of association; a right not to join a trade union is anathema to a government dominated by trade unions. The Government is just not fair dinkum about this so-called Bill of Rights. It is the most limited, pusillanimous and useless piece of window-dressing of a Bill of Rights that I have ever seen or heard of. Why has it been introduced? Why is the Government proposing it? Simply because the whole exercise is one of window-dressing.
If one turns one's mind to consider what might be the result of guaranteeing freedom of religion, the Bill says very much the same as the Constitution in relation to Commonwealth powers in that:

The Commonwealth, a State or a Territory shall not establish any religion, impose any religious observance or prohibit the free exercise of any religion or no religious test shall be required as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth, State or Territory.

An enormous range of questions will arise as to the effect of that. There has been plenty of experience of this in the United States of America. Anyone who is interested should read a very valuable article, of which there are many, on how this guarantee of freedom of religion has operated in the United States. I have not the time left to me tonight to elaborate on this but it has led to an enormous number of cases in the courts of the United States, especially the Supreme Court. Just what it amounts to does not bear much relationship to what might be written down, what we might be agreeing to and what the people might be asked to agree to at a referendum. What it amounts to is simply what the judges of the High Court of Australia might at any time say it amounts to. They will change their minds, the same as judges in the Supreme Court of the United States of America have changed their minds, about what the content of this legislation might be.

We have just had a very good example of the High Court of Australia which, for the last 40 years, has interpreted a provision in our Constitution about freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse, which are said to be absolutely free. For 40 years it has had one interpretation, more or less, of that guarantee. Two weeks ago the High Court stood that on its head. I am not saying that that is right or wrong; all I am saying is that what these freedoms amount to is not what we in this Parliament say they are and not what the people think they are voting for. They are simply what, from time to time, the judges of the High Court of Australia say they are. There may be a majority of four to three. In the United States the decisions of the Supreme Court are a majority of about five judges to four, and they are changed quite frequently. That is what all these so-called guarantees amount to and, as I have said, this legislation is simply a mini-Bill of Rights.

By doing this we are not relying on the democratic process. We are not leaving these decisions to the elected people in this Parliament or State parliaments. We are simply handing over these great powers to unelected judges who, on the records of both the United States and Australia, may change their minds every decade or so as to what they actually mean. But the real objection about these so-called Bills of Rights is that they are not Bills of Rights at all and they are another example of the fraud on the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case some people have just tuned in to listen to the debate I would like to indicate that tonight we are debating five proposed laws-the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988 and one order of the day which is the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987. So we are actually debating four proposed alterations to the Constitution-in other words, four proposed laws. Of course, we have to pass these laws through both Houses of Parliament, as with any other proposed law, but we have the added obligation to take them to the people before the Constitution is altered.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to speak at any length tonight. In fact, I will probably speak for a very short time, but that is not to be taken as an indication that I do not support the first four of these proposed laws that I mentioned just a moment ago. I support each one. It seems to me that these four will be passed through this Senate some time this week, or perhaps early next week, and they will eventually go to the people for their consideration. This being the case, a lot will probably be said by most of us between now and September when these four proposals will be decided upon by the people of Australia. I will certainly be speaking in great detail in respect of one of these proposals throughout the length and breadth of Queensland and I will mention that proposal in a moment.

This evening, the two Bills which I wish to speak about briefly are the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill. I wish to make a few comments about fair elections. I have spoken in this chamber of the need for one vote one value electoral systems on a number of occasions. I suppose that each year for the past three or four years I have probably spoken at least twice. I do not believe, therefore, that it is necessary for me to canvass the issue here again as my point of view is well known. On one occasion I actually drafted a Bill to ensure the existence of one vote one value electoral systems throughout Australia. This Bill never came before the chamber. I certainly took it before my Party and my Party considered that it should be looked at carefully in relation to the possibility of bringing down a constitutional alteration to achieve the same end. I was pleased that I was able to bring this forward because it kept the matter of one vote one value on the political agenda in Queensland. It gave some people an opportunity to bring forward their own Bills as well. Those Bills did not reach this Parliament but they were there for the purposes of discussion.

I have been surprised that the Opposition, especially members of the National Party of Australia, does not want the people to be given the opportunity to vote on this matter. I suppose that when it comes to some proposals which are to be put before the people by way of referendum we could be violently opposed to them and think that it is not proper that they go before the people. I cannot remember that ever happening with any of the proposals that have been put forward by governments of either side while I have been in this place, but I suppose that some people could be so violently opposed to them that they do not want the people to make a decision.

I cannot see why the people should not be able to make a decision on the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill-a Bill which would ensure that various electorates throughout Australia have a somewhat similar number of voters in them. I should mention that the Liberals in Queensland will be campaigning for the fair elections Bill or, as we term it in Queensland, the one vote one value Bill. The Liberals in Queensland want to see an end to the malapportionment in Queensland. A lot has been said about malapportionment and the word gerrymander has been used, but I think it has probably been overused in this debate. Malapportionment is the main problem that we have with regard to electorates in Queensland. Of course, this is not only in Queensland; there are also malapportioned boundaries in other areas. But as a senator for Queensland I am particularly interested in seeing that the malapportionments in the electorates in Queensland are removed. I suppose that one way of doing this is to have them removed by the State parliaments. But one gets into a bit of a catch 22 situation here. If malapportionment favours a particular political party and that party gains power because of those electorates it is very difficult for an opposing political party to gain power and then be able to change those electorates.

We believe that it is one of the fundamental rights of Australians to be able to have an electoral system where one's vote counts the same as anybody else's vote, wherever he may live. The Liberals in Queensland see that there is a disadvantage to them, as a party, because of the way that the electorates are drawn. The small electorates, in terms of the number of electors, generally favour the National Party and not the Liberals. The Liberals feel that, if there were a fair electoral system, they would have a better chance of becoming the government, or perhaps a better chance of becoming the major party in a coalition government. Despite all of the protestations from the National Party, a one vote one value system would make a difference in Queensland. National Party members know that, if they remained in government, under a system of one vote one value they would be the junior party in a coalition government. I suppose that is why they do not want a constitutional requirement that forces their electoral system to be fair.

A number of arguments have been put forward-even before we came to this Bill; I remember that a couple of weeks ago Senator Stone mentioned the subject-for special provisions for people in rural areas. Those arguments do not wash. Parliamentary representatives represent people. If geography demands it, representatives should be given better facilities, electors should not be given more representation. I heard some arguments here today about the electorates of Maranoa and Kennedy. There was a suggestion that the National Party members for those two areas, Mr Katter and Mr Cameron, were not able to service their electorates properly because their electorates are so large. I do not believe that is the case. Mr Bob Katter probably does service his electorate well, even though it is large. Those two areas, or any areas like them, should not have extra members of parliament. Their members of parliament should be given the facilities they need to service their electorates well.

We could do a number of things for large electorates. We could provide extra electorate offices and extra staff for bigger electorates. We could provide better telephone facilities with, perhaps, 008 numbers so that people anywhere in the electorate could contact their member of parliament. We could provide better travel facilities for the members. This is the sort of thing we should be thinking of. There should not be extra members of parliament for areas vast in size.

TALK.START.PARA: —The members for Barker and Kalgoorlie have bigger seats and they haven't been making these complaints, have they?

—I honestly do not think that Mr Ian Cameron and Mr Bob Katter were making many complaints that they could not service their electorates. But Senator Maguire is quite right. There are much larger electorates in Australia and complaints have not come from their members. The point I am trying to make is that, if a member has a large electorate, we give that member the facilities to service that electorate. We do not give it an extra member of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the other Bills we have before us is the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill. Australia has a well developed, three-tier system of government-Federal, State and local. I include the Northern Territory in the State tier of government. The federal system developed from the desire to have a unified Australian government with specified powers. Its basis is the Australian Constitution, part of which the Senate is debating this week. The Federal Parliament has its powers well defined, mainly in section 51 of the Constitution. The Federal Parliament commenced on 1 January 1901 and the first elections were held shortly afterwards. The Federation has now survived for 87 years and, given good will, it should continue. The preamble to the Constitution talks about an `indissoluble Federal Commonwealth'. It says:
WHEREAS the people of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Queensland; and Tasmania . . . have agreed to unite in one indissoluble Federal Commonwealth . . .

We would like to see that continue. The States began as colonies. From about the 1850s onwards each State was given responsible government. The colonies' continuation was assured by the Constitution under the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act, which states:
The ``States'' shall mean such of the colonies of New South Wales, New Zealand-
we sometimes forget that New Zealand was included-
Queensland, Tasmania, Victoria, Western Australia, and South Australia . . . as for the time being are parts of the Commonwealth . . .

So the States are actually recognised in the Constitution. Naturally, from time to time tension arises between the federal body and its constituent parts, but by and large the Federation has served us well. In general, a good partnership exists. Too often it is the leaders of the various constituent parts who create tension. So they are the first two parts of our three-tier system of government-the Federal system and the State system. The States began as colonies. Because of that, the Constitution defined the powers of the Commonwealth and of the States. The third tier, local government, is the closest to the people. There have been several stages in the history of local government in Australia. In the early stages British colonial authorities tried to set up trusts or corporations to share the burden of providing local services. They were concerned about the amount of money that was being spend and wanted to recoup some of it.

The next stage was when colonial parliaments legislated for local authorities to be formed, but such formation was not mandatory. The effective development of local authorities took place only after Federation. Because of that, it is not unusual or unexpected to find no mention of local government in the Constitution. At the time the Constitution was being written local government was only in a fledgling condition. It has increased in stature since. There are now 836 local authorities throughout Australia, which range considerably in size. The Brisbane City Council, for example, has the responsibility for local government services for a city of almost three-quarters of a million people. Others are much smaller, like the Western Australian shire of Upper Gascoyne, which has a total population of fewer than 300.

I can think of no valid reason why local government should not be recognised in the Constitution. The Queensland Liberal senators opposing this Bill should give clear reasons to people such as the Lord Mayor of Brisbane why they are opposing it. The Lord Mayor of Brisbane, a member of the Liberal Party, certainly wants local government to have constitutional recognition. She will be campaigning for that in the forthcoming referendums. I would like the National Party senators to tell the Senate the reasons they will give to the many National Party controlled shires in Queensland country areas as to why they oppose the recognition of local government in the Constitution. We are all waiting for some valid reasons to be given. So are the aldermen, councillors, mayors and shire chairmen. Throughout Queensland and, I expect, in other States, they will be campaigning for constitutional recognition. They will know that they have been dumped so that the Opposition can put forward four No proposals. By putting forward four No proposals when they believe that some proposals deserve support, they are treating the electorate very poorly. They are suggesting that the electorate will not be able to understand the arguments for and against the proposals.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I have probably gone on even longer than I anticipated. I wanted to be brief. The earlier we can get these proposals to the vote, the better. I suggest to the people of Australia-I suppose that I direct my suggestions to the people of Queensland, the people whom I represent, more than to the remainder of Australia-that they look at all the proposals carefully between now and the day on which we vote on them, perhaps in September this year. I suggest that we should see a Yes vote for all. I hope that the people of Australia weigh the pros and cons of these proposals and make up their own minds, irrespective of some of the misleading arguments that will probably be put forward within the next six months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is tonight debating a number of proposed changes to the Constitution-the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988 and the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988. The fifth Bill is not a Government initiative but was introduced by Senator Macklin-the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987. I suggest that we all have different views on the state of the current Constitution. I think that the time is approaching for a major restructuring of our Constitution. The present Constitution, like all political documents, is a compromise-a compromise, I remind honourable senators, that was necessary to bring six separate sovereign colonies together into one nation. Thus it was all about what powers those separate political entities were prepared to give away to gain certain perceived advantages in nationhood-of course, the major advantage that was sought related to defence-and also what powers they were prepared, not to give away totally, but to share concurrently, what they wished to retain exclusively, and what securities they needed to enter such a compact.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the nation grew out of the States colours the Australian Constitution from beginning to end. The protection for the States lay, I would suggest, in these methods of protection: firstly, in the limited powers that were given up to the Commonwealth; secondly, by the fact that the Constitution was to be so difficult to alter that it would require not only a majority of Australians but a majority of Australians in a majority of States; and thirdly, the security of a Senate with extraordinary powers based on equality of each State rather than equality of power to each Australian voter. How the Commonwealth would function vis-a-vis the States and vice versa was the preoccupation of the founding fathers, as reflected in that document.

When we talk about the Australian Constitution we are talking about a bargain reached almost a century ago. In its objective of limiting the power of the new Commonwealth it has to some extent worked. It succeeded in limiting such power. However, as time has gone by I think more and more have looked at the Commonwealth not simply as something that has arisen out of the separate colonies but as a national perspective in itself. As years have gone by attempts have been made of an extra constitutional nature to turn that national perspective into a reality. Thus fictions have developed to extend the powers of the Constitution. A classic example is in relation to industrial relations where fictions had to develop to extend the power of the Commonwealth beyond that technically included, which is limited to interstate disputes.

We have seen the Commonwealth come to use the power of the purse-its monetary powers-to require States to meet national economic objectives. It uses the power of controlling the majority of taxation in this country to guide the States in certain economic directions rather than rely upon constitutional powers that are included in the document we are debating tonight. Judges have largely been prepared to interpret the Constitution according to what they perceive to be contemporary standards and values. Thus we have experienced the most dramatic case of the Commonwealth using the external affairs power and, in particular, treaties that have been entered into under that power to allow the Commonwealth to regulate matters concerning the environment. Similarly, we had the example of Fraser Island. The Commonwealth was able to use the trade and commerce power to stop sand mining on Fraser Island-again to influence a matter concerning the environment. This is somewhat beyond a reasonable interpretation of the terms in which the Constitution was entered into almost a century ago.

I suggest that this willingness of the High Court of Australia to interpret the Constitution according to contemporary standards and values has removed what might have been considerably more stress upon the document during the intervening period. That is not said in an attempt to evaluate the wisdom of either of those two examples, but I think it happens to be a fact. We should not, however, continually rely upon fictions, financial influence or passing the buck to the judges. There should be more cases in which we can turn to the Constitution to provide the correct answers in contemporary Australia. In my view there should be reflected in the new Constitution the relationship and form of government that can best take Australia into the next century.

The founding fathers devised a formula of compromise that could bring the colonies together into a nation. That has lasted us for almost a century. We should now be vigorously debating the relationship that can best serve Australia's interests during the next century. It has been practically impossible to update the Constitution on a bit-by-bit basis. Too often changes have been motivated by political perceptions of the party in government. I suppose that that is not really surprising, but it has meant that too often they have been open to attack on that basis and the special majority that is required to pass the referendum simply has not been achieved.

Rarely, on a similar basis, have we found that the constitutional conventions-and there have been six conventions between 1973 and 1987-have been able to reach a consensus that would sufficiently motivate change. That might not be solely the fault of those politicians-Federal, State and, in the later stages, local government-who debated at those conventions. There is an argument that they were not allowed sufficient resources and were not given sufficient priorities. At the two conventions that I attended, in Adelaide and Brisbane-although regrettably not as a delegate but because of an interest in the subject-I saw those conventions dominated by party-political, set piece speeches. I believe that debates in the preceding conventions went much the same way.

Therefore, in light of what I think has been a failure of that process to lead to constructive reform, I do not condemn the Government for looking for an alternative method of bringing the subject matter to debate, another formula that would allow an increase in public awareness of the issues involved and a further opportunity for public consultation. The mechanism that was chosen by this Government to allow that community debate was the Constitutional Commission and a series of advisory committees on the Australian judicial system, distribution of powers, executive government, individual and democratic rights under the Constitution, trade and national economic management. In other words, the responsibility for raising the issues for public consideration and putting certain views was passed to a committee of experts rather than to the traditional conventions of politicians. As I said, I do not condemn it for doing so. It has cost a great deal of money-I think about $6m. Nevertheless, this subject is critical to the future of this country. If it had worked and if it had been accepted, it could have been a worthwhile exercise.

I read the advisory committee reports. I have read the first report of the Commission. It is my assessment that the men and women who have contributed to these reports have made a significant contribution to the debate. I commend them for their work. I object to the way in which this Government has debased their work. This Government was not even prepared to wait for the second of its own Commission's reports. It determined a set of referendums that were to be put to the people and announced them only four days after the first report was put down. In other words, this Government decided what it wanted to do without any consideration of what the Commission would say. Those who contributed to that work must feel disappointed. They now realise that they have been simply used as tools by this Government in its political agenda. That they have been so cynically treated I think is a great disappointment.

Having set up the structure and having expended very large sums of taxpayers money, the Government should have awaited the final reports and should have looked at ways of then letting there be a continuing public debate and at ways of arousing public debate. It could have referred some of the suggestions back to this Parliament in the same way that there was a Joint Parliamentary Committee on Constitutional Reform in 1959. It could have used these reports as a basis for further consideration within this Parliament and then hopefully the development of a public perception as we move towards the next century. Perhaps out of that could have developed the possibility of a new Constitution to deal, as I said earlier, with contemporary Australia and contemporary problems. But this Government has undermined the work of these people by its impatience, as is shown in the first of these amendments, and its continued bitterness at and preoccupation with the events of 1975. Obviously it has attempted to lock into the spirit of goodwill which has been engendered by the bicentennial celebrations but it has jumped the gun and largely destroyed what in my view could have been a really worthwhile exercise.

The first of these proposals, which is designed to extend the term of the House of Representatives to a maximum of four years, is not so much that but an attempt by the Government to bring the Senate under the direct control of the Prime Minister; in other words, under the control of the government of the day. As I indicated, it refers back to this preoccupation that Labor has had since 1975. The other issues simply follow from that. The camouflage for an attempt by the Prime Minister to control the Senate in this instance is the opportunity for Australians to vote for a four-year term. I and my Party would be supporting a four-year term for the House of Representatives if it were not locked in with an attempt to control the Senate in this way to reduce the independence of the Senate.

When we look at the events which are occurring elsewhere in the world we recognise that there are very few parliaments which have terms in the House of the people of three years or less: in fact, if we look at the report of the Government's own Commission it reminds us that there are only 12 such parliaments out of a total of 143 which are listed with the Inter-Parliamentary Union in Geneva. We find that all State legislatures in Australia except Queensland have changed to a four-year system. We would have been prepared to accept four-year terms per se for the lower House. I know I am on the record in this chamber as supporting fixed terms-a view not necessarily popular on my side-but I think we can now say the experiment in South Australia and Victoria for a maximum four-year term with the first three years fixed seems to be working satisfactorily. These are the sorts of sensible points which this Government could have raised for consideration if it had not been preoccupied with the destruction of the Senate.

If the Senate simply became an imitation of the House of Representatives, it would soon founder. It is my very genuine belief, not only because I am here, that the nation would be the loser in such circumstances. I accept that party politics soon destroyed the founding fathers' notion of the Senate purely as a States House, particularly with the conform or perish discipline of the Australian Labor Party. But the role that this Senate has developed-pressing government accountability both in the financial field and in legislation through the Estimates and standing committee systems-I believe has given it an inestimable value to this nation.

There are other answers to the problems of 1975. There are other ways perhaps to increase accountability-not satisfactory to this Government, I know. One way that I have accepted in constitutional debates before in this place is a reform that would require the Senate, in the event of blocking Supply, also to be obliged to go to the people; in other words, to have to account to the people for its action and not simply have the power, according to the timing, to be able to send the House to the people and not suffer their judgment as well. If this Government had put that constructive proposal to us today it might well have found support, but it chose not to. I regret to say that the balance of the proposals before us are simply there not to portray any great vision or to show leadership but purely for cynical political objectives.

The second proposal, the notion of one vote one value, clearly has been designed in an attempt to split the coalition, particularly in relation to the Queensland situation. The objective of achieving a split does not relate to the second referendum: the Government thinks that if it can split the Opposition on that issue it has more chance of being successful on the first proposal, which relates to the destruction of the Senate. As a Liberal I of course support the principle of one vote one value. All Liberals support that. I am pleased that we are down to a reasonable tolerance in this chamber and in the lower House in my home State of South Australia. I hope that one day Queensland will be in the same position. But matters do not simply end at that stage of one vote one value. Even in this Bill a tolerance of 20 per cent is allowed. As we all know, even if there is not any tolerance at all, the location of the boundaries can determine which party will win the majority of seats, as we find in the lower House of South Australia. So, on the face of it, there may be no gerrymander. The Liberal Party, my Party, in South Australia has to achieve considerably more than 50 per cent of the vote-there is some argument about how much more-to be able to win, as I have argued, simply because of where the boundaries have been placed. So it is not as simple as the Government makes out.

The hypocrisy is quite incredible. The Labor Party could simply reflect on how it preselects its candidates in South Australia, how it operates the card vote system, when approximately 250 delegates turn up-Senator Maguire will be able to confirm this-and are able to cast 160,000 votes because each union delegate comes in with an almighty wad of union member votes. The union members are not asked which way they wish to vote. They are simply recorded as voting according to the determination of the union. If that could be described in this place as one vote one value, or fair elections, I would be very surprised. I doubt that even Senator Maguire would say that that is democracy. So the Labor Party puts this matter forward in its hypocritical way. One can have little faith in its motives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they putting up one vote one value on the new Aboriginal councils?

—I would not think so. Let me continue with this sad tale, before I run out of time. The third of the referendum proposals is the local government one, an amendment that can be described only as shallow, with shallow rhetoric. Shallow rhetoric is not the function of the Constitution. What is local government going to get from this amendment that it does not presently have? The answer, of course, is nothing. Local government was created out of the States; it exists out of the States and constitutionally is recognised in four of the States. What does it get from this referendum? It in fact gets nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: Probably the time has come for a serious debate on where local government should fit into the total constitutional structure of Australia. Should it simply continue to be the child of the States? Perhaps the time has come for us to seriously look at a three-tiered system of government-but it will not get if from this amendment. It will still be accountable to and able to be dismissed by the States. That is not what local government was really seeking. This amendment, as I said, is purely one of shallow rhetoric attempting to dress up particularly the first of the amendments put before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —That excludes the Territories.

—Yes, it does. The last of the Government's proposals before us relates to three basic freedoms. I can only repeat the criticism that was made in the speech before last by my colleague, Senator Durack. If this Government were serious about listing specified freedoms how did it happen to pick these three? Why did it not pick others such as freedom of association, the one Senator Durack mentioned? I remind this Government that it ought to look at the first report of the Commission it set up. What did it recommend? It recommended that if the Government is to start listing rights, it should list the freedom of association. But this Government would not list that because it would put in jeopardy compulsory unionism. The Government was not going to go down the path where it could be argued that the provision could be interpreted as allowing, providing, securing voluntary unionism.

SPEECH.PARA: If I might be excused for being somewhat cynical, one need only briefly reflect on that to realise that the motives of this Government are purely political and not designed to provide a better constitutional framework for use into the next century. I say that as someone who thinks that perhaps the time is coming when either a package of basic freedoms should be incorporated-but it would need to be a fair package-or, as the Commission considered, guarantees within the Constitution of democratic processes. They are principally the reasons why I do not believe that these referendum proposals deserve support.

In the last few minutes I want to look at a few of the areas that this Government would have brought to the people for consideration through any of the various methods available that need now seriously to be addressed in proper constitutional reform.
