Most of them have been raised in advisory committee reports and in the Constitutional Commission's first report. But, of course, they are not being put to the people. The first relates to this question of whether there should be constitutional limitations on excesses of power by governments. As I said, I have some sympathy with that position.

I give an example of why I think there is a growing undermining of traditional freedoms. Let us look at the presumption of innocence until proven guilty, something we would accept as a basic freedom and security. There is no doubt that there is a growing tendency towards the reverse onus of proof, and other mechanisms that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has brought to our attention. These things are undermining that basic presumption of innocence. Perhaps we should have stricture placed upon us so that we do not find it so easy for administrative reasons, however sound they might seem to be at the time, to act to the contrary.

Perhaps there should also be a provision preventing the Commonwealth or States from compelling self-incrimination. It is so tempting, particularly if we are looking at the scourge of organised crime, to depart from traditional safeguards and, on a balance of evil, determine that the self-incrimination rule be waived. It has happened to some extent in relation to the National Crime Authority. Certainly one cannot directly incriminate oneself but one can be obliged to answer questions that indirectly will produce the evidence to incriminate one. Thirdly, a prohibition against unreasonable search and seizure might well now be worthy of consideration. The more one considers the evidence being put before the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, the more one is forced to concentrate one's mind on this issue. Constitutional safeguards would, as I indicated, be a formal restraint that perhaps we should now be considering.

Time is running away but I wanted to mention a couple more possible areas of reform. Opinions may differ, but I would like to see the Commonwealth have a concurrent power with the States over industrial relations and employment matters generally. I remind the chamber that that was recommended by the advisory committee. It would get rid of all the fictions, settle unclear questions of how far the Commonwealth's power goes and allow the Commonwealth to face up to the matters of wages and conditions of work, questions critical to national economic management. Another area is that of treaties. I have spoken of the divisive conclusions in relation to Commonwealth power over treaties that we have seen in the courts in recent years. If we believe that the Constitution should include a power to implement treaties, we should say so. There are other methods of doing that, such as using a treaties council as recommended by the advisory committee.

We could be using this exercise to look forward and put into place, as I said, structures for the next century. One area is in relation to the nuclear industry, which was also raised by this Commission's inquiry. Perhaps we should now be putting into place a power for the Commonwealth to regulate the nuclear industry of the future. That clearly should be a national responsibility. It was not thought of by the founding fathers nearly a century ago but we should be thinking about it now. In corporate law, the powers of the Commonwealth are arguable. This Senate, through one of its committees, has received an opinion from a leading silk that the Commonwealth could legislate for a national companies scheme, but it remains arguable. I am not going to enter into argument at the moment on the merits of such legislation, but the thought of the Commonwealth doing that, with everything that is involved, then having it founder before the courts, is crazy. Therefore, I would have thought there to be a good argument for the Commonwealth to be given specific powers, concurrent with the States, to make laws about all aspects of corporate activity and the securities industry.

Similarly, the Commonwealth could cover all areas of trade practices questions, not only those that relate to corporations. Perhaps it is more arguable whether the Commonwealth should have power in relation to standard, uniform consumer protection laws. One can keep going on-but I have not time today-with other examples such as excise taxes. Should the States have power over excises? Is it time to again constitutionally restructure the financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States? Should we look at the judicial system that has built up? Should it now become an integrated system? These are important debates that we ought to be considering in this chamber tonight. One could go on. The power to protect the environment and human rights should be debated. These are just a few examples that I wanted to sketch tonight as to what this Government could have been constructively doing in this debate. I regret that it has not been prepared to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of Senator Hill's speech I welcomed what I thought was going to be some sense and analysis in what hitherto has been a pretty messy and distorted debate. I thought from this urbane and sophisticated South Australian we might hear something a little better. Certainly he started out that way-in his recognition of the failure of the constitutional conventions to achieve anything, and his acceptance of the work of the Constitutional Commission, its establishment and the quality of the work that it has produced, although his criticism of the timing of the referendum proposals rang a little hollow. Does he seriously contend that had we changed the timing of those referendum proposals the Opposition would have rushed to support the Government? I think not, because he went on to suggest that unless the Opposition's conditions were met, it would not have supported the Government in any case. It is common knowledge that campaign committees had been established around the country well and truly before we had even introduced the referendum proposals. So that lends the lie to that.

SPEECH.PARA: I was disappointed that what I thought was going to be a serious attempt at analysis quickly degenerated into the normal loose and sloppy argument which has characterised the Opposition's contribution to this debate since the beginning. Seldom have I heard such excessive, distorted nonsense about what is a moderate and sensible set of proposals, not only from Senator Hill, but from all those on the Opposition benches who have spoken in this debate. It says more about the sorry state of the Opposition than the substance of the arguments that it is purporting to present. It seems to be a desperate--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are waiting for your substance.

—Honourable senators will hear it in due course. It seems to be a desperate attempt to hold together what is clearly a shaky Opposition coalition. Members of the Opposition are prepared to discard principle for what they see as short-term political gain. I will quote from an excellent article in the Weekend Australian of 14-15 May by Paul Kelly:

SPEECH.PARA: The sad state of the Liberal and National parties will be paraded for the next four months in the sham campaign they will run against the Hawke Government's referendum package to be put to the voters in September.
The fact is that the four referendum proposals are modest and in any other circumstances and with any other Opposition they would be unexceptional. The article continues:

The Hawke Government's referendums are modest, simple and lack ulterior motives. This is no Labor Party political fix. Labor may even lose in the Senate in the short term if the main question is passed. The proposals are a bid to secure moderate constitutional reform around a set of propositions that should have wide support.

Contrary to the claims of members of the Opposition none of the four referenda Bills delivers any more power to government. They do not concern the power of politicians or political parties; the concern guarantees for the rights of people.

I want to focus on two of the Bills-the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill. Both are portrayed by the Opposition as some sort of heinous accretion of power by the Federal Government. I will take the second Bill first. The Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill was designed to put into practice a principle for which there has in the past been bipartisan support. That is the principle of one vote one value, a principle that one person's vote should not be more powerful than another's. It is a principle which is supported by the constitutional conventions referred to by Senator Hill, by the Constitutional Commission, also referred to by him, and by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters which delivered its report One Vote, One Value only last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you not apply it to the Aborigines?

—We are talking here about the Federal Constitution. I thought Senator Tambling realised that. It applies to the House of Representatives and it applies with bipartisan support to this House. It applies in the States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia where variations from the average quota of 10 per cent are the case and it applies in the Northern Territory where a variation of 20 per cent still gets close to the concept of one vote one value. Yet in Western Australia, in Queensland and in the upper House in Tasmania, the situation is far removed from this principle.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I come from Western Australia, let us have a look at the situation in that State. Despite reforms in 1987 which led to marginal improvements in the situation there, it still remains the case that the smallest electorate in Western Australia has an enrolment of 9,046 electors and the largest an enrolment of 21,937. By what stretch of the imagination can this be called fair or democratic? By what distortion of logic does one ever call that fair and democratic? A voter in one electorate has less than half the voting strength of a voter in the other. In the Legislative Council in that same State the situation is even worse. The smallest electorate has an enrolment of 11,989; the largest an enrolment of 39,786. A voter in the smaller electorate has over three times more voting power than a voter in the larger electorate. Both Mr Howard in the other House and Senator Chaney have made much of the point that the then Premier, Brian Burke, in 1985 asked the Federal Government to leave electoral reform to the State. They interpret that as being an argument for States rights. He did initially, but Senator Chaney and Mr Howard both conveniently failed to mention Mr Burke's change of view following successive attempts at electoral reform. I will quote from page 47 of the report, One Vote, One Value, tabled last week by the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters. Mr Burke makes these comments with regard to the new system:

It does not bring me any pleasure to note that the general picture of enrolment imbalances in Western Australia's system remains the worst in Australia. That we are happy to call it reform might give some measure of the injustice inherent in the previous system.
He concluded:
Now that an improved structure has been adopted it is clear that the case for reform is different. The next step is to remove from the system the unacceptable malapportionment which remains.
It is not easy, however, to see how further reforms may occur in the near future . . .

It has been demonstrated that the present Western Australian Parliament is prepared to go no further towards the removal of malapportionment and that unless another major party accepts the fairness of equal enrolments per member, future Parliaments may also make little progress.

In these circumstances, the Western Australian Government thanks the Commonwealth Government for the additional time in which every effort has been made at the State level to, `put our Houses in order'.

Clearly from that Mr Burke had attempted on several occasions to achieve some form of reasonable electoral reform in Western Australia. He had got some moderate reform last year, but concluded that that could not be called reform and washed his hands of the Western Australian system and handed it over to us. Mr Howard and Senator Chaney are quite wrong and quite selective in their quotations.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not appeal to the Federal Government to come in and help.

—He has made it quite clear what he means. If Senator Boswell cannot read that, I am not surprised. If Senator Boswell cannot see what Mr Burke is saying in that statement, then while I am not surprised, I suggest he read it again. There is no doubt that neither the Liberal Party of Australia nor the National Party of Australia in Western Australia has any intention of permitting any further reform. As they have, by the malapportionment that I have already referred to and by other democratic means over the years, controlled the Legislative Council since its establishment-in other words, the Australian Labor Party has never had control and is never likely to have control even under the reformed situation that currently exists-there is absolutely no likelihood of reform. A similar position pertains in Queensland where only 39 per cent of electors gave the National Party government in its own right. How do those opposite claim that that is fair and democratic? How can the Opposition parties justify this gross denial of democracy?
—Do you think a party which got 41 per cent of the vote should govern? That is what the Labor Party got last time.
—Did I say anything about the Labor Party gaining government the last time? What I said was that the National Party gained government in its own right with a vote of 39 per cent.
—But it got Liberal preferences.
—If that is democracy, then I will go he.
—Order! Senator Boswell, I ask you to refrain from interjecting and I ask Senator Beahan to address the Chair.

—It is not a question of States rights; it is a question of individual rights. Both the Constitutional Commission and the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters regarded the latter as more important and believe that the people should have a right to choose. That is what this referendum proposal is all about. Senator Chaney also makes much of the fact that the principle of one vote one value does not apply to the Senate. He therefore implies that it should not apply anywhere else. Whilst this is true, it needs to be remembered-and I indicated this in my address to this House last week-that this was an historical compromise. The Senate was set up as a States House and a number of compromises were made in order to gain acceptance by the States, or by the provinces before they became States, of the idea of Federation. So those compromises were part of that, but it was also clearly in the Constitution a States House. No such historical or constitutional justifications for malapportionment exist anywhere else in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) proposal. As with the one vote one value proposal, this one also has strong public support. It has the support of the business community and it had the support of the Liberal Party until some of its members, not all of them, saw some cynical advantage in opposing it at this time. I say `some of them' because there is a whole group of people who are making statements to the Press and who are making it quite clear around the lobbies here that they are a bit ashamed and embarrassed by what is happening. The advantages of four-year terms have been canvassed by other speakers, and also very eloquently by the Business Council of Australia. To summarise these advantages, they include, firstly, a reduction in the frequency of elections. I remind honourable senators that there have been 22 Federal elections since 1945. That makes an average term for each government of less than 2 1/2 years in that time.

The second advantage that is referred to is the greater stability of government, which was addressed by a number of speakers and by Senator McMullan when I was in here earlier on. The comments made by economists in regard to that question of stability are I think a major argument in its favour. The third is the capacity for longer term planning, also referred to by economists, but referred to particularly by the Business Council of Australia, to which I would have thought the Opposition would have listened a little more carefully. Its analysis states:

It can hardly be said that we have responsible government when important, even necessary, decisions are postponed because the Government has to consider their effects on forthcoming Federal and State elections . . .

Governments have a dilemma in holding their economic nerve during a relatively short electoral cycle. The false and dangerous notion that what is good economics is not necessarily good politics is one directly related to the shortness of the Australian electoral cycle.
As I have said, I am disappointed that the strong supporters of the Business Council of Australia that I know exist on the other side of this chamber have not listened more carefully to it.

The fourth advantage is the reduction in costs. The 1987 double dissolution cost $47m. A half Senate election costs between $35m and $40m. So there is a cost saving in the reduction in elections. The fifth advantage is consistency with State and overseas patterns when it comes to terms of parliament. Again, New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania all have four-year terms. Queensland remains as the one State standing out along with the Commonwealth as having three-year terms. Most overseas countries have four-year terms, and many have five-year terms. In fact quite a substantial number have five-year terms. Very few, in fact only two, I think Mexico and Sweden, have three-year terms.

The Opposition's confused position in relation to eight-year terms is, I believe, a sham. It knows that a proposal for eight-year terms, either fixed or double the term of the House of Representatives-it has never made it clear which one it means-would be rejected by the people. Senator Ray drew attention to a long list of Opposition spokesmen who were on record as opposing an eight-year term for senators as simply too long. This is not an exhaustive list. I have not gone further but I understand there are many more people. Without reciting those people, let me go through the list once again. It includes Mr Sinclair, Senator Durack, Senator Chaney, Mr Spender, Mr Newman, Mr Anthony, Mr Hodgman, Mr Burr, Senator Lewis, Senator Withers and Senator Archer. It is quite interesting to see Senator Puplick in here because he is not on the speakers list, despite an espoused interest in this area on many previous occasions. I am wondering why that is the case. (Quorum formed) As that rather childish quorum was called in order to take the point that I was asking for more speakers from the Opposition, let me make it clear that I was simply calling attention to the selection of the Opposition's speakers. I will cut my speech short. There is nothing sacrosanct or immutable about the Constitution. As Thomas Jefferson said:

``Some men look at constitutions with sanctimonious reverence, and deem them like the Ark of the Covenant, too sacred to be touched. They ascribe to the men of the preceding age a wisdom more than human, and suppose what they did to be beyond amendment . . . We might as well require a man to wear the coat that fitted him as a boy, as civilised society to remain ever under the regime of their ancestors.''

The Opposition parties are positioning themselves, I believe, as constitutional troglodytes, milling around in bemused disarray while the world passes them by. Difficult as it is, I believe the people of Australia will see through the narrow self interest of the Opposition's arguments and carry these and the other two referenda proposals, to which I have not referred, to the continual shame and humiliation of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not know whether I am pleased or sorry that I heard only a part of Senator Beahan's speech. On balance, I think I am pleased, but the bit I heard contained a misrepresentation of the arguments I put to this place and, therefore, I wish to make a personal explanation. Senator Beahan, as I heard him when I was listening to the debate from my office, made a comment to the effect that I had said that no regard should be had for the principle of one vote one value. That is a gross misrepresentation of what I said in debate on the constitutional amendments yesterday. I said that it is an important principle in determining electoral redistribution, but that it is not an immutable, solo or single principle. It is one of the principles to which regard should be had.

SPEECH.PARA: I made the point that when one looked at the composition of both the Senate and the House of Representatives, one found quite dramatic disparities between the weight and the number of votes that were available in the different electorates. I pointed out that in the House of Representatives, for example, the guaranteed representation of five seats for Tasmania-a guarantee which I and, so far as I know, all Opposition senators and I suspect all Government senators would also support-results in that State having a quota base below the magic figure of 10 per cent, which is specified in the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill and that, therefore, the principle of a tolerance of no greater than 10 per cent is not being imposed on the House of Representatives.

In exactly the same way in the Senate, of course, there is a far more sharp discrepancy with some States being as much as 65 per cent above the average number of electors per senator as against other States which are 81 per cent below the average. That is an extraordinarily different situation. The point I was making is that in the judgment of both our historic forebears and of present members of Parliament and, indeed, of the Australian community, that sort of imbalance is not seen as something which requires correction by means of this constitutional amendment.

The situation is, therefore, that this Government is choosing to impose a rule, which is the point I made, of one vote one value on the States which it is not prepared to apply to the Federal Parliament. That is the point I made, and I drew the parallel with Western Australia, which Senator Beahan is also supposed to represent. I made the point that if one had any comprehension of the geography and population of that State, to deny the right of the State of Western Australia to have any degree of regional representation in the upper House is absolutely pathetic and absurd.

If one looks at the discrepancy between the Kimberley and the South West Land Division, and the South West Land Division and the metropolitan area, to argue that one can have nothing akin to a regional representation of the sort that Australia has for the whole of its nation is, in my view, not a tenable proposition. That is the point I made, which is not the point Senator Beahan chose to ascribe to me--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is much worse.

—In some future contribution, I would like Senator Beahan to make the point for the edification of the Senate whether he believes the Senate should be changed, whether one vote one value should be applied to the Senate, and whether he believes the representation of Tasmania should be reduced so that there is one vote one value in the House of Representatives, or whether he--
—You have just about exhausted a personal explanation.
—I think Senator Evans is right but, on the other hand, Senator Beahan chose to debate my personal explanation and I was easily misled by the disorderly conduct of Senator Beahan.
—Interjections are disorderly.

—I am glad Senator Evans has reminded Senator Beahan that interjections are disorderly. Since Senator Evans is now engaged in disorderly conduct, I should bring the personal explanation to a close to avoid giving him further temptation.

DEBATE.TITLE: ANTI-DUMPING AUTHORITY BILL 1988CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS) BILL 1988CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
These three Bills form a legislative package, amending Australia's anti-dumping legislation, by:

establishing an Anti-Dumping Authority, to advise the Minister as to whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed on specified products exported from overseas and to review and make reports to the Government on anti-dumping matters;

amending the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975, so as to restrict the life of dumping notices and undertakings made under the Act to a maximum of three years, and to clarify various technical provisions of the Act;
amending the Customs Act 1901 by prescribing the manner in which the Australian Customs Service is to conduct the preliminary investigation of dumping complaints; and
amending the IAC Act 1973 to remove that body as a body of review of dumping matters; that function will now be performed by the Anti-Dumping Authority.
The Bill implements the Government's response to the 1986 Review of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 (the Gruen Report), prepared by Professor F. H. Gruen.

Dumping occurs when the products of one country are exported to another country at less than their normal value in the country of export. Normal value is usually the price of like goods sold in the ordinary course of trade for consumption in the country of export.

Dumping is condemned internationally as unfair trading if it causes, or threatens, material injury to the industry producing like goods in the importing country. The remedy against dumping is the imposition of dumping duties which can be up to the difference between the export price and the normal value.

Australia's anti-dumping system also deals with subsidisation. Where any subsidy, bounty, reduction or remission of freight or other financial assistance applies to the production, export or carriage of goods exported to Australia and those goods cause or threaten material injury to an Australian industry, countervailing duties, up to the amount of subsidy or other assistance received, may be levied.

Effective anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements are necessary to protect Australian industry from clearly unfair trading practices. This is in accordance with Australia's rights and obligations as a signatory to the GATT anti-dumping code and the code on subsidies and countervailing duties. Other signatories to the codes such as Canada, the EEC and the United States employ similar practices.

Consistent with the GATT codes, however, anti-dumping actions need to be balanced between providing a means for effective relief from the disruptive effects that dumped or subsidised goods may have on domestic producers and ensuring that the measures do not constitute an unjustifiable impediment to international trade.

Upon this Government coming to office in 1983, a wide-ranging review was conducted, culminating early in 1984 in a number of significant legislative and administrative changes to the anti-dumping regime.

Then in February 1986 the Government commissioned Professor F. H. Gruen of the Australian National University to conduct another review of the anti-dumping system to determine whether further improvements could be made and in particular to consider the inclusion of a national interest provision.
After considering Professor Gruen's report, the Government has decided to:
Establish an Anti-Dumping Authority to make recommendations to the Minister on anti-dumping or countervailing action;
endorse Professor Gruen's view that there should be no `national interest' provision written into the legislation;
retain section 5 (9) of the Anti-Dumping Act dealing with certain criteria for the determination of normal values; and
introduce a mechanism under which anti-dumping and countervailing measures will cease after three years continuous application.

The Australian Customs Service still has an important role to play in the determination of dumping and subsidisation complaints. The Australian customs service will examine each complaint made, and conduct preliminary investigations, the results of which will form the basis of information from which the Anti-Dumping Authority commences its own inquiry.
I turn now to each Bill individually.
ANTI-DUMPING AUTHORITY BILL 1988

This Bill establishes an independent authority, which will recommend to the Minister whether grounds exist as to whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed, and to provide the Minister with advice on anti-dumping issues in general.

Anti-dumping decisions require judgments to be made involving a mix of economic and commercial considerations. The Government considers that these judgments can best be made by a small independent statutory authority whose staff will include commercial and economic specialists.
The Government believes that the Authority will bring a broader perspective to the determination of such issues as material injury and causal link.

The sensitivity of dumping complaints also requires a body operating at arm's length from the day to day administration of industry assistance by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Australian Customs Service.
Accordingly, an Anti-Dumping Authority is established. The Authority is to:
advise the Minister as to whether or not dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed on goods (clause 7)
recommend whether the Minister should revoke a notice issued under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975, or release exporters from undertakings made pursuant to the Act (clause 7);
review preliminary anti-dumping decisions of the comptroller (clause 8); and
prepare and give reports to the Minister on anti-dumping matters (clause 9).

In exercising these responsibilities, clause 10 requires the Authority to have regard to the Government's intention that anti-dumping duties are not used as a substitute means of providing assistance to import competing industry in Australia, nor to shield industry from the need to adjust to changing economic conditions. The Authority is also to have regard to Australia's obligations under the GATT codes.

The Bill also provides for the responsible Minister to issue further directions to the Authority to assist it in its interpretation of the legislation where considered necessary. The aim is to ensure that the Authority is guided by the current industry policy objectives of the Government in its assessment of such issues. Any supplementary guidance will be developed by the responsible Minister in consultation with interested ministerial colleagues. Clause 12 provides that ministerial directions are to be gazetted and tabled in Parliament, and that such directions are to deal with general principles, and not with particular consignments of goods.

Assessments of material injury and the causal link must be rigorous and anti-dumping measures should not be used as a de facto form of protection: it has to be seen as a set of measures to discourage unacceptable short term threats to knock out an industry in the importing country in order to increase longer term market share. The Authority will take into account the influence of factors other than dumping in causing injury, such as general economic conditions, production difficulties, domestic competition or undumped import competition when assessing whether a direct linkage exists between dumping and injury to an Australian industry. In this task, the Authority will have the benefit of additional comprehensive data since the preliminary finding stage, as well as the independent examination of all the evidence by its own staff which will have specialist qualifications, particularly in the economic field.

The Government did not accept Professor Gruen's recommendation that section 5 (9) of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act be repealed. Section 5 (9) of the Act precludes `normal' values being based on domestic sales which have been, for an extended period, at prices which do not permit recovery of costs incurred in the production and sale of the goods; in other words, where domestic sales in the exporting country are being consistently made at a loss. The Government considers that the repeal of this section would put Australia out of step with other countries that use GATT anti-dumping mechanisms to counter unfair trading practices. Canada, the EEC and the United States all have and use sections equivalent to section 5 (9) in their legislation.

The Government proposes, however, that aspects of the use of section 5 (9) will be tightened to ensure that wherever possible market based prices are used in normal value determinations and that the application of section 5 (9) is consistent with the rationale behind the new anti-dumping provisions. The Government expects that the Authority, when using section 5 (9), will use an appropriately wide time frame over which to weigh the prices and costs which are to be taken into account. In addition when using section 5 (9), unless there are strong reasons to the contrary, a zero profit is to be assumed by the Authority.

Consistent with its intention that anti-dumping and countervailing measures do not become a substitute form of ongoing assistance, the Government has also decided that anti-dumping and countervailing measures will lapse after three years. This means that all measures in respect of a particular commodity will expire at the same three year time limit, irrespective of the duration of measures relating to individual countries of export. The sunset provision will also apply to voluntary undertakings which have been given by exporters or governments of the exporting countries so as to resolve satisfactorily dumping or countervailing complaints. Such undertakings are normally price related and are offered so as to remove the material injury caused without the imposition of a duty. This will maintain consistency within the system.

The sunset clause will not prevent industry from seeking to renew anti-dumping or countervailing action. It will mean however that injury and other aspects required to justify such action will be fully retested after three years of continuous application before anti-dumping or countervailing measures can be re-imposed.

The Bill provides for the Anti-Dumping Authority to commence operation on a date to be fixed by proclamation. For preliminary findings made subsequent to the proclamation date, the Authority will finalise the inquiry and recommend appropriate action to the Minister. For inquiries in progress beyond the preliminary finding stage at the date of proclamation, the Authority will if practicable advise the Minister on all matters where the ACS recommends the imposition of anti-dumping or countervailing measures.
Part III of the Bill provides for the establishment and staffing of the Authority.

The person who is to be appointed as the member of the Authority under clause 13 will be a person with economic and commercial skills and a knowledge of Australian industry. Clause 15 permits associate members to assist the member with specific inquiries, or for a specific period of time. There is also provision for the engagement of consultants with particular expertise.
The Government concurs with Professor Gruen that the anti-dumping legislation should not contain a `national interest' provision.

The Government considers that such a provision would add to the uncertainty of the proceedings, would lead to administrative complexity and would increase the costs to participants. The range of issues which could be regarded as relevant in each case could no doubt be broadened and the way would be open for parties with indirect interests to claim a right to present views to the Authority and have them taken into account by the Minister in making his decision. Proceedings could thus become unnecessarily complex and protracted.

While it is not defined in the Bill, the Minister will take national interest criteria into account in exercising his discretion in considering the reports of the Anti-Dumping Authority. One problem which adds complexity to considering dumping in a context of national interest is that many of the imports complained of come from countries where Australia already has a large trade surplus.
The issues of dumping have both economic and political significance and circumstances can change with disconcerting speed; hence the need to maintain or even enhance ministerial discretion.

However, clause 23 of the Bill requires the Authority to widely advertise the fact that it is holding an inquiry into whether injurious dumping or subsidisation is occurring in a particular industry and invite submissions from the public. Subclause 7 (6) obliges the Authority to consider such submissions made in response to the invitation. The effect of these measures is to formalise for the first time the consideration of contributions from persons other than those directly interested in the dumping action, thus adding to the integrity and openness of the review process.

I might also mention that clause 9 of the Bill will permit the Government or the Authority to initiate anti-dumping inquiries where facts produced by interests indirectly concerned with a dumping issue can justify such action.

Clause 29 of the Bill requires an annual report of the Authority to be tabled in the Parliament. The report will include coverage of the Authority's operations during the year, the operation and development of guidelines, the Authority's approach to its assessments and important issues that have arisen in relation to anti-dumping action generally. This will introduce more openness to the consideration of anti-dumping issues.

The Authority is being established for five years. However, a review of the effectiveness of the performance of the revised anti-dumping system will be undertaken after three years. I believe that the gathering together of specialists, under a person possessing particular expertise to give advice to the Government in an economically sensitive area like the imposition of dumping duties on exports from Australia's overseas trading partners is an efficient use of scarce government resources, as well as being an effective means of ensuring the Government receives quality advice in the anti-dumping field. This approach to the administration of anti-dumping legislation is similar to the procedures used by other signatories to the GATT anti-dumping codes such as Canada and the United States.
CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS) BILL 1988

The Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill establishes the role in the dumping mechanism to be played by the Australian Customs Service, which, as I mentioned earlier, will be to examine each dumping complaint and conduct preliminary investigations, including overseas enquiries. The results of these investigations will then form the basis of information upon which the Anti-Dumping Authority may commence its inquiry.

The Bill contains specific provisions (new section 269tb in particular) to make it clear that an application for imposition of dumping or countervailing duties i.e. a complaint, may be made by any person on behalf of the relevant Australian industry affected or likely to be affected by the dumping or subsidisation. For example, primary producers may lodge complaints in respect of injury being caused to processors and employees or their representatives might initiate action when the industry is inhibited from doing so.

It will also be possible for complaints to be made before allegedly dumped or subsidised goods have arrived in Australia where there is adequate knowledge that imports of dumped or subsidised goods are to arrive in volumes which will cause injury to an Australian industry.

The Bill also imposes for the first time statutory time limits within which the Customs Service must determine its investigations. Where a person complains that an act of injurious dumping or subsidisation has occurred or is likely to occur, the Bill provides in new section 269tc that the Customs Service will have a maximum of 70 days to determine whether the facts alleged in the application constitute sufficient prima facie evidence to warrant commencement of an investigation.
If a prima facie case is established, the Customs Service then has a maximum of 180 days to make a preliminary finding as to whether dumping or countervailing duties should be imposed.

Where such preliminary findings are positive, the Comptroller-General of Customs may decide to impose securities as provisional measures in respect of any dumping or countervailing duty that may become payable, and he then must refer the matter to the Anti-Dumping Authority within 7 days for its independent examination and report to the Minister.

It should also be noted that decisions by the Comptroller-General of Customs that no prima facie case has been established, or a preliminary finding that duties should not be imposed, are subject to merit review by the independent Anti-Dumping Authority.
CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

Finally, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill amends the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 by inserting a statutory definition of `like goods' (a Gruen recommendation which adopts the definition of the term as applied in the GATT), allowing for the publication of the normal value of goods in clauses 9 to 12. Further, clause 13 provides that duties and undertakings will only be current for a period of three years, adopting the Gruen recommendation that dumping measures and the like should only remain current for a limited period of time. An industry which has benefited from short term relief under this legislation must in future rejustify the necessity for continued relief.

The Bill finally makes various amendments to existing provisions to ensure that the relief under the Act is only available if dumping or subsidisation damages an Australian industry producing like goods to the goods that have been dumped; not Australian industry generally.

It should be noted however that there has been no change to section 13 of the Act, relating to the retrospective application of dumping duty on imported goods following the publication of a dumping notice.

The Government is prepared, consistent with its international obligations, to make full use of that section to impose retrospective duties in critical circumstances to ensure that Australian industries are adequately protected against importers who knowingly cause material damage to an Australian industry through large scale imports of a product over a short period of time.

In conclusion the Government believes that the new arrangements embodied in these three Bills will improve significantly Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing system and are consistent with Australia's rights and obligations under GATT and with the Government's industry policy. The system will provide a balanced approach to protecting Australian industry from clearly unfair trading practices while at the same time ensuring that the measures do not constitute an unjustifiable impediment to international trade.
Financial Impact Statement
The Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill have no direct financial implications.

It is estimated that the establishment of the Anti-Dumping Authority will involve expenditure of $1.12m in the first year of operation and $0.92m in subsequent years. These figures include the salary costs of the statutory appointee and for a secretariat of up to 16 persons. These resources are to come from appropriations made to elements of the portfolio of the Minister of Industry, Technology and Commerce.
I commend the Bills to the Senate and table each Bill's explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill will give effect to a number of the amendments to the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development foreshadowed in the joint news release issued on 20 November 1987 by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). The decisions announced then followed a technical review of the concession, which the Government promised when introducing the Income Tax Assessment (Research and Development) Bill 1986. The review was undertaken with the assistance of external consultants and sought to identify ways in which the concession might be exploited other than as intended; and how it might be made more effective in achieving its objectives of encouraging greater investment in research and development by industry in Australia. In the context of that review, decisions were taken to curtail eligibility to the 150 per cent research and development tax concession for expenditures incurred on buildings and to clarify the law in respect of claims to costs of developing computer software. These were introduced in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to all those decisions which will directly involve the Industry Research and Development Board. The remaining decisions arising from the technical review affect only the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and will be introduced during the Budget sittings.

The powers of the Industry Research and Development Board are to be extended and legislation relating to the powers and functions of that Board are, by this Bill, to be included in the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 under which the Board is constituted. Importantly, the amendments will give additional discretionary powers to the Board.
I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-
The more significant of these are:

To reduce the incidence of companies being required to reimburse tax benefits, the Board will be empowered to refuse to register a company which, on the basis of information provided for registration purposes, is found to be ineligible for the concession.

To increase access by smaller firms to expert R&D assistance, the benefits of exemption from the threshold of annual R&D expenditure and an opportunity to claim for advance payments for ``contracted research'' will be extended to Registered Research Agencies (RRAs). Registration will be provided by the IR&D Board in the field of competence of the applicant RRA. Unlike Approved Research Institutes (ARIs), RRAs may be privately owned and profit-making entities.

To assist the financing of R&D ventures which are too costly or too risky to be advanced by those with the means to use the results themselves, the amendments provide that the Board may, if satisfied as to the bona fides of the venture, jointly register the participants. This is designed to give some surety of tax benefits to the participants. Joint registration will also enable them to claim in advance costs incurred in funding the venture. The details of this `dispensation' which were announced on 17 April 1988 are as follows:
150% TAX CONCESSION: CLAIMING CONTRACT EXPENDITURE AND CONTRIBUTIONS TO SYNDICATED R&D

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator John Button, today gave further details of amendments to the 150% tax concession scheme for R&D where it related to claiming for expenditure incurred for R&D performed under contract including that involving syndicated R&D.
This follows the joint statement Senator Button and the Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, made on 20 November 1987 covering amendments to the 150% tax concession provisions.

``It is taking longer to bring a Bill before the Parliament than had been expected, and it is necessary for industry to know the rules that are to apply to claims when companies incur expenditures for R&D that has not yet been performed,'' the Minister said.

As the 20 November statement indicated, companies will no longer be able to claim expenditures on R&D until the R&D had been carried out. But where R&D is performed under contract, there may be legal and practical difficulties in the claimant ascertaining what expenditures have been incurred by the contractor. It is proposed, therefore, that claims for advanced payments will be apportioned over the specified term of the R&D contract. Companies other than those to which a ``dispensation'' is allowed, will be able to claim in each income year only the proportion of any advance payment that relates to the claim period.

For example, a company for which the income year ends on 30 June that pays other company in April to undertake a three-year program of R&D on its behalf, will be able to claim only one twelfth (3/36) of the pre-payment in the first year (i.e. the pro-rated amount for the three months April to June), one-third (12/36) in each of the second and third years and a quarter(9/36) in the final year.
However, in line with the earlier announcement, a ``dispensation'' will apply to eligible companies that:
contract R&D to a Registered Research Agency (until the enactment of amending legislation, and Approved Research Institute); or
invest in projects of R&D that have been given ``in principle'' approval by the Industry Research and Development Board to ``syndicate'' arrangements.
Companies entitled to dispensations may, in the first year only for which a claim is made in respect of the project, claim in advance for the following 12 months.

If the company given as an example above incurs expenditures under either of the circumstances in which a dispensation is allowed, it may claim 15/36 of the prepayment in the first year, 12/36 in the second and the balance (9/36) in the third year.

Senator Button said that it was important to prevent companies engaging in artificial arrangements for tax planning purposes. The apportionment requirement, coupled with provisions to prevent mis-stating the term of a project, would achieve that end.

The dispensation to companies incurring ``contracted expenditure'' and to companies investing in approved syndicated arrangements was also important. Those performing the R&D would not normally be able to work without advance payments.

The Minister said that he looked to the dispensation to encourage closer collaboration in R&D and to assist those companies seeking funds for major projects the size and risk of which were too large for any one organisation to fund alone.

``It is intended that amendments to give effect to the changes announced in November 1987, including the provisions covering the matters announced today, will be introduced to the Parliament as soon as practicable,'' Senator Button said.

In that context, he noted that some legislation had already been introduced. Further legislation relating to the powers of the IR&D Board would be introduced shortly. The remainder of the legislation will be introduced in the Budget sittings.
The Minister said he hoped companies would invest in research and development that promised to increase their future international competitiveness.

The amendments are also designed to better equip the IR&D Board to act against those exploiting the concession in a manner contrary to the intent of the tax concession. The Board will be able to move against companies which:
claim for a project which has an insufficient Australian content; and
fail, in any significant way, to exploit the results of revenue subsidised R&D in the required manner.

The Government believes that, by virtue of its collective experience and the individual competence and integrity of its members, the Board is uniquely placed to reach decisions on the technical and commercial issues which it must decide. However, it also recognises that opinions are necessarily reached on the basis of evidence provided by companies and that this may sometimes be ill expressed or incomplete. Accordingly, this Bill provides that the Board will not be able to move against a company until it has given that company an opportunity to make a submission in response to the stated reasons for the Board's opinion.

It is also important that companies not be able to frustrate the Board in the exercise of its functions in respect of the 150% tax concession. Where a company fails within a reasonable period to give the Board such information relating to its activities as the Board reasonably requires, the Board may, by notice in writing, require that information to be provided within 30 days. The Bill provides that, if the company fails to comply with the notice, the Board may issue a certificate to the Commissioner of Taxation with the effect that expenditure of the company in respect of the activities which are the subject of the notice is disallowed.

The Board's responsibilities have increased significantly since it was established and it now has six Committees advising it. These cover the Taxation Concession, Discretionary grants, National Procurement Development grants, and each of the four declared generic technology fields for which grants are available. In these circumstances, it is considered appropriate to extend the maximum size of the Board by 3 members. Further, not only should the Board be able to delegate some of its functions to its Committees, but that the Committees should be able to delegate functions to individual members and support staff. Amendments introduced today will permit this.
The Bill will also make certain consequential and complementary amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The principal effect of those amendments will be to recognise the creation under the Industry Research and Development Act of registered research agencies which are to replace approved research institutes for the purposes of the tax concession.

The Government intends to prevent exploitation of the benefits of incurring contracted expenditure for tax minimisation purposes or as a substitute to obtaining joint registration for certain collaborative ventures. Companies will be unable to incur contracted expenditure to a registered research agency to whom they are related. In addition claimants will be required to have a plan to use the results in connection with an existing or proposed business.

There is to be some modification by the Bill of the provisions which disallow deductions for expenditure claimed under the tax concession on receipt by the Commissioner of Taxation of various certificates by the Board. These amendments will take into account the additional powers which the Bill will confer on the Board to issue certificates. These have been outlined above.

A decision of the Board, expressed in a certificate stipulating whether particular activities are research and development activities, is binding on the Commissioner of Taxation. However, if a certificate is subsequently revoked, the deduction is revived.

The 150% tax concession has been available to companies for expenditures incurred since 1 July 1985. The Government has made it clear that the concession will remain in place until 30 June 1991. Companies have had the benefit of the concession for 3 years. They will have that benefit for a further 3 years.

It is too soon to assess the effectiveness of the tax concession as an incentive in encouraging performance of R&D which would not otherwise have been undertaken. However, there is evidence, including that provided by the Australian Statistician's recent catalogue ``Research and Development, Business Enterprises, Australia, 1986-87, Preliminary'', that since 1985 there has been a welcome increase in real expenditure on R&D by private business enterprises in Australia. Anecdotal evidence indicates that much of the additional reported R&D would not have been undertaken but for the tax concession. This appears particularly true for smaller companies.

The Bureau of Industry Economics has started to collect data against which to assess the effectiveness of the tax concession. This matter is to be considered by the Government in 1990. In particular, the Government will be looking closely at the return the Australian community stands to gain from the generous subsidy currently available to companies claiming the research and development tax concession.

Ministers in this Government have repeatedly spoken of the need for growth in high technology based industries and the revitalisation of traditional Australian industries through innovation, training and application of new industrial management techniques.

The world is less dependent on Australian commodities now than at any time this century. International trade is also becoming increasingly competitive. If Australian companies are to survive to the year 2000, they need to invest as much or more in researching, developing, targeting and marketing products as their overseas competitors. At present most are not. The latest statistics suggest that, typically, Australian companies invest in research and development only half that of world competitive companies. Before the introduction of the tax concession it was a third. The progress of the last three years is encouraging but not sufficient.

It is important to recognise that potential competitors are also increasing their innovation and marketing efforts. Unless industry management recognises research and development as a necessary investment for corporate survival and that investment in new technology must at least increase with the pace of technological change, Australia's relative performance may well worsen despite any absolute growth in research and development performance.

The Government's commitment to maintain the present tax concession arrangements until the end of June 1991 provides sufficient opportunity for industry to establish the technology base for new businesses in Australia. There is a goldmine of commercially exploitable research in government funded research organisations and academic institutions. There is no shortage of innovative ideas and enthusiasm in some of our smaller companies. Yet these companies often lack the funds, the development facilities, the production means and the marketing infrastructure to realise the potential of their ideas.

The provisions of this Bill establish the means for garnering funds which would not otherwise be available for research and development. It is for this reason that the Government is seeking early passage of this Bill.
Financial Impact Statement

To the extent that the amendments are successful in stimulating research and development which would not otherwise have been undertaken during the deduction period (i.e. up to 30 June 1991), there will be some additional tax revenue costs in fiscal 1988/89 and the three following years. Offsetting this, there will be savings due to the tightening up of provisions to limit avenues by which the 150 per cent tax concession may be exploited other than as intended. It is estimated that the net funding impact of all the changes proposed as a result of the Technical Review will be broadly neutral.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Film Commission Act 1975 to enable the implementation of the Government's decision to establish Film Australia Pty Ltd as a wholly Commonwealth-owned company. It is the Government's intention that the new company should operate from 1 July this year. Honourable senators will know that Film Australia and its antecedents have a unique place in Australian cinematic history. In one form or another it has existed as the Commonwealth's film making body for three-quarters of a century. In this time it has set and maintained the high standards for Australian film makers that have made the local industry among the leaders in innovation and technical excellence. Indeed, many of the internationally acclaimed Australian film makers of today spent part of their training at Film Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate the rest of the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator GARETH EVANS

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1975 Film Australia became part of the Australian Film Commission, where it was responsible, as the Production Division, for the `special activities' of the Commission. These activities are defined in the Act as

INTERJECT.PARA: (i) programs that serve the purposes of a Department of State or an Authority of the Commonwealth;
(ii) programs that deal with matters of national interest to Australia; and
(iii) programs that are designed to illustrate or interpret aspects of Australia or of the life and activities of the Australian people.

In its new form Film Australia will continue to carry out these functions. In May last year, after a comprehensive review, the Government decided that Film Australia should be removed from the umbrella of the Australian Film Commission and established as a wholly Commonwealth-owned company to operate along commercial lines as far as practicable.

The Government is looking to a reorganised and revitalised Film Australia to reduce the cost of its productions, to achieve more effective dissemination of programs through cooperative arrangements with local and overseas networks, and to pursue more vigorously off-budget revenue sources. In other words, the Government expects the new organisation to be more attuned to the realities of the marketplace.

Production of national interest programs dealing with cultural, social and other issues relevant to Australians will be met by contractual arrangements between the Commonwealth and the company. The company will be offered secure minimum funding over a fixed term, and to this end the Government has agreed to a total forward funding commitment of $15m, at 1987 prices, over the next three financial years to allow orderly production planning.
I now turn to the provisions of the Bill. Once again I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate the remainder of the second reading speech in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator GARETH EVANS

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill seeks to achieve three objectives. It removes from the Australian Film Commission the function of making films and television programs, which will become the responsibility of the new Film Australia Pty Ltd. Second, it provides for the transfer of assets, liabilities and contractual rights and obligations from the Commission to the new company. Third, it provides for the transfer of specified staff.

INTERJECT.PARA: There are also a number of consequential amendments to the Act. I would mention in this regard that the repeal of section 9 of the Act, that deals with the high standards of film making expected of the Commission under its now superseded power to make films, does not mean any diminution of the high standards expected of the Commission in general terms. Subparagraphs 5 (1a) (a) and (b), which are not affected by this Bill, adequately cover that point.

There are no other implications for the residual functions of the Australian Film Commission. The Commission will retain the power to promote and distribute, but not to make programs. Film Australia Pty Ltd is now in the process of incorporation in the Australian Capital Territory in the normal way under the Companies Act 1981. A number of prominent Australians have been approached to become the directors of the new company, with backgrounds in the film industry, commerce, law, and entrepreneurial activity.

The introduction of this Bill confirms the Government's commitment to a continuing role for Film Australia as a producer of films about Australians and for Australians. Incorporation of Film Australia under the Companies Act provides the opportunity for a fresh start. It will place the organisation in a strong position to capitalise on the success it has achieved in the past. I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Puplick) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the adjournment tonight I wish to refer to the Work Skill Australia Foundation competition which has again started for this year. Of the 30 competitions that will take place during the year, the first was held in Canberra last Saturday and Sunday. The occasion was most impressive with the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) participating in 18 of the categories for which competitions are run by Work Skill Australia. All honourable senators will remember the successful International Skills Olympics which were run in Australia in February this year during which Australia did particularly well coming third behind Korea and Taiwan. Canberra brought home two silver medals in plumbing and industrial electronics.

SPEECH.PARA: The impressive feature of Work Skill Australia is that it is a voluntary organisation and particularly impressive was the number of local people on the regional committee chaired by Mr Chas Cook, the number of people who give their time for the whole of the weekend to participate as judges, the many people who sponsor the competition and the many people from the technical and further education colleges in Canberra who also participate. The competition will run throughout the year and will take place in 30 centres throughout Australia. Finally, the winners will be known and they will participate in the international competition that flows from it. I wish all those who participated well, especially those from the Australian Capital Territory who will now go on to the next stage. I trust that some at least will participate in the international competition which takes place at the end of this series of events. Many from the Australian Capital Territory who had previously been medal winners were there assisting and they made a fine contribution having had the benefit of being in the competition before.

Tonight I particularly want to say to the benefactors, sponsors, organisers and all who participate in facilitating Work Skill Australia that I believe they are doing a great job giving the young people the opportunity of competing. I wish them and the Foundation well in the 1988 competition.
