PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Community Services and Health: Unattached Employees

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 22 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister provide details of how many employees of the Department are presently listed as unattached (to a substantive position within the Department).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There are 329 unattached employees in the Department by comparison with its approved average staffing level of 6,857. As staffing of the Department's new organisation proceeds, this number will reduce.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 16 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What percentage of the Australian Defence Forces regular personnel are of ethnic origin and what percentage of regular officers are of ethnic origin.
(2) What percentage of the Australian Defence Forces reserve personnel are of ethnic origin and what percentage of reserve officers are of ethnic origin.
(3) Is there any significant difference between the percentages of ethnic personnel in the Army, Navy and Air Force.
(4) Are people of ethnic origin encouraged to enlist in the Defence Forces.
(5) Are people of ethnic origin encouraged to seek promotion to officer status within the Army, Navy and Air Force.
(6) Does the Government intend to extend the Equal Opportunity legislation to the Defence Force; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Specific records are not kept which identify Defence Force members as belonging to any particular ethnic group.
(4) People of ethnic origin are encouraged to enlist in the Defence Force but they are required to meet the same criteria as all other applicants.
(5) The Defence Force does not make distinctions based on ethnic origins when considering personnel for promotion.

(6) No. The Defence Force does not discriminate in any way on ethnic grounds. However, it exercises an exemption under the terms of the Sex Discrimination Act (1984) which allows for women to be excluded from positions involving combat and combat-related duties.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 16 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a report in the Hobart Mercury regarding overservicing allegations levelled against a Hobart skin specialist, Dr Michael Readett.
(2) Does the Minister consider justice was done in the case of Dr Readett in that:
(a) 99.84 per cent of his practice was not criticised;
(b) only the profiles of 15 of over 10,000 new patients in the 5 year period were criticised (1 out of each 675);

(c) ministerial reliance was placed on 4 Tasmanian doctors of whom 3 live in Hobart, each of which sent patients to Dr Readett both before and after the enquiry, because they did not have the expertise or the facilities to treat them.
(3) What is the dermatological expertise of the members of the Committee that investigated the alleged overservicing.
(4) Are doctors who are not dermatologists able to accurately investigate and report on a doctor who is a specialist in this field.

(5) Is the Minister aware that the Chairman was on long term sick leave from his practice and another member had recently had long spells of sick leave and none of them had had any specialist dermatological experience to match Dr Readett's extensive experience.
(6) Did a dermatologist attend some hearings but did not write a report, or offer any criticism of Dr Readett's work.

(7) Were the documents seen by a senior dermatologist on the mainland who can see no sign of overservicing, particularly as many facilities for treating skin patients in Melbourne and Sydney are not available in Hobart.
(8) Is the Committee's report inconsistent when it criticises some profiles, but accepts profiles of other patients with similar conditions seen at more frequent intervals and on more occasions.
(9) Are all cases of a condition such as psoriasis similar.

(10) Does the Minister believe that there is a limit-even in exceptionally severe chronic medical cases-on how many times a month or a year a patient with a particular condition can be treated, and whether such a figure is relevant to Hobart with poorer facilities as well as Melbourne, and whether this figure is to be enforced even in the 1 in 675 of the most severely affected patients; and if so, does not the Minister accept that the outlook for the chronic sick in Australia is grim.
(11) Does the Minister still believe in bulk billing.

(12) Is the Minister aware that Dr Readett never asked for more than the rebate, did not charge for many short visits or visits associated with minor operations and so saved Medicare well over 10 times the amount in question.

(13) Is the Minister aware that bills for another $200,000 for the gap could have been issued, or even over $450,000 over the 5 year period if Dr Readett had charged the Australian Medical Association fees.

(14) Does the Minister realise that expenses in a dermatological practice are high and that Dr Readett received in his pocket out of the $4,032 involved, less than $500 over the 5 year period, in fact just over 20 cents a day.
(15) Does the Minister feel that Dr Readett has been properly and decently treated.
(16) Will the Minister now consider referring the profiles to specialist dermatologists who would be competent to judge.

(17) Is the Minister prepared to consider changing the Act so that true peers are appointed in such cases, or so that such problems can be sorted out in a court of law where evidence can be brought by both sides, with cross questioning, in the open, and where, in Dr Readett's case, all the patients whose portfolios have been criticised could substantiate their statutory declarations which state that they needed all the treatment, were not over-treated, came willingly (one person came over seventy miles) and resented the slur on Dr Readett and themselves as they feel they are not so naive as to come for treatment unnecessarily, especially as coming involves much time and money even if they were bulk billed.
(18) Is the Minister aware that at the relative time, there were only 2 dermatologists in Hobart against the national average of 5 for the population involved.

(19) Can the Minister justify the estimated $125 000 spent on the inquiry and does he feel that it is in keeping with common law, natural justice and the Australian Constitution, because once a profile has been selected by a computer as unusual, for whatever reason, the Doctor is guilty until and unless he can prove himself innocent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) and (b) As is normal, the Committee had referred to it only a small sample of patients from the particular practice. It is not a matter of 99.84% of his practice not being criticised. It is a matter of 99.84% of his practice not being reviewed by the Committee. The Committee considered 44 of Dr Readett's patients and found that excessive services had been provided to 15 patients. That is, 34% of the patients considered had received excessive services.
(c) This bears no relevance to whether the services considered were excessive.

(3) The dermatological expertise of individual Committee members is not relevant. However, the Committee as a whole must be satisfied that it has sufficient evidence before it to make a recommendation. The Committee may engage consultants and call witnesses. In Dr Readett's case, the Committee sought the advice of a specialist in dermatology who attended seven of the Committee's sittings.
(4) Yes, given their general knowledge of medical practice and procedure and using appropriate specialist consultants.
(5) No, however, these members must have considered themselves sufficiently well to continue with the inquiry. The latter part of this question is addressed in (3) and (4) above.

(6) The Committee sought the assistance of a specialist in dermatology, nominated by the Royal Australian College of Dermatologists. The role of such an adviser is not to criticise the practitioner under inquiry; rather to provide advice to the Committee on accepted practice within a particular speciality or for a particular type of procedure.

(7) The Committee, as previously stated, sought the assistance of a specialist in dermatology. That specialist came from Melbourne. I understand that Dr Readett has claimed that senior dermatologists had perused the documents and could find no case for any action. Presumably he made such documents available for their inspection. It was open to Dr Readett to call that evidence during the inquiry.

(8) The Committee is not inconsistent if it finds that various patients with apparently similar complaints required differing medical management. The Committee reviews the treatment provided to each individual patient included in the inquiry and does not set some arbitrary figure which is to be applied across the whole of the doctor's practice.
(9) I am unable to comment on the medical details of psoriasis. It is for that reason that an expert Committee has been appointed.

(10) The notion of a limit on attendances for a particular condition fails to appreciate the individual treatment needs of each patient. Because Medical Services Committees of Inquiry have been established in each State, a particular State committee can take into account variations in treatment brought about by differing facilities.

(12) and (13) Medical practitioners are free to charge the amount they consider appropriate for medical services. In the context of whether a medical service is excessive, the charge for that service is of no interest to the Committee.
(14) Dr Readett's practice expenses bear no relevance to the Committee's determination.
(17) Under the present provisions of the Health Insurance Act 1973, the practitioner is already able to:
(i) be represented;
(ii) call witnesses;
(iii) cross examine other witnesses;
(iv) address the Committee; and
(v) to give evidence.

(18) Yes. However, the number of dermatologists in Hobart is not relevant. The Committee does not review the number of patients consulting the referred practitioner, but rather whether the services provided to the patients in the reference were medically necessary.
(19) A significant deterrent effect is achieved by these cases. The estimated costs of the inquiry were:
Fees and travel for Committee members...6,235.00
Members preparation time (for reports etc)...295.00
Consultant's fees, travel and accommodation...4,212.64
Total Costs of the inquiry excluding the secretariat...10,742.64

Medical practitioners appearing before a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry are requested to explain to other medical practitioners the reasons and basis for their past treatment of patients. I believe Committee inquiries are fair and comply with the requirements of natural justice.
